East-West has a variety of services to offer to incoming as well as current students. To be more specific, East-West teachers are great resources for school work. Through the East-West e-mail system, most teachers are available to help students. Different extracurricular activities and student led clubs bring school spirit to East-West. Guidance counselors are readily accessible with outstanding work ethics and personalities. Teachers engage students through the use of smart boards, laptops and projectors. Our ever-changing global world is in need of Japanese, Korean and Chinese speakers; something that East-West prepares its students for. Everything that East-West offers to its students is whole-heartedly made to benefit and succeed in the real world.

I came to East-West, freshmen year, as a shy, not very out-spoken, antisocial individual. This all changed as I became more engaged with school activities and befriended many people. I graduated this year as the valedictorian. Through studying Asian language and culture, I became more aware of the world around me in terms of the global community. I’m proud to say that, when saying ‘hello’ in Japanese or Korean, one must bow. My experiences in East-West have taught how to be a leader in various clubs, mature as an individual, perform hours of community service as a humanitarian, become independent as a young adult and a better person in general. The East-West experience is unforgettable and will open many opportunities in the future with the all the skills and tools gained over four years. I left East-West as a completely different person, for the better. 

In East-West, I have also grown as language learner. Learning Chinese was hard, but a very rewarding experience. Recently, I was accepted into the Chinese Flagship Center Program at Hunter College, where I will be able to fluently speak Chinese after four years. The first three years of the program, I will have the luxury to learn Mandarin Chinese. Eventually, the last year of my career at Hunter College as a student, I will be sent to China to study at Nanjing University for a semester and then an internship in China, the second semester. This major in Chinese is a complement to my International Relations major, where I will be studying to pursue a career as an ambassador or diplomat to China in the future. If it wasn't for East-West, I wouldn't be where I am today.

My only problem with this school is that it's small. Besides that, this school is great. I am enjoying my time at East-West and I don't have a problem with the uniforms. Most of the students pass their regents and there is tutoring almost everyday if students need help. It's not the teacher's fault if a student is failing. If a student really did care about his grades he would spend less time "hanging out" and dedicate a majority of his time to afterschool/beforeschool tutoring. And because it's a less crowded school (unlike Francis Lewis) a student has more one-on-one opportunities with a teacher. I LOVE EAST-WEST! >:D

I am currently a graduate of this school, East West School
of International Studies. I remember when I went to a high school fair when I
was in 8th grade, looking for a good high school that wasn’t typical
or boring to me. When I first met Mr. Sherman and some of the other students
who are now alumni of our school, I instantly knew that this school would have
my attention.  liked that this school offered Asian languages, because not
many other schools do. I wanted to learn more about China.

I signed up for information about
East West because of the languages that were taught, the technology and the
school clubs they had offered. Due to some funding issues, we didn't have as
many clubs as we intended on participating in but the school did have some
technology that grew in number as the years went by. Attending East West, I
studied Chinese. We had the opportunity of choosing which language we wanted to
learn and Chinese was the language for me, as there is a demand for people who
are bilingual or even trilingual.

East West is an interesting school
with students who treat each other like family. As the years go by, people
became very close, often including newcomers into our humble family. Strong
friendships have been formed and I will definitely miss my family but attending
East West helped us all to prepare for the real world, the world of college and
society. Projects, entertainment, caring teachers and leaders, friends who
support you and extra help is what is found at school, my school, the East West
School of International Studies.

I have attended East-West since its' start. I've watched it grow from a school that included only two grades to what it has become today. I want to start off my talking about my first impression of the school. At first, I was against going to this school because it was new and I would have to meet a crowd of completely new people. From what I read about the school, it had many ambitions and promises to not only the students but as East-West as a whole. My first year was an interesting experience and it wasn't surprising that nearly everyone knew each other. However, the community didn't know much about the school, which was the main reason behind the lack of spirit of our students. The school itself lacked a lot, maybe because it was new. I remember one of the promises the school had made for us was giving every student their own personal PDA. We were promised this the second year and we still didn't receive them...Eventually the faculty stopped with this ongoing promise. Many students were also against the school uniform and found different ways to disobey the rules, knowing that they wouldn't receive a harsh punishment. The first year, honestly, wasn't the greatest for me because the students in the school had a very negative impact on me and I didn't feel the support from the staff either. But, we didn't have a few memorable school events that brought us together. By the end of the first school year, a number of students and teachers had left the school to move onto another one. The second year was interesting because it was the first step towards our growth; we had more students and more room. This was the year when there were several issues in our school...We didn't really have clubs and the students didn't get along right away. I remember the first and second year, no one really had a desire to be involved and make a change, including me. The year went by like any other and many of my friends moved onto what they labeled as "better" high schools. I really wondered if this school would lead me to less opportunities in the future. Through the following two years, our school began showing a spark of potential. One example of this was east-west holding the very first talent show. We began having more clubs such as Student Government. This really allowed the students to have a voice and to be able to communicate with the administration. We had our first graduating class and many of them ended up in great colleges/universities. Our school became more known in the community. It was a positive change for east-west. This has shown us the success of our school and students. Our students have achieved scholarships, high grades, and have been able to represent the rest of the school. We've have many events that have been enjoyable and a break from studies. This past year shows us that maybe this school will get somewhere.

I had the option to leave east-west a few years back but being able to find close relations with the people here, it was difficult for me to make that decision. One positive aspect of the school is the focus of east-asian studies. I enjoy being given the opportunity to learn about others and their cultures myself. It gave me a desire to want to learn and be self-determined. We are given opportunities such as visiting Japan, Korea, or China and even studying there. This is what makes our school stand our from the others. Honestly, before this school year, I wasn't involved in extracurricular activities within the school. But, once I joined, I enjoyed myself and I was able to learn with others, beyond the classroom. I also like how students acknowledge each other even if they've never talked to each other before. Many students are role models to our younger students and are able to help them when they don't feel comfortable with the staff.

What I believe the school still lacks is a challenge. Our students should be reaching high, not just being satisfied with passing grades. The students who work hard are able to obtain good grades with a breeze. But those who can't, struggle...I don't like that our school has students who aren't willing to work as hard as others. Students who hold us back from becoming the best are students who don't belong in this school. Another aspect which I would like to see in east-west is AP classes. Many other high schools have APs and it shows that students are just getting good grades in the required class but are reaching for a challenge. This may have a negative impact on the student's future for when they're applying to colleges. Our school also needs pride. There are too many students who hate going to this school and want to just make it through the year...There needs to be something to change their minds. If our students don't want to make a change, no one else will either. Two problems which I faced with this school was the importance of students vs. teachers and staff members. First off, there are staff members who are disrespectful and offensive to the students. This prevents the students from being comfortable to rely on the staff. I also had an issue when I had nearly $135 stolen from me in school...The staff members blamed me for this issue. They said I shouldn't have brought this large amount of money to school. I brought that money to school because it was my mom's birthday the next day and I had planned on buying her present after school. And our school should be a place where I can feel safe and not have to worry about safety of my belongings. Why do I have to be so cautious? I reported this incident to the teachers right after school and they told me to write a report on it. Days passed and nothing was done. I knew who the student was who stole my money but the staff claimed that I had no real evidence, even though I saw him with my money. Another case was when a teacher's wallet was stolen. When this was reported, the classroom was locked by the principal and the students were told that if we don't return this wallet, the police would be called and all of us would get in trouble. Eventually a student found the wallet and returned it...My objection is why isn't the school as concerned about the students as it is about the staff members. We are the ones who make this school a success therefore we should be given more rights. This means we need trust between our students and staff.

The experiences I've mentioned are those that I had a few years ago. It makes the school sounds really bad...But over the past year, I've realized that it isn't so bad. Sure, east-west isn't perfect but it is taking clear steps towards improving. The school just felt a better environment over the past year and the year before. It made me want to become involved and encourage other students as well. Several community members and organizations even know about school and appreciate its' efforts. It's getting better and I'm not ashamed of going to this school anymore, even though it took a long time for me to reach this point. I think we'll get there, one day we'll be able to reach to students as one of the "better" and brighter schools. I have had a few bad experiences in this school but I think I would have in any other school as well. I'm actually looking forward to the next school year and see what it brings for us.

Hi, my name is Asim and I’m a student at
East-West school of International Studies. I’m a senior and I’m graduating
tomorrow from this school. I have spend my four years of high school at
East-West. It’s a unique school containing about 600 students who have an
opportunity to learn Japanese, Korean and Chinese. East-West school focuses its
studies on the Asian culture. I learned Japanese at East-West. It’s one of the
great high schools which make you focus on achieving goals. It has an excellent
staff and teachers who care about students and their assertive goals.

I have had a good time in the 4 years I have been at East-West.
I was even given a scholarship to attend a free trip to Korea. I was exposed to
a completely new culture and observed how others on the other side of the globe
live their lives.  Our teachers also
traveled with us, one of them being Ms. Rhi, a Korean teacher, who helped us
travel around Korea and guide us around its amazing cities. 


 


The teachers here at East West also made it worthwhile. Most
of them offer tutoring and help on the subjects they teach. They really make
sure that almost all the students pass each marking period. I graduate tomorrow
and I can truly say that I am going to miss East-West. I have a lot of memories
here which I cherish, and a lot more to make as I leave with the things I
learned onto the road of success. Each step I take puts me closer to success and
East-West was one of those important steps. Every step takes me up closer to
success and there is no such thing as failure, just temporary failure disguised
as success, we just have to have our eyes and mind open when it appears.
GrowNYC awarded 29 NYC schools a Grow to Learn grant for creating garden classrooms.

My son, John So, is a 6th grader, and he loves the school so much that he wears his school uniforms almost 7 days a week, because he is so proud of being a student of EWSIS.  On the contrary, he hates to tell other people about his primary school, and he just doesn't want anyone to talk about it.  The teachers at EWSIS are very compassionate and caring, and they show respect for all students.  My son is just a "kid" with a "simple" mind (not diplomatic at all), who likes those he thinks are nice and dislikes those unpleasant.  My son always encourages his primary school classmates to switch to EWSIS for middle schooling, if they are not happy with their current middle schools.  The school spends a lot of time and resources on helping the "at-risk" students, hoping that these students can catch up with the syllabus and coursework.  My personal opinion is that EWSIS is the best middle school in the district, and I highly recommend P.5 students to consider EWSIS for their middle school and high school education - they definitely won't regret!

Just wonder whether or not John is an "at-risk" student?  If so, you have made a right choice because EWSIS is definitely the best school for your son.  Since the school is a "special" school, which accepts an abnormally high percentage of "at-risk" students in the district, the school has designed a lot of enrichment programs for these students.  The teachers sometimes even ask the "normal" students to do their own work during classes, because they need to spend time with the "at-risk" students to help them catch up with the subjects taught.  I can't say it's wrong, but I think it just benefits the "at-risk" students at the expense of the "normal and smart" students.  I am not saying the school is not a good school, but I think the school can do a better job if it can assign students of the same or similar level to the same class.  If there are three classes for each grade, then divide the students according to their performance.  The top 25 students go to one class, then the next 25, and so on.  I think it's more fair to every student, and this plan can retain smart students to stay with the school when they reach high school level.  Of course, this plan benefits the "at-risk" students, too.  To be honest, it's time for my kid to think of high school education, and I am struggling with it.  However, if the school designs different programs for different levels of students, I will definitely want my kid to stay with EWSIS.  Again, if a school cares "too much" about the at-risk students, how can it keep the brilliant students?  At least, it should try to design a program that is fair to all students (even if not 100% fair, try to be as close as possibloe).

Can't agree more!  Hope the school will take your advice!  While taking care of the "at-risk" students, the school should consider the normal and smart students, too.  This is the only way to retain good students, or the school can only attract "at-risk" students and won't have a track record.
normal, ouch somebody isn't very pc are they

I attended the East-West School of International Studies for my junior high school years (6th, 7th, and 8th grades). I am currently in 8th grade. I hope to not be attending this school for my four years of high school. I liked it at first, made friends immediately, liked my teachers for the most part. I very much liked the trial period you get to choose your language. There are three languages: Chinese, Japanese, and Korean. You get to try out each class to see what learning each language is like before you choose one. One thing I don't like about East-West is that there are no Black teachers and two Hispanic teachers. This website obviously hasn't updated it's EWSIS information because there are many more Black and Hispanic students. There are mostly White and Asian teachers. The school needs it's own building now that there are over 500 students. We have to attend one of classes in the auditorium with two other classes or in the library that doesn't really have enough space for us with those same to classes. Some teachers have a horrible accents so it is hard to understand them and nothing was done about it after my classmates and I complained about it. The teachers with the bad accents are mostly the language teachers so it's extremely difficult to understand instruction and the translation therefore hard to learn. Those also get visibly annoyed when asked to repeat what they have said so us students can understand it better. Since the school is small, there is constant feeling that everyone is in your business. Some of the teachers are actually good teachers and what they teach sticks while others not so much. Also, the uniform is very easy to go around. There are very many ways to bend the rules about uniform. Another thing is you're only supposed to use your locker for outside clothing (though it isn't, I have gym clothes, books, and shoes in my locker at all times), and only at certain times (no one follows this rule either). I would not recommend this school to anyone and I hope to go to another for my high school term.

Some points are fair statements, such as the use of lockers and the strong accent of the language teachers.  However, if students want to learn an Asian language during middle schooling, they have to adapt to the strong accent of the foreign language teachers.  In fact, how many people can master two languages at the same time without accent? There may be some, but definitely not a lot.  I won't say the school is perfect, because it does place a lot of emphasis on the "at-risk" students.  However, which school is a perfect school?  None.  Even Hunter College High School (HCHS) is not suitable for some students.  At least my son doesn't want to go to HCHS for his junior high and high school education (not because he's not brilliant enough to get into the school, but he just doesn't like it.)  Therefore, EWSIS is already a very good school in the district, because we just can't find a perfect school, which fits every student.

The article on this website was written a long time ago when there were a lot of promises. Most of them have not been kept. East West is still better than 237 but it is not a wonderful school. It has a lot of problems and it seems like the student population is going more and more down hill. Also, it seems like the teachers are going more and more down hill. The best teachers were the ones from 2006, like my daughter's science teacher and math teacher. Neither of them are here now and it is obvious that the staff changes have made a big impact. Mr. Solomon is not there either and he started his own school. The japanese teacher is really good and I would recommend coming here if your child really wants to learn japanese, but don't get fooled into thinking this is a sort of specialized school when it isn't. There aren't many clubs but what they have is interesting unfortunately it seems like its always the same kids in the clubs and other kids don't really participate.

"It's a nice idea to give families school options at this level, because I wasn't too thrilled with the idea of my daughter going to JHS 237," says a parent of a 7th grader. "Before selecting this school I did make a point of checking it out, basically asking about their criteria in selecting students and what programs they'd offer. My daughter wanted to go here because of the opportunity to study Japanese. She does miss art and music but she knows it's down the road and the school seems to be trying to get everything in place. Overall, I'm pleased with the school so far."

I currently attend school here. I just finished my junior year and I can honestly say that this was the best decision my mom and I made. My mother and I had a discussion before me entering the 6th grade about how I should go to a relatively smaller school because I would not be able to keep up in a big school community.  I was nervous at first because it is a huge transition from elementary to middle school. The current middle school assistant principal, Mrs. Poulos took me under her wing and made me feel very comfortable and safe in school.  In the seventh grade I had two teachers in almost every class. I can say that that was the most helpful thing towards my academic life. I had 85s and above in all my classes. As I went on to 8th, 9th and 10th grade I did not have an extra teacher in the classroom. I struggled, but it was not the teachers fault. The teachers did in fact the exact opposite and did everything in their power to help me succeed. During my junior year I had two teachers in almost every class again, which was extremely helpful because junior year is a tough year. For the first time I’ve had an average of 91 which is a huge deal for me. Our principal Dr. Werner has been at the school for only three years and has already made significant changes to better the school. Dr. Werner cares for every single student and helps out in any possible way she can.  She influenced me to join Student government my junior year and it was a way for me to express my ideas on how to improve our school as a whole or just a grade. Dr. Werner also asked me to join SLT (Student Leadership Team)  which allows teachers, administration, parents, and students to see our school as a whole and give our input and perspectives on ideas that could benefit the school and/or students. Not only Dr. Werner but also the teachers have made a positive impact on me. The teachers pushed me out of my comfort zone and made me do things I never knew I was capable of. They have the determination and ambition to see students succeed which is why I love the school so much. The teachers and staff are amazing. I know I can talk to any teacher because I feel very comfortable opening up to them and because we are a very small school, all the teachers and students know each other.  This allows students to create a connection with their teachers. It makes it feel more as a community rather than your average high school where there is a thousand kids in one grade and you don’t necessarily know everyone in your OWN grade. My friend Abigail and I put together an assembly in honor of teacher appreciation week with the help of our principal Dr. Werner. We came together and shared ideas on how we can get our message across to show that we truly appreciate the teachers. They are one of a kind teachers that you can never get anywhere else. We decided to make them personalized folders for each teacher filled with letters from their students.  I can say from the look on the teachers faces receiving the folders that this was a surprisingly amount of appreciation from the students. Teachers sometimes don’t even realize how much they can impact the student. We wanted to remind them that they are always appreciated.  The teachers is what makes WJPS definitely worth while.  As I enter my senior year I’m going to be very upset when I leave because the teachers have had such an incredible impact on my life and it is going to hurt not being able to see them on a routine basis.  The staff is always there to lend a helping hand or even just to be a listening ear. WJPS, not only to me but many many other students feels like our second home.  As the way it should be. We feel extremely safe and comfortable walking through the halls every morning. Thank you to all the teachers and staff for making my last six years the best they could ever be. The school and community is truly unforgettable. This is a family with open arms, and a family I will cherish forever.

Over the past 3 years , WJPS has offered me so many opportunities. I came into the School in ninth grade and will be entering my senior year in September. It took me a long time in 8th grade to decide where I wanted to go to high school and didn't know which school was the best fit. After months of discussing the decision with my middle school guidance counselor and parents, we decided on WJPS. Looking back , it was the best decision I've made. The small school environment and population gives students the opportunity to form close and supportive friend groups. In addition, the small school allows students to form relationships with the teachers and administration . Ask any student in the school , everyone has a teacher they can go to for advice , academic troubles , and just to talk. The teaching staff is amazing. They are supportive, always available and have a true urge to make sure every student has what they need to be successful . The administration has done a phenomenal job these past 3 years. Every administrator takes the time to know every student, to encourage student involvement , and always have an open door at all times. Anyone who tells you this school isn't academical challenging ... they are wrong. The school offers a variety of AP courses, and partners with Queens and Queensborough Community college to offer college now courses to every students. The school maintains high pass rights on regents and AP exams. Every teacher is more than qualified to teach these courses. Academics in WJPS are on par with other bigger high schools in Queens.  Students are offered a variety of extracurricular activities to take part in. This year the school has done a great job of making sure every club is running efficiently and has the resources they need to grow. If there is club you wanna start, the school willing will help students create their own clubs and will support the student until the end. If you are considering WJPS, you will not regret it. My high school experience so far has been the best and I am thankful for every staff member that has made it so great to go to school every day. I have made friends, connections and memories that I will carry with me forever. WJPS ,from students to staff to parents to administration is one big supportive family and community.

When I read the poor ratings below...  I tend to believe that it is usually because the parent fails to address the underlying issue of their child's classroom conduct. While I believe the basic tenets of learning, such as sharing and respect should be reinforced in the classroom, they should be taught first at home. My experience with WJPS  has never been less than impressive when it comes to a safe, inviting, caring and competent school environment.   My children attend WJPS, and have attended since 6th grade, my oldest is graduating 12th this year.   Yes, it is a small school, but the staff, teachers, the Sr Administration, are all deeply invested in educating well-rounded, world citizens who are prepared to enter any industry or academic discipline. From Student Government to Model UN to the twice yearly talent showcase, and everything in between, everyone has school pride!  I see the negative comments below and I must disagree.   My children’s needs were met, the work load, the AP classes offered, the tests, the social aspect, I have absolutely no complaints.  The teachers and admin staff has always addressed all my concerns, including when I feel my child needed more guidance, and help. They have also been very proactive in being strong with guiding all children who attend towards acceptance and empathy towards their fellow citizens. The Sr Admin is far from the incompetent accusation I saw posted below.  My child, who is graduating, was accepted to ALL colleges applied for with very decent academic scholarship offers.  My child's SAT score was in the 1300's without supers-coring it and I thank WJPS for setting the groundwork, and foundation, for what to expect in competitive colleges.  My youngest is doing very well also. This school encourages the students to think outside the box, ask questions and to see things differently sometimes, to help shape them.   I am a very happy and satisfied parent of a current student who is active in the school, and needs a little push here and there academically and my child gets it, the teachers, the staff, they are there and behind my child 100%.  I am also a very happy and satisfied parent of an upcoming 2019 graduate who is going onto a competitive private college career with a full scholarship..   all thanks to the ground work and teachings learned at WJPS.
https://nypost.com/2016/03/20/dean-impregnated-student-sexted-another-from-rubber-room-probe/ more facts on the school.

Do not send your child here if you truly care about their education and safety. The current administration 2018/2019 has no regard for the students. My daughter was telling me of widespread drug use and abuse by the students in the school. The senior administration is completely incompetent.
i go to this school this is a blatant lie
there is none???????

My child attended WJPS straight out of elementary school until the eighth grade.  Biggest mistake of our lives and I want all parents to really consider your choices.  We liked the cozy student population and the journalism theme.  Unfortunately, we quickly realized that with the small number of students it meant that every class was slowed significantly so that the slowest learners can keep up.  So any above average student will excel in their grades but it's based on a very low curve.  Another issue came up when my child was ready to take a regents class and the school cancelled the regents class without announcement at the beginning of the school year.  The official explanation we received was that the previous classes did not perform well and the administration decided that instead of trying to pressure students to perform it would be better to do away with the regents class offering.  Sounds to me that they could not adequately teach the students and instead of reporting lower scores for students and teachers they decided that lowering expectations was the answer.  It sounds very convenient to the teachers involved but it's a tragedy for the students.  The overall vibe we perceived was that teachers were not up to par in teaching their respective classes.  And the administration was covering up for the teachers.  I can say this because I had to personally provide supplementary study sessions and we paid for after school classes.  So if you want your child to have fun in middle school and not be bothered by academic success then please choose this school.  But if you want academic challenges then choose another school.

I will be looking to transfer my child from the middle school asap next year.
- Very low advanced regents diploma rates in the high school (the school lets seniors out a period early...shouldn't they have these students try to achieve more rather than just giving up on them?)
- Ian Millman's sexual relationship and WJPS really never formally addressed it
- No extracurricular activities for middle school students

Everything is bad.
An investigation has found that a former dean at World Journalism Prep had a sexual relationship with a student over several years, reports New York Post.

This school sucks, my mom was totally correct, she said she had a bad feeling about this crappy school. The only teacher I like is my math teacher and my science teacher, my ela teacher is ok and my social studies is boring as hell. Im sorry that if you are reading this and you feel offended or you disagree with me but this is the truth and I cannot tell a lie.
Are you a high school student or middle school student.? Would you prefer going to the high school over the middle school or not at all?
Not at all.

I hated this school with my heart. I attended WJPS from 6-8. They don't offer any enriched classes, AND this website is wrong; there are no electives for middle school students (yes, no dancing or music). The school doesn't offer nearly as much as they should, and they make strange decisions like teaching Latin to 8th graders (on Rosetta Stone instead of textbooks), and then teaching Spanish starting from the 9th grade (I heard from my friends that stayed in that disgusting school). If you're contemplating on sending your child to this school, and want them to get a good education, please do not send them. If it hadn't been for my motivation to be challenged, I would've never escaped that school. They pressure you to stay until the 12th grade, even though academically-gifted students might not want to stay in a school which don't even have staff who can challenge them and help them think for themselves. Instead, they have a ridiculous principal who acts all nice (I had an interesting experience with her when I was a 6th grader and she's just all-around rude. It was a horrible experience for an 11 year old). There's so much I could say about this school, but the main point is that this school isn't for kids who actually want a future. If you're interested in an easy school with peers that are only interested in social life and instagram and a curriculum which is equivalent to that of an elementary school's, then by all means, WJPS is the school for you.

I'm a former student at WJPS and I regret it. Even my own mother apologizes for sending me there. "We're aiming for a paperless school" was basically code for "we are too cheap to pay for anything" because WJPS is unbelievably wasteful. Oh & might I add they don't have text books for students to take home. The entire administration plays favorites and certain students are exempt from certain rules.
World Journalism Prep's newspaper tackled some big issues in the fall of 2013, including strategies to ease parking congestion in front of the school. Read more here.
The New York Times highlights World Journalism's school newspaper as an example of high school newspapers that are struggling to survive. Read more here.
Since World Journalism does not offer any music classes, some students meet every Friday at lunchtime for the school's music club, which is run by an English and journalism teacher. Read more here.
Principal Cynthia Schneider tells SchoolBook about how social media and digital technology are used in the classroom at World Journalism in an interview here.
Is the honors program in the high school rigorous? How does it work sharing the cafeteria with middle schoolers? I don't think my 9th grader would want to be eating with 7th graders.

This school is decent at best. I would suggest against going for middle  school because the electives are only for high school. The classes are taught at an extremely slow pace and most of the classes are pointless. The principal doesn't seem to know what she is doing. If you intend to go to this school to get a good education, you could learn much more at another school. If your intention is to half-ass your way through high school, come on in.

My child is currently in the 8th grade.  my child wanted to take the specialized HS exam, they had stated that since this is a chartered school they don't give out the test. Remind you that if you do attend this school know your rights as a parent and as well as a student. They will take fill advantage of you.

My child is in 6th grade and I will tell you something that they do not tell you at Open School Nights....the sixth graders do not use any Text Books!  And there is No Homework!  My child literally has 5 minutes of HW everyday other day.  This school is NOT an Academically Rigorous school.
They also do not tell you that your child has to be in a 2 to 1 class when they are in middle school. a 2 to 1 means its a slow class and they learn thing at a very slow pace.

Never did any teacher give out answers to state exams.What you are stating is a pure lie. Perhaps your child is in need of the answers. Lessons are not postponed due to a students absence. Any student who is absent required to obtain the work load they missed. The class fee is not mandatory. It was a way to pay the senior dues in increments as well as support the schools website.You are obviously a parent who certainly has no involvement in the school or you wouldn't be bashing the PTA. Do you show up to meetings? Do you volunteer to help?You say that there is no parent support from the PTA, well where is your PTA support.How dare you state that they are lazy. They are the hardest working parents I know, especially when they have to deal with people such as yourself.   This is certainly not a country club. My child works extremely hard for the grades that he/she gets.Perhaps yours needs to do the same. This place is not stupid, perhaps its just you. Good luck in the next school your child attends. It's parents like yourself that learn the hard way.

This school is a good school, but only in a sense of how little work there was. The learning enviornment is extremely relaxed. Anyone that gets to class on time and raise their hands a few times a week can easily get a good grade.

"We're trying to become a paperless school," Principal Cynthia Schneider told Insideschools. "All notices will be posted on our website and parents have an open invitation to come in and use our computers."

"This school has a great learning environment and has a lot of extra activities," writes a student. "It also provides lots of opportunities and you get to travel to many places and get to enjoy many new experiences."

In an article published in the Queens Chronicle on November 2, 2006, teacher Laura Grosselfinger comments on the school's educational approach. "'Inquiry' is a word you hear around here often," Grosselfinger said. "We encourage kids to ask questions and look at things through different perspectives."

More than 150 men attended Bell Academy's Bring Your Dad to School Day. The annual event aligns with Chancellor Fariña's charge for schools to think of creative ways to get parents involved New York 1 News reports.

Education policy researcher at The Century Foundation visited BELL Academy in search of a more equitable approach to gifted education, and found a model she thinks other city schools should examine closely. Read more here.

I'd like to say that there are 2 city bus lines from the school, not 1. It would be great if the MTA would extend the Fort Totten line to our corner but for now 2 city bus lines and yellow bus service seems to work. I have a seventh grade son there now and my older son graduated last June. We LOVE BELL Academy. It is all that you describe and more.

Ok as a student in bell this school is horrible! I mean the teachers are rude and the students have so much drama and have fights everyday!!!! A teacher throws paperwork to the students face in purpose, the teacher judges students by their race, and some teachers loses the student's homework. This Queens College School For Math, Science & Technology was one of six New York City schools that earned US Department of Education Blue Ribbon honors in 2014. Read more and see the full list of schools here.

While this at first seems to be a great honor for a school, there are specific strategies employed to make certain that "high levels of performance are achieved." At PS/IS 499, students are separated in the 7th grade along abilities in Math/Science. In 8th grade, students are separated in all subjects. Basically, there are two groups/two classes in each of these grades. So while students aren't "screened" academically upon entering the school, this method assures that only "high potential testers" are allowed to take the Common Core Algebra/Living Environment Regents. Sure, there are students slated for Stuyvesant, Bronx Science, Townsend Harris etc. but what about the overall achievement of those who are not taking the Regents, and for whom no "test prep" is given.(I am not suggesting that testing /test prep correlates with achievement.) For those of you who may feel that I am a "sore loser," nothing could be further from the truth. My child was placed in the "Regents classes," and actually got accepted to one of the specialized high schools. My concern is for the self-esteem of those who were not among the "chosen," and my strong belief is that a good school should find a way to reach/teach  all students, not be given special honors for promoting the "Stars."

The lottery is drawn by a computer program. The process is completely fair and unbiased. To answer the question of the ex-student who moved to Australia... none of the teachers have retired. We are ALL still here!!

I am offended by the remark posted by a parent previuosly about the lottery process. I have observed the lottery process and would also agree that it appears to be a fair method to select students. I have observed a few lotteries and I believe this is the most complex lottery method that I have seen. I cannot believe that students ethnicity, race, or nationality could have been the only criteria in the selection process, it is much more complicated than that. They have to select students from all over the borough of Queens and do it judicious manner. It is a good school, a small school and people find out about it through friends, neighbors and relatives etc. When my child did not get in the first time I applied, the principal encouraged me to apply again and I did. So I encourage you to apply again if you are so inclined. By the way, just what is considered an "American" last name?
You say, "I cannot  believe that students ethnicity, race, or nationality could have been the only criteria..." But it IS one criterion? Is that even legal?

But I'm proud to be a New Yorkan, and in the precious few years I had at PS 499 I excelled in my education to be one of the top students in my current school.I absolutley loved school there, and I loved the diversity of subjects and creativity the staff used to make sure we had a great time learning. P.S/I.S 499 is a great school that i have been attending for over 4 years. The teachers are exellent, and after school programs have been developed, such as sports, math, and english. Sadly our principal, Mrs. Schneider, passed away, and Mrs. Helene Jacobs is her succesor. This year, our second class graduated from IS 499, and went to the finest of the city's high schools, such as Stuyvesant, Bronx Science, etc. the 8th graders are also given the oppurtunity to have a staff vs. student softball game in the neighboring field. 6-8th graders visit the Campus for career day, where workshops are held with adults from numerous fields. The bathrooms and computers are abused by some, but otherwise, the school is in exellent condition. The school also earned over $1000 in the penny harvest. Representatives from numerous charities came to collect the checks. PS/IS 499 is a great school, and i am proud to say i go there. And your child should too.

yes you are right! I was in the 3rd graduating class back in 2010, and through out my student life from 4th grade to 8th grade, i always thought that 499 wasn't much of a good school. But in reality, it was- i just seemed to take everything for granted. Every child SHOULD be proud to go to that school, enough said!

"This is my last year at this school. The students are nice. If you do your work, you will be loved by all of your teachers. The work can be challenging at times, but teachers are always ready to help out. I have been going to this school since Kindergarten and I cannot believe I am leaving. This school is so much a part of me. It is a wonderful experience!"

"In response to the parent raising the issue of Band over Language; I am sure that as the school grows these programs will be instituted. As a former member of school bands I think it is great to see that with all of the decreases in fine arts in schools that the decision was made to have both art and music, with the future of a full-scale dance program," writes a parent. "The school has still developed an outstanding reputation and has received great notoriety for its success evidenced by your choice to keep your child in this school. I also love the interaction between the parents and teachers. I receive e-mail at work regarding my daughter's adventures during the school day and I have sent e-mail during the school day and have had all of my concerns addressed within 24 hours. I think that is excellent given that school has just started and things are still hectic. And yes, the concrete walls take getting used to, but once you leave the stairwells and enter the halls and classrooms you are overcome by a warm atmosphere that the best paint job in the city couldn't replace."

"The teachers are wonderful," said a parent, in response to the below comment. "There's nothing to complain about this school. The kids are extremely happy, and my kids are getting a great education." She added: "It's so nice to be in a brand-new school."

"When this building was designed the architecture of the school and not the practicality of the building was more important," writes a parent. "The school looks like a big gray slab of concrete with an unfinished interior. The children do not meet the physical education requirements and are often kept inside simply because the lunch aide is having a bad day. They are told to sit quietly and interaction between them is frowned upon. I am utterly disappointed in this school that my daughters waited for years to be built. Nothing is as promised at its inception and we are on our 5th or 6th principal. We are still not satisfied. We are continuously told that this is a new school and a lot of things are still being worked out. My oldest daughter has been there since 1999!! Instead of a technology teacher or language teacher our principal has opted for a band instructor."

In response to the above comment, Principal Anastasia Schneider writes: "We work closely with Queens College to plan curriculum and develop programs that will enrich the educational experience of our students. We also endeavor to integrate technology into all curriculum areas. We are fully aware of the need to provide professional development to enhance teachers' skills in that area. In this school, technology (which to many means computers) is considered a "tool" to enhance every curriculum area, and not an isolated subject to be conducted and taught outside other subjects." She adds that the school's website offers information to parents, and the school is "in the process of providing our PTA with a page there too. I am very proud of our school and all its programs which we developed in consultation with our School Leadership Team, and Queens College. Our partnership with Queens College (QC) is stronger than ever - we have a QC Interface Team comprised of QC faculty, school faculty, and 3 parent representatives. This team meets monthly. Finally, this building is an architectural beauty, and our concrete walls become the museum space to showcase students' work. "

A parent complains: "As an original parent at this school, I am extremely disappointed at the growing and blatant disrespect that the administration and region allows toward the parents. It appears that the upperclass parent are excluded and denied any access, information and consistency in interacting with the children. Although this school has proposed many wonderful ideas, they are steadily being retracted, such as the growing class size (now at 23 per class), unilateral partnership with Queens college (QC uses our children for student teaching, but our children have no accessto QC facilities or equipment), and the intentional undermining of the PTA by delaying and preempting every proposal or plan. The school has severely fallen short of the great expectations of its originators!"

The principal responds that a survey of the school's families was conducted in April 2004 "in order to address the needs of the families." According to survey results, 98% of the parents polled said they "felt welcome at the school;" 97% said their "child enjoys coming to school." An equal number said they were "satisfied with the communication between me and my child's teachers."
"We have unbelievable parent involvement," the principal said. "This is a choice school - and because of that parents get involved."
"The building is incredible," said a parent. "Kids get personal attention. Everyone knows everyone else. I don't think there's more than two to three kids I don't know. And the staff is great."

A parent writes: "Every morning my daughter is looking forward to attending Queens College School for Math, Science and Technology. She is learning a lot and she is very happy with her teachers and classmates. She is getting art, music, science, and social studies lessons in addition to math, reading, writing, and physical education. She is also performing on the auditorium stage in some of the assemblies directed by the teachers." He continues: "Since September 2004 my daughter has been enjoying a brand new building equipped with new computers in every classroom. She has been using the new school library which, hopefully soon, will have a librarian. She has also been eating breakfast and lunch in a neat and spacious cafeteria with clear glass doors which allow seeing from inside the attractive playground outside. So far, I am satisfied with my daughter's progress in this school." He adds: " PS/IS 499 has an official website and most of the teachers have e-mail addresses, which makes it very easy for me to communicate with them. According to the principal's newsletter, applications for 2005-2006 will be available early February 2005."

A parent writes in to say that Principal Saccente was not removed for poor performance. This parent writes, "PS 499 has done remarkably well under the stewardship of Mr. Saccente, the presiding Interim Acting Principal who left in March 2004 as a result of the C-30 principal selection process. His departure was not due to the desires of the majority of parents at school, but was the result of a decision brought on by Region 3. It is evident that the school thrived under his leadership as test scores from the 3rd and 4th grades are relatively high for the city (most children scored at level 3 and 4). We wish Mr. Saccente well and know that the DOE press release will be corrected."

According to a June 28, 2004 press release from the NYC Department of Education, Principal Joseph Saccente is one of 45 public school principals "being removed from their positions for poor performance this year." The press release states that "All of the principals had received or were in danger of receiving unsatisfactory ratings in their performance evaluations." Mr. Saccente will return to a position he previously held within the department, according to the DOE.

Some of the teachers in the school are very committed and dedicated .The teachers do stress on academics and encourage the kids.

SPRING 2011 UPDATE/CORRECTION: P.S. 18 DOES and WILL continue to host a very enriched district-wide gifted program!
class of 1999 here PS 18 is the foundation of knowledge
A parent who moved into the community from Elmont on Long Island says the "education is better here. Even the teaching is better."

"We've always been an impressive school," says a parent active in the PTA whose three children have attended PS 18. "I think it has the most outstanding staff, and not just the teachers, the custodial staff as well." Parents and staff "work as a team," she says.
"We do teach grammar and punctuation and phonics. Those are the structure for communication," says Principal Kathleen Peknic.

A longtime parent in the school says that the feeling of separation between the gifted program and the rest of the school has evaporated. "The goal is the same goal," she says. "The kids feel safe. The teachers are getting support from parents. There's not a feeling of school being a babysitter anymore."

The school has undergone a number of changes in recent years, says Parent Coordinator Kathleen Lee, formerly a parent at the school. "The face of the PTA was a certain look and very traditional" in the past, she notes. "Now there are many more parents of color...and volunteers with limited English." She says the school provides a "safe and comfortable atmosphere for parents." Two teachers speak Spanish and one speaks Chinese, according to Lee.

"I graduated from PS 18 in 1993 and I feel that it provided me with a strong education and more importantly with amazing values and morals," writes a former student. "It was my gateway to my current position as an honor student at a prestigious university. It was a wonderful thing to be greeted by my principal every morning and to have teachers go out of their way to help. I returned to PS 18 as a visitor last year and I was amazed with the warm welcomes that I received from some of my former teachers. To see them sitting in their classrooms teaching their students reinforced my decision to become an elementary school teacher. I would not be where I am today had it not been for PS 18 and its staff."

A parent of a child in the magnet program writes, "there is resentment about the program which non-magnet parents voice again and again at PTA meetings and so forth, even calling for the removal of the program altogether." She writes, "logistically, it is fairly obvious why magnet kids don't as a rule befriend kids from the neighborhood: most magnet kids live miles away from the school. Many go to afterschool programs or are bussed home after classes, out of the neighborhood. The class is a self-contained unit, and the same children progress from grades one through five together. As fourth grade classes overall are larger, the magnet class gets bigger as more kids are allowed to test into the program. This year, in fact, three children from PS 18 tested into the fourth grade magnet class. The magnet class does not receive "extras". There is one teacher, one classroom, and the same subsidies per child as other classes get. The magnet program is an enrichment program, which basically means that the material covered is more advanced than your average class in the same grade level."

"The principal walks around with a contagious smile for the students and parents too," writes a parent "She is visible, available, and accessible to all. Most of all, she is very even-tempered and provides a supportive presence to all. She has a daunting task in terms of trying to educate 500 students in the midst of chronic budget cutting in New York City but Ms. Hammer is smart enough and knows how to make lemonade out of lemons. She knows how to multiply her limited resources to obtain more services for her students. She is a hard-working person who has earned the respect of parents, staff, and students.

This school is a joke. Why are you teaching such jargon to 1st and 2nd graders? Get the basics down before teaching them SAT words. What is a 1st grade going to do by knowing the word ingenuity or ubiquitous? This school is made for over achievers, not the average 1st grade student.

Some of the local Ys and community centers in Queens are serviced by private carriers which pick up at elementary schools and take the kids to the Ys for afterschool care.  Try calling your nearest Ys and community centers, and ask them which carriers provide service.  However, it seems that your child's elementary school also offers afterschool classes, for a fee.  So it may be easier (and cheaper) to enroll your son in these classes, and then pick him up from these, rather than trying to arrange for transportation when school lets out.  Good luck!
i went to this school and its the best school there can ever be standing i love the teachers there and i love ms graybow

"I joined the PS 31 team this year as a first year teacher and I could not have asked for a warmer, more supportive environment. The principal is exceptional. She is approachable, communicative, and addresses the concerns of every teacher, parent, and student in the school. Regarding the over-crowded class sizes in the upper grades, I was added as an additional 5th grade teacher and a new 4th grade teacher was added as well. The principal fought hard battles to get these positions created. Now the class sizes in these grades range from 26-29. As far as I can see, there is nothing that needs changing at PS 31."

Former student, Brian Lee writes: "This was a great school. I was lucky enough to attend 5th grade in the former planetarium/library. The only downsides were that you could only sit with your class at lunch, and we had limited time and equipment outdoors. However, my experience was very colorful, and I learned many beneficial things that I heard again in the 6th grade."

A parent writes: "PS 31 is a very good school. Parent Workshosp are done often by the school to help us gain information on what to expect and how to help our kids on testings like city or state wide test." She believes that the school has a "whole rounded curriculum" because they have "excellent academic programs" as well as good extracurricular activities, "especially the winter and spring concerts." She adds: "Downside [is that] the 4th and 5th grade classes is overcrowded. Classroom size is too tight for 35 kids and over."

"There's a lot of heart and caring in this school," said a teacher. "I wish that this building were not so old, but it is one of the best-maintained buildings around. We have an excellent custodian. It was constructed the way schools were at the beginning of the century: the size and shape of the rooms."

"Teachers are very fortunate to be here," said a teacher. "We have a nice group of children, not many behavior problems. We had a rough kindergarten last year, but it's good this year. It's an interesting, financially diverse neighborhood." At the same time, "the community functions nicely within the school," the teacher said.

"I have been fortunate to be a part of the PS31 family for 11 years and I consider it a privilege to be a part of such a wonderful school," writes the school's parent coordinator. "I was very surprised to see the unflattering comments about the school being dark. I find it to be totally opposite. The hallways are a beige color with a multitude of colorful paintings of the children's favorite book characters painted directly on the walls on every floor - the Hungry Caterpillar, Marvin Redpost, Amelia Bedelia, Harry Potter, and the list goes on. In addition, the teachers are constantly updating their bulletin boards with the children's work to add to the bright and welcoming atmosphere."

A student whose sister attends the school writes, "She comes home with something new she learned every day. She never gives me any serious complaints about this school at all. All the teachers are caring and respect each student. They don't just teach them they care for them!"
As the start of the school day shifts 40 minutes earlier, a PS 41 family scrambles to get kids to school. Read more here.

if the principal is the same teacher I had in 46 then i'm happy she's now a principal

PS 41Q is a fantastic school. The principal, Sari Latto, and AP, Joseph Ferrara are completely committed to making the school one of the city's best. The teachers and staff are all very dedicated and have a lot of integrity. The school offers many programs to enrich the curriculum. The Parent Coordinator, Mary Bow, is a ray of sunshine who keeps parents connected and school spirit high. The PTA does so much and organizes a lot of evening events so working parents can be involved. It is a wonderful school for children of all abilities.

The U.S. Department of Education designated PS 41 as one of three 2007 No Child Left Behind Blue Ribbon Schools in New York City. To receive Blue Ribbon status, schools must either be "academically superior in their states" or "demonstrate dramatic gains in student achievement."

According to the city Quality Review Report, "Teachers use data very well and are continually striving to present lively, interesting lessons where students are actively involved in assessing their own learning so they can have high expectations of themselves."

"The portable classrooms in the playground should not be interpreted as overcrowding," writes a parent. "The teachers and students in the portables love them because everything is new and the climate is completely controlled. The extra classrooms gave the school the ability to reduce class sizes. My child's average class size is 16 since the portables were installed."

The Alley Pond School will not lose its popular ballroom dancing classes, thanks to a grant from the school's PTA, reports the Queens Courier. The grant ensures graduating fifth graders will get 20 bi-weekly classes in everything from the tango to the foxtrot.

"Coming to PS 46 this year has been the best move that I ever made," writes a parent. Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. J.H.S. 67 Louis Pasteur was chosen to host P.S. 30 Mary White Ovington and William Carr. Read more here.

As an alumni at MS67, I loved this school, because this school has given
 the challenges and opportunities to foreshadow what it's like to 
experience the high school years. Even though I wasn't in the magnet 
program, I was given classes that weren't difficult, but were a bit of a
 challenge. The teachers here, in general, are amazing! Depending on the
 teacher you get, you will either have a good year or have a frustrating
 year to work and study independently. MS 67 is a great school and 
offers "electives" that I think is one of the best factors about MS 67. 
The band is an amazing orchestra! The teacher, however, has retired. He 
was the best conductor and music teacher I ever had, so far! The new 
teacher, Mr. Peterson, is really nice and outstanding. The problem I had
 with MS 67 was the teachers were constantly changing every year! I 
mean, every year, from 7th grade to 8th grade, I saw new teachers that I
 never knew! Lol... that's not a big deal, but I think MS 67 should try 
and limit that habit. Other than that, MS 67 is a great school to be in.
 Guidance is amazing and the teachers here are wonderful! Come here and I
 will promise you 80-100% that your child or you (as a student) will 
attend/get accepted into NYC's best high schools. The education I 
received has helped me pass the SHSAT to get into Brooklyn Tech (not 
Bronx Science; I was just 2 points off!!!!) and Francis Lewis's 
University Scholars! Many other students show exemplary performance and 
high school acceptances. There may be some kids attending the zoned 
Cardozo, Bayside, Francis Lewis, or Martin Van Buren, but that doesn't 
make MS 67 bad. In general, MS 67 is an amazing school and personally 
recommend it to parents and students interested in coming here! Just a 
side note, if you become an 8th grader, MS 67 gives you the chance to 
skip the 8th grade Regents Core, which is Earth Science. The school provides an aptitude test, to show which Science Regents class you may have potential to take and do better in. I got the opportunity to take Living Environment and received good education on it. I took the regents and got a great score; a 96! It's not how the teachers teach that determines one's score; it's the student's effort to do well.  So, MS 67 is a recommended school to go to!

My child is in the eighth grade currently at this school.  Academically - challenging and demanding.  Can't tell whether it's more so than other schools in the area given that the demands on the students have increased city-wide.  A lot of motivated and diligent students in the school, along with parents who seem to care about their children's academic and social development.  Parent-teacher conference is too chaotic and short- due to the number of parents the teachers have to meet.  The biggest adjustment I had to make as a parent - no more coddling by the teachers and staff (my child had attended a small elementary school where everyone knew each other), and the huge load of school work/assignments/tests.  The presence of other motivated and diligent students and the high expectation/standard set by the teaching staff - a plus. Also, my child enjoyed the big student body (despite my fear of the "bigness" of the school) - more personalities and friends to choose from.
If you are not going to a specialized high school, the counselors dump you into Cardozo. Except for 158, this is the worst run school in D26

Not true. I think you're getting confused here, but a lot of the kids here were zoned for Cardozo, yes, but you can't make the assumption that the kids who don't get into specialized schools go to Cardozo immediately. That's not the guidance counselor's choice; it's the student's choice of attending Cardozo. Plus, you have no right to say that. Unless you have valid evidence of what you're saying, please don't ever say that, because I'm sure you say things mindlessly. I'm sure you haven't been in this school before, I have been (Alumni Class of 2014). MS 67 is academically one of the best middle schools, so what you're saying is completely false. MS 158 is not a bad school either! I got a 511 on the SHSAT (getting into Brooklyn Tech) and Francis Lewis High School's University Scholars. I decided to attend Francis Lewis. Ok? There are many kids who do well and get into one of NYC's best high schools. My friend didn't get into a specialized high school, so does that necessarily mean that he's going to Cardozo? No! His zoned was Bayside and wound up getting into Cardozo's DaVinci. So, with my evidence, it's obvious that what you said was completely wrong. It's just that a lot of the kids do want to go to Cardozo, but they're not forced to. The counselors have no right to choose where every students go for high school. Do you think my counselor choose Francis Lewis for me? NO! I did, not him. Also, you may mean that the guidance counselor suggests Cardozo, not dump you. So, I suggest you to keep your filthy, dirty gossips to yourself. If you think it's necessary to say (with all the right evidence and stuff), go ahead. Otherwise, just keep it to yourself.

You don't have to wear a uniform if you don't want to.  BUT YOU MUST fill out the UNIFORM EXEMPTION REQUEST form and return it to school. The form is part of the Chancellor's Regulation A-665 that describes the voluntary uniform dress policy guidelines.  Students cannot be 1) sent home, 2) given a lower grade, 3) or excluded from extracurricular activity, for not complying to uniform policy. Be informed, know your rights.

MS67 shouldn't have combined regular classes and SP classes. The part about everyone taking Earth Science in 8th grade is a lie. There was a computer class, but the only reason they stopped it was because the teacher retired. I'm not sure if it's still going though. I graduated last year, 2011, and now i heard from my little sister that the school's insane rules got even more restrictive. MS 67 is still a good school, but they're kind of blind. To be honest, the MS67 you know and the MS67 I know are completely different. First off, yes, not everyone takes Earth Science in eighth grade. Only the Gifted and Talented course takes them, and there's no 'placement exam', we're just separated from the Gifted and Talented course and the regular course. Second, there aren't any 'insane' rules. It's a very free environment, and almost nobody I know got in serious trouble, and I know these people don't follow rules daily. I know I don't. Third, nobody smokes at MS67. Nobody. The teachers do something about it if they see someone juuling or smoking. I know this is from seven years ago, but I think it's better to delete this review and let the new students see the recent comments instead.

A student complains that "some teachers are inexperienced at controlling the students and motivating them to learn."

"The faculty is patient and does provide adequate guidance," writes a parent. "The teachers are sincere and enthusiastic with their teaching methods. This enthusiasm and creativity is evident." This parent notes that although the school is overcrowded, "there are programs available to assist students who require a smaller setting, and the building is clean and very well maintained."

"I enjoyed my three years at M.S. 74," writes Timi, a recent graduate. "Despite the overcrowding, all the great teachers contributed to make my time there great. Now that I am in high school, I am positive that they also have prepared me well."

"I think this is a great school with many well-picked staff members," writes a student, who adds that he particularly likes his social studies teacher because the teacher makes the class fun. "Even though some teachers may seem strict at first, you'll find they're very friendly as the school year progresses."
Olivia, a student, writes: "This school is the best ever. I couldn't imagine my self anywhere else. The teachers are the best, and I can look at some of them as friends also. I love being here."
A student writes: "I think this school is the best school there is." He praises his teacher Mr. Perlstein in particular.

A student, writes "This school is so cool! Sure, some teachers are strict but they just want to prepare you for the real world. They want you to be smart, be a good student and accomplish something in the real world." She adds, "You have a lot of opportunities in this school!"

A former student writes, "I just graduated this year and will be headed to Townsend Harris High School. These three years at 74 were some of the best years of my life. All the teachers and the administration are so welcoming and friendly, the students all get along ... and the academic life is very good." She adds, "I was never up late late at night doing homework. The school prepares you very well for high school."

A parent praises the school's "outstanding teachers," especially her son's special education teacher, but complains that "teachers assign at least an hour and often as much as two hours of homework a night" and that the extended day program "results in partial social ostracism" for the students who are required to attend it. This parent also writes that because the gym is used as the cafeteria, whenever there is bad weather, "instead of outdoor or indoor physical activity, students are required to sit in the school auditorium and watch a video."

The US Department of Education designated PS 115 a 2017 "Blue Ribbon" school for having test scores in the top 15 percent in the state, with students in all demographic groups scoring higher than at least 60 percent of students in their state, according to a US Department of Education press release.

Who ever said mean things about this school, you are very very wrong. This school, I came into in second grade. This school gave me experiences I’ll never be able to forget. The teachers and faculty are so sweet, that you will remember each one of them wherever you go in life. You’ll be so thankful. This school is a blue ribbon school, which means it definitely is a highly great school for academics. And not just academics, even friends. The faculty are so sweet that I had a friend who was a lunch lady and all the teachers I had were my friends as well. I loved that school, it’s not an opinion anymore since it’s New York State’s 6 blue ribbon schools. You’ll love the teachers you meet. They were all caring and fun. They would always come up with fun activities to do for boring topics. They have multicultural day, a day when you can express your culture through food, dressing, music, and dance. And in fifth grade, you will love it the most. The kind faculty in this school have inspired me to become a teacher in the future. I looked up to them and I still do although I graduated a few years ago. You will never ever ever regret the experiences you have and learn from this school. You will always cherish these memories. Fourth grade for me was pretty sad, we lost a beloved principal named principal James J. Ambrose. That’s how ps. 115q became the James J. Ambrose school. He left great remarks on this school. He deserves most credit for making this school so great and Mrs. Scortino who was our assistant principal at the time. She loved history so much. So I can tell you all the teachers were super nice... I don’t know about how kids these days are but I can reassure you the faculty is one in a million. You will never find such a faculty in any school. I’m in high school now, and it isn’t so great. And they also have this great after-school program where you can do homework with volunteers helping you and more fun activities. This school deserves the blue ribbon award for everything they have done from teaching lessons to teaching great values in life. Go bulldogs!!!

At first, reading all the reports and comments, I was very VERY reluctant to put my kids into this school... I considered myself lucky when I got my son into PS 203 in PK and he's been there for the last 3 years - happy and in advanced classes. I tried to get my daughter in, but no luck. wait-listed for the 2nd year in a row.
However, circumstances change, and I was left with no choice and finally went to register my daughter for Kindergarten class for year 2016-2017.
I was greeted by a security guard as I would by any school guard, it's appropriate and acceptable. Proceeded to the office and was greeted with smiles and very nice and approachable staff who was very helpful, and again - nice. Didn't give me any issues, even though I was a week late with pre-registration, thinking I'd get a call from the other school. My daughter was approached by a Language specialist(I think), just so she can assess her skills, in a very nice sweet manner, asked her a few questions, which my daughter (who is normally extremely shy) answered all questions very comfortably. I met with the Parent Coordinator and spoke to him about my son who just scored high on G&T test and because they may have a spot for him, it would just work out for me to transfer him out of PS203 to this school, so my kids would go to the same school. So, we'll see how it works out.
So far, my experience with the school was great. I will be happy to update you all when and if we get them in and see how things go.

My son went to PS 191 for a couple of years before transferring to PS 115 for the after school program. There is a major difference between these two schools.  PS 191 was welcoming and the staff were always there to help. At 115 the security guard rolls her eyes and sucks her teeth at the parents. The parent coordinator, while he responds to inquiries, is gruff and unfriendly.
