"I graduated from 158 in 2007, and I was very sad to leave," writes a student. "The amazing teachers, staff, and students made my time at this school very memorable. The school atmosphere is very comfortable."

Principal Marie Nappi tells Insideschools that the day before our visit MS 158 received an unexpected one-day visit from police who set up metal detectors as part of a city-wide initiative to randomly select middle and high schools for a day or two of scanning. "It went well," says Nappi. "Some students were frightened when they saw all the uniforms, but for the most part they were inquisitive. About 100 or so cell phones were confiscated, but no weapons."

A graduating student writes that despite her SP classes, she does not feel "adequately prepared" to enter her competitive high school in the fall. "Some teachers are horrible, especially in crucial subjects like math and science. Others are merely mediocre. Sometimes very little homework is assigned but a Regents test is still expected to be passed."

"I love 158! The teachers take the time to explain things properly to students having a difficulty in an area. The deans are very efficient," writes Priya, a student, who also complains about lax security at the school.
"I think this school is great, especially Magnet. The general subjects are a lot of fun and most of the teachers are really nice," writes a student.
"The gifted magnet program did not only accept students from P.S.188, but was open to students who were recommended by other elementary school teachers," writes 2005 graduate, Jonathan.

"I'm not to thrilled about coming to this school how can they cut the 8th grade P.E? I think that's bad because P.E gives people exercise and makes the students think harder and have a bigger attention span for class," writes a student. "My 7th grade middle school had overcrowding too, but cutting P.E for the 8th graders is no exception- We need P.E."
The principal mentioned often, Charles DeMeo, has retired as of June 30, 2005. We have an Interim Acting Principal, Marie Nappi," writes Margaret Porter, a parent at the school.

"I think this school is good," writes student Jennifer. "The kids are very aggressive, but it's worth it. You can meet a lot of people that will be close to you. The teachers are nice, especially my English teacher Ms. Rey. All the students who are going to attend middle school should come here. One tip kids, don't bring heavy bags-people make fun of you."

A 6th-grader who has attended the school for almost a year writes: "I think the school is pretty okay ... . It has great programs like computer, art, and dance. The teachers are nice." She adds: "One thing I don't like is that it's impossible to get through the halls, especially the middle staircase."

Sherrika, a student in her last year at the school, writes: "MS 158 is one of the best schools. I been there ever since 6th grade and I had a lot of fun through out the years. I think if they were to have a better yard the kids would have more fun at lunch. Beside that everything is good." She adds: "Most teachers take there time and help you with anything you need, so does the Dean and Mr. Demeo."

Christen, a student, writes: "The school is alright. Sixth grade and 8th grade [were] the best grades for me. All my friends that stayed for 9th grade regret it." She adds: "The principal is very nice and cares about the students."

A student writes: "This school is pretty great, but there are a few not-so-nice people there. However, he adds: "The school itself is very nice, if you don't mind the long lunch line, crowded halls, and occasional bully. The school taught me a lot even though I haven't been there long (I'm still in 6th grade), and it is very wonderful, with its music program and all."

A parent writes: "Marie Curie is a wonderful middle school. Mr. Charles DeMeo is a very caring principal. He knows just about every child in the school by their first name, which is not easy when you have 1250 students. The teachers and staff are very supportive. The school has many school clubs and academic support classes free of charge for their students. My child has had a wonderful experience in this school. I feel this school has helped her grow into a responsible young lady." She adds: "The hallways are beautifully decorated with the children's work as well as art work. Each year the school has a magnificent winter and spring concert. Alot of talent comes out of this school. Not to mention a talented dance teacher who always puts on a great dance show each year. We have two very popular community based after school programs, Beacon and TASC, with a great staff."
Lenny, a 2002 graduate, describes MS 158 as "one of the worst schools I've ever attended," and says that while he was there, it suffered from lax security and overcrowding.
An enthusiastic student writes, "They will always know what they are doing and if there is a problem, they would always try to fix it!"

A student writes, "This school is great and the teachers really do their job. The problem is that our school doesn't give us gym for the 8th and 9th grade. Instead we have a class of health." This student believes all students should get gym because "we deserve some fun."

"I am only in 6th grade and I already love this school!" writes a student. "All the teachers support me and I feel really comfortable in M.S.158. I hope I could stay in this school until 8th grade!"

This review is VERY old. Margaret Allyn has not been PTA president there in about 10 years if not more.  There are a little more than 700 currently in the school.  Until June of 2011, there were few works of art to be seen in the school other than in the main hall and some classrooms.  The new principal (who was the AP) has an artsy flair and will hopefully bring more art into the classrooms as there is no art instruction at all in the school this year. In the past the PTA paid for the Studio art program but they are unable to do so this year. That alone is a poor reflection on both the principal and the PTA. Pay $13,000 for the whole school to have art for 6 weeks or pay $8,500 for the 5th grade to learn ballroom dancing?  They chose one grade to benefit because there is a competition involved. Better to disappoint the masses rather than give up a chance at winning a medal.  The PTA is slightly frigid and some members tend to look down on parents. They spend more $$ to fund raise than they make because they don't want to get their hands dirty. Meetings are a joke. Parents haven't had a say on school lunch or uniforms in years. Even the voting on the principal last may was limited to the PTA board members ONLY. Ms. Saunders herself claimed no one on the list could be reached. It's a school with a veil. Everything looks okay until you lift the veil, when you do, you probably won't like what you see. Don't bother complaining to the district family advocate, she can't think for herself and goes along with anything she's told by the schools administration.  Don't waste your child's education on a school that "might one day be..."

"This is one of the lowest performing schools in district 26. While the scores look good compared to the rest of the city, comparison to other District 26 schools show it at the bottom with hardly any students earning 4s on state tests. This is in comparison to other district 26 schools, some of which have up to 50% of the kids at the 4 level.These other schools offer tracking and enrichment to those advanced kids. The principal here has been bringing in as many No children left behind kids as she can so that now the classes are so overcrowded that some classes have to put their coats in their knapsacks, no place to hang them up safely. This schools was overcrowded with just the zoned kids. Today my child brought home a notice saying that the school was getting title 1 funding for more remedial education. What about the kids who already are on the 3 level? They deserve to be educated too. Principals should be required to educate all children to their full potential."

"My son's 3rd grade teacher is NOT going to teach him division this year. I am so angry. It is obviously going to be on the state test but she is not going to teach how to do it. This school is horrible. I am currently a student in this school. In this review, I will speak of the bad and the good. I was reading this, and this would have been fantastic if I was in school back when this was written. Back in 2008, when I was a 6th grader, there was no Exploratory Language Course. We aren't allowed to play during lunchtime in the adjacent playground. I know people who are smart and willing to learn; but are taught by teachers that do not know how to teach and help others, by instead blaming the student, and not attempting to help the person learn. Oh that reminds me, there is a BIG gap between students. Some, not all, some students in the Scholars Program put in good effort, time, and grades into their schoolwork. The conduct for the General-Ed on the other hand is not as good. They scream and yell a lot. BUT, it has gotten much better than before. No more people smoke, or do drugs or all that crazy stuff. We got nice, normal, but annoying kids with no effort to learn. Some people don't care at all; but some actually do.  There is a Student Government program, and I had a friend in the Student Government. My friend showed the council his ideas and had explanations on how they could achieve it; but he was given excuses in return, "We don't have time....we cant do it now in the beginning of the year...etc."  But, there are good things. They have a PTA association which is very active in the school.They have fundraisers and bake sales in order to get money to use for their school, as well as two school stores; one for money and one for kiosk machines. Some administrators (Ms. Kaplan, for example) work hard in order to keep the school in shape, visiting at lunch sometimes to calm the chaos that may erupt, and going to classrooms during the day. The teachers in the school are not all good, but many are pretty good at teaching. Some are strict but help you learn, while others are more calm and relaxed. The building itself is not in the best condition, but they try in maintaining its shape, with janitors cleaning outside, in the hallways, and everywhere you can think of. This may not be the 100% school. This may not be the place for those prep-students that want to go to Harvard, but it might be a good place for those students in the Scholars Program. Overall, its not a bad school, but they got holes to patch up.
The school is much better now. You can play outside and stuff.

A parent writes that her son complains that many of the school's teachers use "boring," outdated teaching techniques. "The teachers should make classes more interactive using this century's technology to their advantage, and teachers should have their own websites so that the parents know what their children are doing," this parent writes, adding that her son's Spanish teacher is not fluent in Spanish and that the school could benefit from "more tutors and counselors with a heart." Principal Jeffrey Slivko responds: "We are in the midst of a massive fundraiser dedicated to raising $100,000 towards replacing the obsolete computer equipment we recently discarded. We are also awaiting monies for computers and just (last week) received additional city monies which are being used to enhance our sagging technology infrastructure. This year, we have already placed eight Smartboards (which are shared) in classrooms and have trained teachers in their use. Many teachers do have websites, but all teachers do not. We continue to work with teachers to give them the technology skills to better assist students.

"We have an extensive academic intervention program after school; many of our teachers also work with students before school and at lunch -- they are always available to assist students that need extra help. We regularly have two guidance counselors for 1100 students -- again a budgetary constraint. We are fortunate, this term, to have a third counselor and a one morning/week counselor as well. All of our counselors excellently assist students that are mandated for counseling, are recommended for counseling or request to work with a counselor."

Slivko emphasizes that all Spanish teachers are fluent in Spanish: "Four of our Spanish teachers are certified in that subject and are highly qualified. A fifth teacher is a certified special education teacher and teaches one section of Spanish to a special education class; Spanish is her native tongue."
"My teachers were cool and let all the kids feel comfortable in class," writes student Fernando Candia. "If I had the chance to change the school, I wouldn't."

A student writes: "Some of the teachers don't know what they are teaching, but otherwise it is okay. There is not really anything special about it. Mostly everyone is nice." She praises her teachers Miss Romano and Miss Pancheri.

A student writes: "The school isn't that good. There is a very poor work environment." This student writes that teachers are caring, but that teaching could be stronger.

Nadia, a recent graduate, writes: "I love my new school, but I really miss 172. I had alot of fun and loved my teachers. I couldn't wait to leave the school when i was in 8th grade, I was ready to face high school and its challenges, but now that I look back on my experiances at 172 I'd do anything to relive it." She adds: "Our class of 2004 was really close and most of us still keep in touch outside of school."
A student writes: "My school is the best. Learning has never been easy for me."

Kathy, a 2004 graduate, writes: "My stay in 172 went well" but complains that her Spanish teacher wasn't expert at the language. She also describes an incident in which she got into a fight with another girl and the security guard didn't intervene.

A student writes: "I am currently in 8th grade at the school, and I love it. Most of the teachers are very caring and want you to succeed. This year, Mr. Slivko is our new principal. So far, he has done a good job." This student adds: "During my 3 years here, I spent most of lunch periods in the library. Our librarian, Ms. Borger, is the best. She is very kind and creative. She plans special readings for each holiday." However, the student complains: "I do not like the afterschool program this year. The afterschool staff is mainly made up of teens, who do not have a lot of experience."
Max, a student, writes: "I think the school is really fun, the teachers are really into having the students learn."
A student writes: "I like this school a lot, especially Mr. Herrera and Mr. Martinez and Mrs. Tomasik. ... I used to hate math and Spanish and they changed that for me."

Alyssa, a former student, writes: "I attended 172 in 6th and 7th grade. I left in 8th grade to attend PS/IS 266. I enjoyed my stay at 172. I especially enjoyed having Mr. Martinez and Mrs. Suave as teachers."
Kristofer, a student, writes: "This school is very cool. All the teachers are very nice and some are very very funny. I think every kid would like this school."
Oyuki C., a student who graduated last year, writes, "teachers were so nice and funny. It is really one of the best schools in District 26."
Ramanjot, an alum, writes that although MS 172 is "very competitive" it is "the best place to learn," and that the "supportive teachers" help kids deal with the school's challenges.

A student who did not attend the school, but had many friends there says students benefit from "a good social environment," respectful teachers and a caring principal. "Great school," the student writes. "Would love/have loved to go there. "
Website QNS reports that PS 173 has been named a Reward School by New York State.

Chancellor Walcott released a congratulatory statement for the New York City schools that were named “BLUE RIBBON SCHOOLS” by the US Department of Education: “Today, Secretary of Education Arne Duncan named P.S. 172 Beacon School of Excellence in Brooklyn, P.S. 48 William G. Wilcox in Staten Island, P.S. 130, P.S. 159 and P.S. 173 Fresh Meadows, all in Queens, as 2011 Blue Ribbon Schools because of their students’ academic achievements last year. I want to congratulate the students, teachers, principals and parents at these five schools for all of their hard work and dedication in ensuring their students are making strong academic progress and are on track to graduate college or career ready.”

Valinda, a former student, writes: "This is school is great. You learn a lot without so much pressure and you can't ever forget it because the way you learn the skills is just so unbelievable and unpredictable and out of the ordinary."

A 2002 graduate describes the school as "amazing." He writes: "The teachers were all friendly and helpful, it is a beautiful campus, and it's very close to Ryan Junior High. ... I am now a senior at Nathaniel Hawthorne MS 74 and this elementary school really helped build my education."
Long Island City parents rally for the creation of a new local school to ease long waitlists at PS 178. Read more here.
The Reebok foundation is bringing its physical activity program, BOKS to P.S. 178 as part of an expansion of physical activity options for elementary school children. Read more here.

This is a great atmosphere for elementary and middle school students. Small classes allow teachers to individually help students. The projectors, Smartboards and computers in the rooms are state of the art. 

Because this school is so great, I am able to take 9th and 10th grade courses, while still in middle school. I am taking a biology regents in June. Biology is a 10th grade class. I am also taking Algebra which is 9th grade. Because of this, I can take accelorated classes in my high-school.

My teachers are insanely nice, and caring. They will go out of their way to help you. One teacher saw a girl crying in the hallway, and spent her entire lunch period calming the girl down and helping her, as well as calling the guidance counsler. The teacher didn't have lunch that day, because she cared so much about her student. That is dedication. My other teachers always make themselves available if you had trouble in class or with homework. You can visit a teacher before school, during lunch, free period, or after school. Teachers share much of their personal lives with students, making the bond greater. Sometimes I feel like I have personal tutors for each of my subjects, because my teachers are so close. They also have great senses of humor, and make class enjoyable.

The school recently built a new playground outdoors, which students in all grades enjoy. Tennis courts and a baseball daimond will be added to the school yard. At the moment we have basketball hoops and handball courts, as well as two large playgrounds and jungle gyms, so you are never bored during recess. Some students read in the shade during lunch, or create study groups and do homwork together. The small classes allow students to know everybody in their class. (There are only about 60 students per grade.) In addition, everyone is racially, culturally and religously diverse. Students are very open about these things, and proudly talk about their culture as others eagerly listen.

Sports teams usually practice once or twice a week, but you can be excluded for practice with a note from a parent. The teams have won numerous trophies which are displayed in the school. 

Academic teams also compete, and have brought home trophies, plaques and medals. The hallway outside of the main office is scattered with numerous awards that the school and students have won. Teachers encourage academic contests, and students have won cash prizes and other things because of their tremendous writing and drawing skills.

Students who wish to take extracurriculars will have no problem finding a program that suits them. Many students take part in multiple programs. Debate Team, Peer Mediation, Newspaper Club, Band, Recycling Club, Math Team, Vollunteering Club, NJHS, as well as mandatory art classes, computer classes and performing arts and theatre classes will keep anyone engaged. There are plenty of other extracurriculers, but frankly I can't think of them now.

Bullying is NOT an issue at this school. Weekly advisory meetings with the guidance counsler let students do fun activities in small groups that promote following virtues, building character, and stopping cyberbullying as well as regular taunting and teasing. The guidance counslers are extremely helpful. During the ever-stressful time of high-school applications, the guidance counsler made herself fully available to answer all questions, as well as reccomend schools that would interest students based on their academic and other interests.

The building itself was newly renovated, and is in great shape. It has 2 girls bathrooms and 2 boys bathrooms, which is more than enough room for the small student population. The cafeteria is spacious, and often times is only half-filled with students. It has a large, flat-screened TV hanging on the wall which is used for announcements as well as for advertising when students are running for student government.

The library is amazing. It is stocked with a variety of books to suit the needs of all ages. Simple books are kept for younger grades, but other more intellectual books are kept for the middle school. All classrooms have their own library, but the library I am talking about is used for all classes. Middle schoolers used library class as a study hall period. The library has 5 computers for students to use whenever they wish, which are always available. The library also has 2 printers, (one color, one black and white) and a scanner for documents and photos. The carpet in the corner has beanbags and cushions so that you can cuddle up while reading. Some of my favorite selections fromt the library are Harry Potter, The Hunger Games, Romeo and Juliet, Nancy Drew, and a biography on Charles Shultz. The library also contains 2 or 3 full sets of encyclopedias, as well as dictionaries, thesauruses, and translators. All students can take out books whenever they wish, and then return them after about a week or so. Books can be renewed as many times as you want.

The technology lab has a full new set of 30 computers. They hold the newest versions of software such as Microsoft Word, Excell, Powerpoint and Onenote, as well as Macromedia Flash, Fireworks and Dreamweaver.  

The art room is filled with paints, brushes, pastels, shading pencils, newspaper, string, and all sorts of craft items. The walls are lined with student work, and is extremely colorful. The art room also has a set of Mac Laptops which can be used for digital artwork, or for downloading photos that were taken with a digital camera for projects.

Overall, P.S. /I.S. 178 The Holliswood School is the best elementary and middle school I have ever seen. It seems to tower over all of the other schools in the area. I will never regret going to this school, and I strongly suggest this school to anybody.

What can I say about P.S./I.S 178? Well I can say a lot. Even though I have only been in this school since 6th grade. And I am in the graduating class this year going on to high school. Doesn't mean I won't miss this school. I have a lot of great memories and I will always remember the fun times. If you like that teacher knows your name and help you out in anything you need. I know sometimes they can forget somebodies name(like mine) they are great teachers and staff. If you like to play sports or like to be in teams. This is a great school to be in. In the past years unto now I have been in soccer, volleyball, badminton, basketball and softball. And if you need extra help the teachers are there for you. Even if you need help on the state exam they have programs to help to you succeed. Teachers and staff actually care about how you do in school. They want you go on to high school and college. If you like to sing there is young people's chrous for 3-8 grade. I will surely miss my teachers, the lunch staff, Mr. Chin, and Mrs. Ambert. If you love a small community this is the perfect place to be.-DG

This school is a great school, and I'm not just saying that because I go there. Most students who do leave our school after 5th grade, instead of staying for grades 6-8, often tell me that they miss it, and some of my friends who left said that they got better grades and test scores here. Our school is very small, and the teachers are completely awesome! I love all of my teachers, and find them very fair with homework load. Our school is also less crowded then others. Our school houses grades Pre-K through 8 and has about 500 students, while a nearby middle school that many kids leave to go to, has over 1500! If you want a small atmosphere where teachers and staff know you personally, and you're not just a number, then you should definatly come here!

I went to that school and graduated in 1982 when they had 6th grade, went to Ryan J.H.S. then Stuyvesant for 9th through 12th grade.   
Had very good memories of this school with printing press - all the plays we put on - the gifted program - I'm sure much may have changed but overall this was a great school.

Most of the info above is true but some is not. The info says that middle school students are kept in the same classrooms but that is not true. I actually am in the middle school and change classes all day just as any other high school or middle school. This school is a great place and I'm sad to be graduating from it this year. I will deffinatly miss it.

P.S. /I.S. 178 is by far the best school I have ever seen. I've been going there for 9 years. You would think one would get bored with the same school, but not me. These 9 years were well spent, and honestly, I don't think I would have done as well going to another school. This school was a BLUE RIBBON SCHOOL! That's an honor respected all over the country may I note. Basically, the blue ribbon goes to schools that exhibet excellent work. I give credit to all of the teachers who try their hardest to help us succeed. Because of the low population, the class sizes are smaller than average, and teachers know your name and know you much more personally than in over-crowded schools. Even the principal and assistant principal know everyones names. And at the top of the page you see the racial statistics: I believe we're much more than a number. We have multiculture day, where everyone brings in a board and foods from their culture and shares it with the school. We have people from Korea, Russia, Germany, Dominican Republic, Guyana, Ireland, Colombia, Bangladesh, Italy, China, etc: so don't judge the racial factor from above. Smart boards are eqiupped in every middle school classroom. (This is a K-8 school.) The extra-curricular activities are also superb. We have competative and non-competative teams including sports teams such as: Basketball, Soccer, Rugby, Football, Badmitton, Handball etc:. For the acedemic student we have: Math Team, Debate Team, Think Quest (A club where people make websites), etc:. For the student who wants to help the world we have: Recycling Club, Penny Harvest (A club where people collect money to give to the poor.) And of course the others such as Drama/Theater, AV, etc: You can easily be involved in more than one club due to them being on different days. Finally, the biggest question. Homework load?- The answer is: In elementary school the homework is fair, for younger students you won't get much homework at all, then when you get to 5th grade the homework takes about an hour or two at the most. Once you're in the middle school, the work load gets harder and you have to pace yourself. An organized student can get done in an hour or two, but if you're like me, it takes me 3 or 4 hours because I tend to get distracted VERY easily.-But that's me. Overall, I'd say come to Holliswood, the best school around! -GO BULLDOGS!

I really think that 178 is one of best schools in the district. The school makes you feel like you’re at home. The teachers know you very well and the staff is overall incredible. There are Smart Boards in every room of the middle school classes and I realized some schools don’t have the money to buy these high technological things. The homework amount is very decent, not too much, not too little and if you get lucky, some days you won’t have homework at all. :D

"The U.S. Department of Education named PS 178 a No Child Left Behind Blue Ribbon School. PS 178 is one of five New York City public schools -and 320 schools nationally - to receive this distinction which is given to schools which demonstrate dramatic gains in student achievement."

Student Janelle writes, "It's going to be so cool to be the first graduating class of the Holliswood Middle School. The teachers are always there for you whether it's staying after school or coming up during lunch time."

A parent calls Principal Diane Hobbs "understanding, sympathetic, intelligent, honorable, and dedicated" and praises her "open-door policy with parents." She writes that she was glad to have been directed to PS 178 when looking for a school that could accommodate her child's special needs. "At last we had a found a principal with a sympathetic ear ... who was willing to try something that we all knew was a risk," this parent writes, noting that when the original arrangement faltered, Hobbs stepped up her involvement. "She has spent countless hours doing everything possible to help our situation succeed."
A parent writes that the curriculum is "excellent" but that "communication among the staff and PTA to parents is quite poor. Principal Diane Hobbs is not very accessible."

"PS 178 is an exemplary public school with bright students, a dedicated principal, teachers and parents," writes a parent of a 2nd grader. "The quality of teaching is excellent, despite occasionally encountering some "old fashioned" practices/behaviors by more tenured teacher."
"The school is warming like a family, but very competitive," writes a former student. "Those who aren't on level of most students in the classes don't do well."
A parent writes that while the "teachers are great," the administration is not supportive to staff, and the PTA "is not an inviting environment."
I recently graduated in this school, but now I am in High School! All of the teachers here are very considerate, and they can help you overcome tough times. I recommend going to this school!

I went here from 1997 - 2003 for K-5 and it was an amazing school to grow up in. We used to have annual trips to the farm and the teachers were so kind and caring. I do wish that they had speech teachers when i was there since i grew up with and still have a stutter. Principal Quinn came in right when i entered 5th grade and she was very nice to everyone and seemed to really care about the students. I hope to place my future children in an ele.entary school as nice as this one!
PS 186 Castlewood parents are protesting the placement of a substitute teacher at the school who has been accused of inappropriate behavior with a student at a previous posting. Read more here.

Thank you to the parents who advocated for his removal. I am just finding out about this and my child goes to this school. I am at distress that this was not communicated to parents and very worried that our children were exposed to such danger.

Principal Dolores Troy-Quinn received a 2006 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.

"I have never seen anyone as dedicated, caring, helpful, and as capable as Principal Delores Quinn," writes parent Deanna Kane. "She truly loves her job and all of the children. My daughter had a problem with shyness and had trouble with low self esteem. I talked to Ms. Quinn and she has been very sensitive to my child's needs. She has gotten all of her teachers involved and constantly checks on my daughter while in the classroom."

A 2002 graduate of the school praises the teachers as "nice," the former principal as caring and funny. Security is "unbelievable," with teachers waiting until students leave. If parents don't come, students wait in an auditorium with a security guard. "Teachers are caring, funny, but strict with rules."
Anyone can tell me about the blueberry children after school program run in this school? Is it good? and How much they charge per month?

to "First time Parent" the Blueberry afterschool program is pretty good. The students are able to do all their homework, and we would play afterwards, like going outside or into the gym on rainy days. Sometimes Coach Andy would come and teach us about sports. Talk to Mr. Guha.
I used to go to PS 188 and it was great. I really want to note that Mr. Bruno is the BEST TEACHER EVER! (he teaches 5th grade) The teachers were great and 188 prepared me very well for middle school.
Phyllis Berk, a pre-kindergarten teacher at P.S. 188 Kingsbury was honored in a ceremony at Gracie Mansion and presented with a Big Apple Award. Read more here.

how about blueberry after school program.
I am first time parent to this school.
I want to put my child to Blueberry after school children program.
any recommendation.

I'm currently a 5th grader at P.S. 188, in the Gifted&Talented program. This school is so amazing. it provides me with everything I need to grow and strive as a learner and critical thinker. I don't want to leave P.S. 188 for middle school :(
The Reebok foundation is bringing its physical activity program, BOKS to P.S. 188 as part of an expansion of physical activity options for elementary school children. Read more here.
Love the school but beware the music and art teachers
haha
I love u lizzy
PS 188 ranked number five for NYC elementary schools on the new state exams. Read more here.

As a former student, I loved this school. I can say that there is social seperation from the Magnet and "Normal" classes, but people do mingle in the afterschool programs. For the kids who enter the Magnet program, in 3rd grade for example, from one of the "Normal" classes tend to combine their old friendships with the ones developed in the Magnet program. I am strongly against the idea to develop a citywide test for PS188. PS188 is not that type of environment, and some of the upsides of PS188 is that all the kids usually live near each other, they have known each other for a while, and they have even seen their teachers around town. And lets say a child from Brooklyn gets accepted into PS188--What if they have a half an hour commute? You would have to wake the child up earlier than normal, and it is more that likely that their parents work in the opposite direction of PS188. That would put unnecessary stress on the child and the parent.

Instead of spending money on creating a testing program and having children be sent out of their neighborhood to another to get a good education, maybe the city should spend money on making schools in less educated districts better. That way the disrict could soon have it's own school with great education, and you can have intelligent children stay in their own neighborhoods and contribute to their community, instead of being shipped off to another borough.

This is the most prejudiced comment I've ever seen on this website.  You should really be ashamed of yourself.  Clearly we all know the demographic of the neighborhood in which PS 188 is located.   You  should understand [that]the NYC Public School system is just that -PUBLIC. Therefore, the same education should be afforded to all students no matter where they live.  NYC parents pay taxes for all of our children and we know that the money does not follow the child, so why should your children that happen to live in a certain neighborhood only go to the best performing schools?  What makes you or them so entitled?  Queens county  is home to some of the most segregated communities and from comments like this I see why.  

The world is so much larger than your little community and as a parent you might want to get out  from under the rock where you live and experience other cultures and ways of thinking and maybe you should expose your children as well.

There is a reason why there are zoned schools for neighborhoods. Listing PS 188 as a citywide school will only created more segregation. Your comment shows that you don't understand the school system. Why blame a neighborhood? Rather, blame the DOE in not being able to provide better education for ALL of its students. The onus should be on the DOE to implement programs to create equitable schools in ALL neighborhoods.
Some parents support this school’s decision to replace recess with activities and clubs. Read more At Top Public Schools, the Arts Replace Recess.

Queens families are concerned that the Department of Education's proposal to replace the district Gifted and Talented program in PS 188 with a city-wide program will take away seats for Queens residents. Read the story: Fears fly over the fate of Queens PS 188's local gifted and talented program.

"I was in the 'magnet' or gited program from 1st to 5th and I absolutely loved it," writes Kaitlin, who graduated in 2005. "The former principal, Arlene Burg, was very stern, but she kept the school in order."

A parent complains that Principal Janet Caraisco was "totally unresponsive to parent concerns" after a teacher was in an accident and had to hand her class over to substitute teachers. The principal sent little communication home about the situation, refused to meet with parents who requested meetings, and did not adequately supervise the substitute teachers, even while confusion about assignments and disorder reigned in the classroom, this parent writes.

Andrea, a student, writes: "Through all of my six years in PS188, the school overall is probably the best elementary in the city. The teachers, the students and all of the supportive parents are truley what make this school really great!" She adds: "I have to give special thanks to our retired principal Arlene Berg for keeping our school #1! I hope that all of the students who enter our school will enjoy learning as much as I have."

A former student writes: "I was in this school since Kindergarten and 2 years ago I graduated. I LOVED this school!" This alum writes that the teachers were very nice, and praises Mrs. Kazin in particular. She adds: "Even as an ESL student I understood almost everything!"

A parent who transferred her child to PS 191 from a lower-performing school told Insideschools, "My son has learned so much since he's been in the school. I'm in college now but my son recognizes what I'm doing for my classes. He recognizes what the main idea is in my work and he's in 4th grade."

Parent Pat Pisani writes: "In June, my youngest daughter will be graduating from this wonderful school. My two other children also graduated from P.S. 191. The teachers, staff and principal are all wonderful. I am sad to be leaving after 10 years."
"I am in PS 191Q in 5th grade and this is a great school," writes a student. "This school involves lots of education and there is also time for a little fun."
PS 203 is sending teams to the Odyssey of the Mind competition, an international creative problem solving contest active with participants from across the US and 25 countries. Read more here.

They need to check who comes to this school and how. I know for a fact two students in the gifted program in this school got here by lying . They were helped out by another school as to what to put on their applications and basically fooling the system so that they can get both their kids into the program. One sibling didn't even pass the test. she just got in b/c the brother did.
PS203 is really an amazing school. There are programs that increase responsibility such a MITTS and the arts program gives you a nice selection of clubs.

Principal Nussbaum demands perfection from her teachers and students.  I am sure it’s not easy to be a teacher or student at the school.  However, most ultimately feel grateful that they have this shared experience of excellence.  Equally important, the community deeply appreciates her laying a strong academic foundation for its children.  I hope she never retires.

Made a typo...

I wish I could tell her* where I am now.

"Teacher Union Representative" explains that Ms. Nussbaum is not racist but that is truly undermining the terrible experiences of minority students who did experience negative bias from her. We're not fabricating our experiences and it is truly hurtful that the voice of the minority child is being overruled by an adult who just won't listen. I was a student there many years ago and I'm sad to hear that she is still the Principal. This is coming from an Ivy League graduate. I wish I could tell here where I am now.
Huh. All the students seem to like her. Including me.
But you DID graduate from an Ivy League school.  Ms. Nussbaum would be pround of you

This is a great school for smart kids and even a better
school for kids that need additional help. Teachers do not make excuses for
anyone. It's elementary school after all and ALL kids regardless of their
innate ability should be able to master the material.  So advice to parents, don’t blame the school
if they can’t keep up – work with the school to demand more from your
child.  The moment you lower the bar for
your kid, you have given up on him or her!
I hope the principal at 203 never retires!  She is the glue that holds this entire place together.  And, our City needs more schools like this.
As a former student, I know from experience that this school is utterly phenomenal.
Mrs. Nussbaum, the principal, is spectacular -- she is an talented educator and an extraordinary chief executive!  Whether you are a student or teacher -- God help you if you don't give 100%.
P.S. 203 provided me with a wonderful academic foundation in the 1980's. I'm glad to see that things haven't changed.

All my former classmates at P.S. 203 ended up at the best
high schools in the City and many of them are now attending Ivy League
Universities.  I know this is only an anecdotal
evidence of the strong academic foundation that P.S. 203 gave us (after all, we were first taught the scientific method at the school).  However, for me and my friends, it’s the
reality!

Carole Nussbaum does not have a problem with people who are minorities.  Carole Nussbaum has a problem with teachers who don't want to give 100%.  She has a problem with people who come to work unprepared, or ill-prepared.  She is one of the most hard-working, knowledgeable, and creative teachers I have ever met.  She wants teachers and students to be the best that they can be, and not just engage in "get by" behavior.  I would take a very long look at the parent(s) who are most vocal in their attacks.  Follow a diva child home, and a diva parent will open the door for him/her.

Kids have to go to the back school yard for line up in the morning, but there're always 2 parked cars at the enterance. I saw a kid hurt his arm trying to squeeze in between those cars. Is it legal to parked the cars there?
the cars are the pricipals.

I don't believe anything in your note. My child is a minority in P.S. 203 and has been for  two years now. When I brought my child to this school I had no knowledge of how wonderful an experience it would be. My child was a student in a private school that didn't have the funding to help, so they just kept passing him to the next grade. My child started this WONDERFUL SCHOOL in third grade with a first grade reading level and was given all the extra classes he needed to sucide within record time. We were told right away that my child might be left back at the end of the year. However, P.S. 203's Principle,teachers and staff worked harder then I could have ever hoped for and my child not only passed but earned 4's on both state test.
I am so thankful to the teachers for all their hard work and love,to the staff for all their compassion and to an amazing principle that isn't afraid to bring the best out in her teacher. Being "THE BOSS" is a hard job and I have never seen anyone in all my years do it as well as Mrs. Nussbaum. Her job is to make the children in her school sucide, to make sure the staff is doing their job and if that means she comes off "mean", you need to realize, that's her job and THANK GOD she does it well enough to be one of the top N.Y. public schools. You should feel blessed that your child has been given the chance to be apart of this school rather then complaining about unfounded feelings. 
I don't know where my child would be today if it wasn't for all of these wonderful professionals.

"As as a high school senior just about to go on to college, I continue to remember all the amazing experiences I had at PS203. The loving teachers, the enriching field trips,and the overall atmosphere all things that I have not found anywhere else. This is an amazing school with a dedicated staff Class of 2002!"
Jennifer, a former student, writes: "I LOVE this school!. When I graduated in 2004 it was the greatest moment in my life."

A former student writes, "I think this school is a great place to put your child in to learn. The teachers are all nice and caring. Mrs. Nussbaum shows other people that she knows what she is doing. This school helped me a lot in middle school from all the things they have taught me." She adds, "The drama club is the bomb!!! The cast [members] all look so professional!"
Mrs. Nussbaum is really encouraging to us.

I went that school al my life and i will never foget it. I was the best 7 years of my life.

This was a wonderful school that I attended and I learned a lot for five years. The learning experience and environment was wonderful, especially the science courses. We learned how to organize our notebooks and we explored the realms of environmental science such as the tomato-sphere project and the soil testings. The other subjects such as math and English also taught us a lot because every teacher put a tremendous amount of time and effort into each student.This school created a strong foundation for my academics. Thank you PS205!

"The staff of this school was truly part of a great and small community and was immensely supportive of the students," writes Eric,a graduate. "I realize that this school offered me many opportunities that other schools did not even come close to matching, such as the hands-on experience of a vegetable garden to foreign culture activities such as the annual Lunar New Year play."

According to the city Quality Review Report, "Each individual is known very well to all staff and students feel valued, supported and confident in their ability to succeed. Expectations are high and students are challenged to make the best progress they can."

Kapil, a former student, writes: "I love this school incredibly." This student describes positive experiences at the school including art class, yearly class plays, holiday celebrations such as a haunted house, the magic club run by Mr. Blum, Baskin Robins at the end of each year, and field days in the park.
Mr. Blum wasn't here this year. I think he said that he wanted to train more with technolgy. Mr. C is taking his place THIS year. Too bad I forgot my graduation book when Mr. Blum came to school.
Website QNS reports that PS 213 has been named a Reward School by New York State.

The School is a mixed bag. Some good teachers and some pretty lazy ones. Principal more interested in how things look instead of her teacher's effectiveness. Too many tenured teachers who don't have the majic, but several others do have it. Like I said, a mixed bag here.
does anyone know if ms.grand is still teaching there

"This school teaches a lot of manners and it is a full hard working school which also includes fun activities at the same time," writes former student Grace Yang. "They have group activities and lots of trips that help develop the kids mind and teaches them a whole lot! I remember going to this school years ago and I sure know that I learned a lot from the school and Im extremely excited to be having a niece going to pre-k next year and she will love it! I you need to send a daughter or son you should pick P.S. 213 Carl Ullman school for your first choice!"
A parent notes that there is little emphasis on spelling at the school and "no spelling bees until the 5th grade."
"This school is good, but it should be better," writes student Peter. "Recess is to short. In cafeteria it is too noisy."
Daniel, a former student, writes: "I think that this is a number one school and I would recommend it to anyone in a heartbeat."
Does any one know the difference between GT and IGC classes.  The school also has SP classes as well.

I would personally like to say a big thank you to all staff at Ryan MS 216. To say the word staff is a injustice because they have become friends and my villagers. It does take a village to raise kids and the "staff" at Ryan does a great job.A very wise parent teacher coordinator, Mr. Nichols, once said that during the three years (grades 6-8) the kids spend at Ryan, they grow and mature so much. During all their changes, Ryan has been their to guide and encourages them. From the workshop in helping dealing with adolescent behavior to high school workshops. This school is great with providing parents and well as students with the tools they need to succeed. After school programs and activities are a great way for them to express themselves and find interest to encourage social skills. From robotics to roadrunners and i just want to say GO LIONS!! The security guards are respectful and provide safety from making sure the kids get in for homeroom until all after school activities are over. The cleaning staff maintains a clean environment for productivity. The teachers go above and beyond to providing successful students education. They offer their time to hold tutoring and keep in touch with parents to keep them updated on progress (good and bad). I would like to think that because they have a good principal,  Dr. Landeau, to lead by example. From the weekly calls to keep parents informed of events to the wow words, Dr. Landeau had always made time to say hello or discuss something serious. He has always done so with a smile that in encouraging. I can see why this school is a blue ribbon award winner. Keep up the great work. I am very happy with the time i have spent with all of you!
Hi! Does anyone remember the vice principal in 1999 by chance?

I have four kids graduated from Ryan and two of them going to college. But till today they keep reporting their progresses to Ryan school . I missed that school. To me as a parent the best school ever because Ryan school made sure that my kids are on track. Helped them not only improve their academics but build their personalities their confidence. This school helped them how to set goals and how to work to reach those goals. I have been in this school for SEVEN YEARS. I was an active parent, I was volunteering in most of the school’s events I joined the SLT and PTA. This gave me the chance to see how the staff actually think and work for the students to make sure they succeed. The school helped graduates and their parents throw the process of high school. One fact, if the parents got involved with school , they can see how the school perform and they can see the influence on the students. 2 of my kids were in honor classes, one was in regular class and one was in special ED class. All teachers were amazing I didn’t have any doubt that any of my kids will perform low in their classes. Actually the school helped them improved their performance more than I expected. The school made them true leaders. I really miss this school. Ryan is like home and everyone in their is like family.

My son just graduated from Ryan and we  will truly miss the school and staff.  The school offers a lot, and I've witnessed personal and academic growth for my son. 

 I recommend all parents volunteer and become apart of the PTA, SLT and attend the monthly meetings.  Mr. Satya one of the APs is  dedicated and attends each meeting.

The school has a welcoming environment from the school safety to teachers and admin-istration.  The teachers do respond to you, via email or pupil path.  

Mr. Nichols, the parent coordinator is PHENOMENAL.  He goes above and beyond to make sure families are engaged and connected. 

Dr. Landeau serves our school community well and we've been recognized as a Blue Ribbon school. 

Our memories with Ryan will always be cherished.

With fondness, 
the Russo's
How do i do my sons application, because i want him to go to your school.

I don't like Ryan. This is only my experience with it. There was virtually no difference in academies, other than teachers and colors they would wear to assemblies. It was a dumb idea. There were a lot of fights during lunch time and the courtyard. There was a lot of cursing in the lunchroom when teachers weren't around. Many teachers were rude and sometimes helpful but 5 minutes after school was over they were gone. The teachers at my new school are a lot more supportive and there aren't nearly as many clubs as in my new school. We were often given a lot of work or not enough to practice what we learned. I felt it was too easy to get good grades, where as in my new school hard work really does come into play. And everything was so overcrowded. 30+ kids to a class and no varying languages to learn, only Spanish. This is my rant, disorganized but says all it needs to say.
Mr. Nichols is the best PARENT COORDIANTOR in the world!!! Everyone should be like him

MS 216 is one of eight New York City public schools to achieve Blue Ribbon Status, a national award for schools with students with test scores in the top 15 percent in their state, regardless of demographic background, Chalkbeat reports.

I have three children currently attending this wonderful middle school. I have an I.C.T.-(Integrated Co-Teaching) student, an I.G.C.(Intellectually Gifted Children) student and a general education student.  Because of this I have probably met about half of the teachers at this school and each teacher has been encouraging and supportive. From the moment I went to orientation with my son for 6th grade I felt right at home and I felt that my kids were going to be okay. The principal, Dr. Landeau, is an amazing speaker and quickly captivated the crowd.  He spoke of his personal experience in middle school which really resonated with me. I can’t say enough good things about this school. The Parent Coordinator, Mr. Nicholls, is not only a parent coordinator but a friend, his door is always open. The teachers are phenomenal, talented and go above and beyond for their students. The students are just as amazing and I have met some of the very best parents at Ryan. This is a school of about 1500 kids and it runs like clockwork and offers so much to the kids academically and for after school activities.  I know when they walk into Ryan they are safe. I love being a part of this school and community, it truly is like a family.

When my daughter graduated from elementary school I had many questions and worries about middle school. It’s different system, different environment, bigger school, more students. My daughter was a high active student in elementary she was participated almost in all activities in school. When she went to Ryan I asked myself will she be able to that does the school provide such activities will she be able to adjust in her new school. My daughter was participating in many clubs from dance to leadership program. She was highly active student more than elementary. The school built her personality, her skills, her goals, her dreams. The school tought her the skills , showed her the way of success and she achieved her goals she was one of the top students. And now my son will graduate from the same school. This school improved my son’s academic levels in overall the school helped him to be in honor roll after 6 months and he is still in honors roll. Such school I will never forget and I will always be thankful for everything they did it to my kids. Five years I never had a single complaint about the school in anything. Best communication, staff, organization, updates, events , clubs , enrichments, aids. When the school is keeping you updated day by day on your kids improvements and needs and struggling issues and helping them with all of that . To me that is the best school. Thanks Ryan.

I have been a teacher here for about 10-20 years but previously taught in a private high school and Long Island public high school.  If I had the chance to place my own child in any of the schools I have ever taught or attended, it would be this school.  Everyone here is nice, from the principal to the guidance counselors to the lunch personnel to the janitors.  I really appreciate the fact that this school is so diversified and caring.

I have always had good communication with parents and really appreciate the new parent coordinator.  The parent coordinator is compassionate and caring, and I always know he and the guidance department truly care about our students.  I am proud to work here and the parents of this school are proud their children attend this school.  There's no wonder this school is working at capacity.

The leadership team is a group of professionals who are authoritative and respectful.  It all starts with leadership, and I believe we have leaders who are tough and fair.  I respect them immensely as they are empathetic and appreciative of my hard work.  I appreciate they have brought bragging rights back to Ryan.

My fellow teachers are very hard working and talented.  They are technologically gifted, implement a vigorous curriculum, and have many different levels of experience.  I enjoy working with the young teachers full of energy as well as the talented teachers with years of experience.  I am grateful and proud I get to work here and would definitely place my child in this school if given the opportunity.

Three years ago, when my son was in fifth grade, we came to an orientation
at Ryan. I remember a young lady, an eighth grader, speaking about her
experiences at Ryan and how much she loved the school. I looked at my son and I
had the same hopes and dreams for him. 

I have always had faith in my son’s teachers and therapists. The
administrators and staff at his schools have been wonderful, too, and never
more so than at Ryan. I was very anxious when he started sixth grade. That
transition is a tough one. I realized right away that the work was tough but
the teachers, administrators and staff always support these kids. They never
feel alone, they always have guidance and help. I saw my son turning into a
young man these last three years. He's taking ownership of his life and
choices. It has been incredible to watch. 

I really don't even think I can express how grateful I am to everyone at
Ryan. My son would not be in this place without this school community helping
him, guiding him and encouraging him. It is truly a special school. I feel
incredibly lucky to have the privilege to send both of my sons to Ryan.

I am joining this school soon, but with summer registration, i dont know which one of the three programs i will be put into. I prefer to choose myself, but im afraid that might not be a option for summer registers. Can someone please help out?
Whatever program you are in. You ma be able to switch at some point in the school years.

If someone can answer this question it would be helpful
Now they created something that which is like a test, to determine if the student meets the igc standards. They take it in 5th grade. Grades most definitely matter.

Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. J.H.S. 216 George J. Ryan was chosen to host Ronald Edmonds Learning Center II and P.S. 42 R. Vernam. Read more here.
its really true this school sucks and does not do good with the cursing and people fighting and doing everything bad

Granted, there were definetly some teachers who were my favorite and made it atleast bareable but still I wouldnt have had much of a horrid experience with the rude and non-caring teachers as well as some of the deans. only one foreign language class and gym is overcrowded. 100 students in one gym at the same time!
I agree with you. The gym is TOO overcrowded. They should separate them. Also they should let us play sports not just a bit but let us learn
This school is terrible i was here for 3 three years. the idea of three academies is idiotic the principles are terrible and the teachers don't care about anything.

This report is so outdated. Ryan is the best middle school in the district according the the DOE. Only school with an "A" grade and sends more kids to specialized HS than any other middle school in Queens. Dr. Landeau runs a tight ship. I have seen the school change drastically over the last 10 years. You need to go back and see what they are doing there now!
Graduated back in '76. How the demographics have changed since that time.

I am in 8th grade, been here since 6th, and spent all three years in IGC (Intelligently Gifted Class). The school is pretty cool, but it is just overpopulated. The class sizes are huge, making it impossible to tend to a specific student's concerns or needs. About 3 teachers in the ENTIRE school are horrible, and about 10 are AMAZING. The rest are okay. I have to admit, though, that Mr, sorry, DR Landeau should go. The students and staff deserve better.

In 8th grade, been here since 6th, and all three years in IGC (Intelligently Gifted Class). The school is pretty cool, but it is just overpopulated. The class sizes are huge, making it impossible to tend to a specific student's concerns or needs. About 3 teachers in the ENTIRE school are horrible, and about 10 are AMAZING. The rest are okay. The administration isn't the best. If it was to be rated from 1-10, I would say 4. However, the location, is not dangerous. Though reports show it to be, students all feel safe, and are genuinely happy.
Ryan is awesome!!! I've been there for like 2 months, but still. AWESOME!!!

The school needs more lunch food options, and things that people from other religions can actually eat. Also, there is a very strict bullying policy which is great. One flaw is that you can get easily suspended for little things. Anyway the school is great

one of the best schools! i had an amazing three years at this school. It is safe, friendly, and fun! The school does lack lockers,and more clubs, but it is a great school. The staff is very friendly and helpful.
hey! Mr. Landeau isn't that bad. Besides the lunch staff is really should improve in many ways.
this site notes the great work of the teachers and students in spite of a miserable administration
the principal needs to go.  he got rid of the best teacher, ms. montagano.  i'm leaving the school this year and i'm glad b/c landeau is mean and doesn't think about us students.
The Learning Environment Survey for this school says it all.

"I'll be graduating from MS216 this year. What a great school and what a remarkable teaching faculty! I enjoyed every moment of my time and studies and will truly miss MS 216 especially the Science Olympiad Team. When we took the 1st Place at the high school level, I could not have been more proud of Mr. Franco and my fellow team members. Good luck Rayan's at the 2009 NYS Science Olympiad in SUNY Paltz (April 17/18)! Thank you Principal Landeau for giving us such great opportunity."

"Parent Coordinator Susan Chang writes to tell Insideschools about a new partnership between the school and the St. John's University (SJU) School of Education. According to Chang, the university will provide teacher training to the school's staff. In particular, teachers who instruct the honors and Special Progress Enrichment classes will pursue SJU certification in gifted & talented education. The university will also offer a Saturday college experience program for 100 students, and it will work with the soccer and tennis teams to promote physical fitness."

"As a parent of a 7th grader at MS 216, with another child coming into the school for 6th grade in September, I have to totally commend the principal, Mr. Landau, and the school overall," writes a parent. "From my experience, I have found Mr. Landau to be a very enthusiastic official of his school. He is also very visible, very approachable and friendly. His passion for what he does and for his school emanates when you hear him speak at a PTA meeting or any other meeting. As for the rest of the staff, whether it's a guidance counselor, office administrator, dean, and especially teachers, in my son's 6th grade and now in 7th grade, I need to commend them also, because they have been caring, welcoming, open, and passionate, in my dealings with them. Also, our parent coordinator has been very helpful and informative with her emails. My son only has good things to say about all of his teachers. I am constantly amazed at all the programs that are always available and ongoing, such as the TASC program, Beacon program, Honors, IGC, sports, community service, and so many more opportunities for students to get involved in this school."
"George J Ryan is a great school," writes student Tahmid. "This is my last year there and I have to say, I learned a LOT! The three academies were a great idea."

"Some teachers are mean but the young ones are very laid back and let you get away with anything," writes a student. "There are a lot of fights. In September of 2006 there were three or four fights every week, and our school gets into fights with other schools."
Fenella, a student, writes: "This school is the best. I'm having a good time here. It has lots of fun activities to go to. All the students are active and really try their best."
Samantha, who is in her final year at the school, writes: "This is a great school. ... I learned a lot."
Samantha, a student, writes: "I am the graduating class this year. My 3 years have been successful and I learned alot."
Kelly, a former student, writes: "It's a great school, but students fight and after school."

Patrick, a student, writes: "This school need more fun activities and programs [such as] handball tournament, raffles, and more. Ryan is a good school but just needs some excitement." He adds that most of the teachers are great.

Kyla, a former student, writes: "Ryan is a really great school. All of the teachers are very friendly and always there to help out the students. I attended Ryan from 6-8 grade and it has well prepared me for high school."
A student writes that the school has been experiencing many small changes, including new vending machines for the students.

I was a student in this school (Alumni Class of 2011) and I loved this school. The tree that was grown in the side of the exits was in memory of my 3 friends who has taken the "big nap." But anyways, why digress? PS 221 was an amazing school, to show how education should be a challenge and a fun thing to do at the same time! My teachers were really amazing!! The principal, Mrs. Bullard, was the Assistant Principal the first time when I turned to a 4th grader. She was the best and I was very close with her; she'd take me to her office and comfort me when I feel like I'm down. She's very nice and comforting. The kids are academically doing great and the environment is never a worry! This is a place to be to be a great student in the future!

My child attends this school and we are please with the strong PTA at the school and the teachers and staff.  Principal Bullard and the Vice Principal are both dedicated and warm to the kids.  The school is well deserving of it's Blue Ribbon award.
I think PS 221 is the best school ever! All the teachers are super! They make learning fun.

Jennifer Malave's 2nd grade class wrote the following profile of their school:

Team Malave believes that PS 221 is one of the best New York City public elementary schools...

The atmosphere at PS 221 is wonderful! Everyone is excited because we like to learn. Everyone is happy because we won the National Blue Ribbon. Every kid walks around with a smile on their face. We like to come to school. We make visitors welcome by inviting them to PS 221.

The teachers at PS 221 are awesome! Our teachers take care of us. They work very hard. They solve our problems. They make us smart too.

We do our homework at PS 221. At PS 221 we do our math almost every night. Everybody reads every day. At PS 221 we do science homework sometimes. We have spelling homework on weekdays.

PS 221 is a beautiful school building. PS 221 is a clean school. The rooms, floors, walls and desks are always clean. Carpets in classrooms are vacuumed. Being in a clean school helps us learn better.

The cafeteria at PS 221 is where we eat. In the cafeteria, we can talk to each other. They serve good and healthy food. There are a couple of different food choices. Lunch is never boring. In the cafeteria, the lunch ladies are very nice. We all have a spot to sit in. There are lots of tables in the cafeteria.

PS 221 is a National Blue Ribbon school. We study hard for our tests and we never cheat. We work hard to take care of our community. We listen to each other and our teachers. We are respectful and peaceful. We work hard and don't give up.

In closing, we feel that our examples prove that PS 221 is one of the best New York City public elementary schools!

I am more than satisfied and grateful with PS 221.PS 221 is definitely one of the best schools in NYC. I moved here from Riverdale Bronx and I know I have made the right choice. My daughter is now second grade and she totally loves everything of it. I have seen tremendous progresses and improvements since she started school. From not knowing the language, reading or writing to now a regular reader who can read advance books and write her own composition. My daughter just loves being in class with her classmates and loves her teacher Ms.Malave. This is the most important because i want my child to be happy in school and enjoys learning. PS 221 rocks!

PS 221 was one of six NYC schools to receive the 2013 Blue Ribbon Award from the United States Department of Education. The Blue Ribbon schools are recognized for their academic excellence and their success in preparing students for college and careers. Read more here.
i love ps.221 it is the best school i ever been to mrs bullard is also a great  princapal

A parent of triplets writes that she "couldn't have asked for better administrators" and that the school aides "are in a class by themselves." Everyone at the school, from teachers to the nurse to the safety agent, offered "love, support, and kindness every step of the way," this parent writes.
PS 221 is a "well developed school" according to the New York City Department of Education's quality review report.

"PS 221 has been balanced literacy for a long time so we haven't changed much," said Principal Twomey in reference to the roll out of the citywide, uniform curriculum "but we are growing upon what we have. Our philosophy is to give the children as much literacy power as possible."
This is my son's first year.  So far, so good.  He has a great teacher, Mrs. Kruter and the principal has a great vision for the school. Great PTA and parental involvement is encouraged.
How do  u get admittedto this school

It's only our first year here, 1st & 4th grade boys, but are very happy so far. I feel welcomed something I thought such a big school might midd out on. I love mt sons' teachers they are very caring and keep contact with you..for bad and good! I only wish the first grade had fewer students, 30 is way too large for the little ones. They offer so much here that their prior school ps 159 really lacked!!! Trips, parent involvement, activities on campus like Halloween party & carnival, even 
A career day, many things don't require big funds just caring, time and coordination.

This is an amazing public school, my daughter started here in 6th grade and is due to graduate this year. I have had experiences with other middle schools in my district with my older child and this is a child friendly school. I made a point of joining all her class trips and volunteering at events at the school as we really did not know much about the school before she got in. I have to say every person that is staff, children and parents I have met here were wonderful. My daughter blossomed, loves school and her teachers. The teachers are demanding and know your child very well. My daughter has 
been accepted to a specialised high school in Manhatten and I believe she is well prepared for what is ahead of her because of her three great years in PS/IS 266.

I think the schools statistics could be better but who am I to judge. the are very nice and supportitive. Ive seen the children on feild trips. They go to many educational places that are woth our money and the kids are very happy here
how do i transfer my daughter in this school?

My son was in the pre-k program here last year and I feel that his teachers were far from ideal. They do not take their jobs seriously. My son has mentioned that they are too busy chatting about their lives to really pay attention to them. It is only for a few hours yet they can't seem to focus on the tasks on hand. I feel that the kids are not respected as I have seen both of them talk over a child's comments. They are pre-k students but their thoughts should be respected as well. These two don't understand that. Its disturbing to me that there does not seem to be a strenuous review process for hiring pre-k teachers. You really cannot complain to Ms. Scott during the semester as your child is still in the class but I felt that now was the right time to voice my concerns. I would really think twice before enrolling your child in the pre-k program here.

"This lottery-based school is truly a gem. Principal Scott along with Asst. principal Winter lead the school positively and are open to ideas and new initiatives. Amazing building offering Smartboards in many classrooms, beautiful library and computers. Highly active PTA is phenomenal in their fundraising efforts to compensate for budgetary cuts imposed by the State. The school instills month core values, such as determination, tolerance, perseverence, knowledge through literature to its entire student body, K-8. Teachers are caring and understanding. The school reaches out to outside sources, i.e., NY Islanders, Harlem Wizards, to provide varied experiences for their students during their assembly periods. The school also offer afterschool programs for student enrichment. Although parking can be complicated at this school, many bus routes are established to take children from throughout the district. Too bad there are no G&T classes available in the elementary grades."

Principal Kenneth Morris received a 2006 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.

"This school was a great experience for me," writes a former student. "Everyone knows each other and is friendly to each other. I had so many memories and made a lot of friends. I would definitely recommend this school to any parent or child because of its wonderful faculty and friendly atmosphere."

Alyssa, a graduate of PS/IS 266, writes: "I was so lucky to graduate from this school. My experiences with the staff and fellow students will never be forgotten. ... Mr. Morris, Mrs. Scott, Mrs. Ramdath, Mrs. Shriki, and all of my teachers really made my year memorable. I'm glad I was a part of the first graduating class."

"The school is great," writes Kristen K., an 8th grader. "Mr. Morris and Ms. Scott are a wonderful team in our school. Mr. Morris is a great principal and he's also a very good person to just talk to. I was a part of the girls basketball team last year and it was a great experience. I love the school and I'm very upset that I will have to graduate this year and leave the school and the teachers that I love."

A parent writes, "My children are very comfortable in their new school. Even though you mention that there is no neighborhood connecting the school, and children are dropped off by car or bus, I believe it is to our benefit." She explains that at her children's old school, a lack of parking spaces, as well as rules barring parents from pulling up to the front of the school to take their children inside, forced many parents to walk to the school with their kids, even in bad weather. Since many families at PS 266, "have many children in the school, or in other schools ... bussing is very helpful to moms and dads who have to bring different children to different places at the same time." She adds, "The school is very comfortable, not overcrowded like other elementary schools & My children love the large library, and gym. The school is a happy place where older children, 7th- and 8th-graders, are very helpful and protective of the younger children. In almost one term the children are becoming a family."

"My children love it," said the parent of a 3rd grader and a 7th grader." Besides the newness, they're following the same model as other district 26 schools- the celebrations and the projects." This parent also praised the "diversity of cultures" represented by the students and the teaching staff.  The school "tried to get the best and the brightest teachers. A lot of the teachers come with a lot of experience," she said.

P.S./M.S. 42 is on a list of 50 schools that will participate in the DOE's Bronx Plan, which will boost salaries in hard-to-staff positions and "give teachers formal decision-making power in their schools" according to Chalkbeat.
P.S. 42 violates school cafeteria city health inspections, according to Spectrum News NY1.
Amsterdam News reports that PS/MS 42 will remain open

Parents at PS 42 in Far Rockaway are fighting an uphill battle to keep their school open, Chalkbeat reports. https://www.chalkbeat.org/posts/ny/2018/01/09/harkening-back-to-earlier-era-struggling-new-york-city-school-fights-closure-but-faces-long-odds/
The principal of PS/MS 42 was punched in the face while breaking up a fight outside the school, reports DNAinfo.

P.S./M.S. 042 R. Vernam has been selected to participate in the Department of Education's Community Schools initiative, aimed at boosting attendance and achievement by bringing in community partners to provide support for students and families. P.S./M.S. 042 R. Vernam's partner is Family Health International 360. Read more about the program here. and see the full list of schools, their community partners and their proposed services here.

Ninety-four low-performing schools are now called “Renewal Schools,” by DiBlasio. They will receive increased funds designated for an hour of additional learning time, after-school and summer programs, and teacher training. The principals will also be under review. Read more here.
