The Reebok foundation is bringing its physical activity program, BOKS to M.S. 42 as part of an expansion of physical activity options for elementary school children. Read more here.
The NYPD is investigating a teacher at PS/MS 42 for sexually abusing a student. Read more here.

A parent writes: "My daughter came out of pre-k reading and writing and was put into this school. She started in kindergarten and made honors each year. [In] 4th grade she was put into a lower class with students who were not doing so well. I was then told that her grades were not what they needed to be in 3rd grade although her report was excellent. I was then told by the 3rd-grade teacher that she only allowed her to be on the honor roll that year because she felt she needed the encouragement." She continues: "She has now adjusted to the classroom she is in and does well; although she does not make the honor roll, she is passing ... I was terribly upset that the 3rd-grade teacher did not inform me of any troubles that my daughter was having -- and mind you she taught her in the 2nd grade as well."
"The school has a good reputation in this district," said a kindergarten mother. "I went here. They give a lot of homework. I wish they gave more tutoring."
"Everyone works together to make it better for kids and parents," said a staff person who handles attendance.
"I like the school," said a kindergarten mother. "They have good teachers. It's clean. The security is good."

"So far, it seems to be pretty good," said a kindergarten and pre-kindergarten mother. "When they let them out [after school], I think there should be more supervision. There's a step where my daughter comes out [a side exit, not the main exit] that should be fixed. Everyone is worried about getting over that step."
"It's been fine so far," said a kindergarten mother. "But he doesn't like that they don't get much recess. He likes the homework and the teachers."
"We have a new principal, and she's good," said a paraprofessional. "So things are getting better. It's a big change."

"Some people say it's failing, but I think it's a pretty good school," said a 3rd grade parent. "The teachers are good; they're dedicated to their students. The homework they bring home is accurate [appropriate to age and grade]. They get good grades."
"My daughter's been here since kindergarten," said a 3rd grade parent. "She gets good teachers. The best thing is that they can get free tutoring Tuesdays and Wednesdays after school."
"We need things: a bigger gym, vending machines," said a 6th grader.
"We need cleaner bathrooms," said another 6th grader.

PS 43 was the biggest winner in the Municipal Credit Union's "Build a Better School" contest, receiving $20,000 to rebuild classrooms destroyed by Hurricane Sandy. Read more here.

PS 43 is piloting an extended day program that will give participating students the opportunity to get extra help with literacy and to participate in extracurricular activities. As the program gets underway, the school is troubleshooting solutions for increasing participation. Read more here.

PS 43 is among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

I hope that everyone who has posted has an opportunity to read this post. I entered the education system within the walls of PS/MS 43 in 1997. It was a ground of care and discovery. Teachers aided this environment, the parents and students created it.  I graduated in 2004. I am now a Midshipman at the United States Naval Academy. If that is not success, please tell me what it is. I was instructed by the same teachers your children have. I resolved issues with the same "overwhelmed" guidance counselors. I wrote essays in the single computer lab. I studied under Mrs.Classie when she was Ms. Stublick. I was under the command of Principal John Quattrocchi. 
The success of students is not solely  dependent upon the discipline of their instructors, but also the respect of the students. The respect is instilled at home. If parents forget to instill this paramount value within their children, then lack of response to authority should be expected. 
I studied in overcrowded rooms. I read the inappropriate comments on the bathroom stalls. Yet I had the determination to work hard and make it through. If I can do it, your child can do it. 
Also, when you are posting to complain about an institutions' lack of success, please be vigilant of your grammatical errors.

"Bullying is an issue at this school," writes a parent. "My child has been a target at this school for a few years. I finally put my foot down and got some resolution. They have three guidance counselors for approximately 1,500 students, with one counselor assigned to 1000. The counselor has no outside line. If you leave a message the counselor is unable to return your call. The counselor is the point of contact for mediations, so this is most inconvenient for us parents."

A teacher writes to respond to a parent's complaint about the school being unwelcoming: "I have always had an open door policy with my parents and have invited and welcomed them into my classroom whenever they have wanted to join us. I have given out my telephone number to them so that they may call me any hour of the day or night with any questions or concerns they may have. I have stayed well after the end of the school day to meet with parents who are not able to meet with me during the day. I have met with parents early in the morning as well. I have met with parents on Saturdays! A large number of my colleagues go that extra mile as well. ... The security measures we have in our school are not designed and implemented to make any parent feel unwelcome; they are in place to make sure that our students are safe."

A mother says parent involvement is low because school staff discourage parents from being in the school. "They are not welcoming." However, she adds that the parent coordinator is an exception and does a lot to get parents more involved.

According to a New York Times article, a "$2.5 million annex built by the developer, Ron Hershco, at his company's expense... opened on Sept. 8, the first day of school, and houses nearly 200 students." The annex will help alleviate overcrowding at the school, as new housing sprouts up across the Rockaways.

A parent writes: "This school is great. ... Teachres are easy going [and] most of them will offer extra help. Students are well behaved." She adds that "the lunch is a little bit bad" but "they sell chips and soda so the kids can go get that instead."

My son attended this school for less than one year and I had to remove him because the school was too large to function well for students in the elementary level," a parent writes. "The older children eat lunch with the younger children and often pick on them or beat them up at lunch time. Discipline was a huge problem in the school and I found the children disruptive and rude whenever I sat in on classes."
Third-grade scientists at PS 45 found that Groundhog Chuck was wrong this year when he predicted an early spring, the Staten Island Advance reports..

well i went to that school since 4th grade since i moved to Africa. now i am i 7th grade. to be honest that is the best school ever. i got a 3.11 on my state test for 6th grade and it all because of my teachers mrs.vailes, mrs.Brennan,and Mr.Tantillo. they have all been abudanly coardial to me. i just want to thank them because now i am in an honors class at my middle school. thak you to mrs.severin, mrs.kerrison, and all other staff members

Students from PS 45 visited with Mayor de Blasio and First Lady Chirlane McCray at Gracie Mansion. The students ate lunch, got a tour of the residence, and participated in a black history month program. Watch a short video from their visit here.

This is the most unstructured and unsecure school I have ever seen. The security is either on the phone, down the hall or even sometimes sleeping!  Dismissal is a mess. There is no set routine and half the time they fail to have the sign out sheets ready and everyone is stuck waiting. The teachers leave before their whole class has been signed out, and whoever is left to care for the children couldn't even if they wanted to because they allow the older children to be running around screaming and fighting. This year my childs teacher is absence 80% of the time so the class is split up amongst others, including higher grades, instead of calling in a substitute and leaving the class where they should be. It only confuses the children. The teacher should be on a leave of absence instead of missing so much. Lunch time is a nightmare. Sometimes my child comes home and says he couldn't even eat. Another had a sweater thrown around like it were a rag and completely ruined. Not to mention that there are kids who need special attention that aren't getting, poking other kids with pencils is no joke but the principal thought it wasn't anything to worry about. Bullying is a crime, not a game. This school has no idea on the laws and standards of NYS and it makes me sick, i pulled my child out of that school right away.

We love PS45. our kids learn so much there. There are a lot of things for kids to be involved with. The school has  so many activities for the kids it's great. You can tell that Mrs. Severin really cares about the kids. The school has guitar,music,art, and dancing. Recently we went to go see Niki Minaj at the school. It was such a nice event, we got a free turkey and got to hang out with a star.

I have two kids enrolled at PS45 and I am in school studying to be a teacher. This is a very good school.  The students at PS45 out perform neighboring schools. You should check the doe school statistics to see for yourself. My kids are involved in extracurricular activities and  their grades and test scores have gone up these past two years. I feel that they are being prepared for success because they love learning. I think that principal is doing a great job and you can tell that she cares about the kids and their future.

The school is nice and clean but that's it.  The kids stay in their classes all day.  There's no school spirit or activities for these kids to partake in during the school day.  They have 2 performance throughout the year.  But with a huge auditorium at their disposal, you would think other things would be celebrated.  Some of the teachers are disconnected from their students.  The principal says the kids are preparing for college but nothing that leads me to believe this.  Children are expected to sit at their desk and learn from the teacher all day until it's time to go home.  You'd be better off taking your child to a neighboring school that has programs and activities to nurture kids abilities and talents.

My daughter is in sixth grade and has been there since Kindergarten.  The school has the following programs:  Ballroom Dancing, The Learning Garden,Studio in Art, a guitar program (can't think of the name of that one), a nutrition and art program  and National Dance Institute.  It also had schoolwide participation in the Scripps National Spelling Bee.
"They've added great new things -- the after-school programs. The parent workshops are also good, to help your child with math, for example," says Edwidge Duval, mother of a 3rd grader.
"My daughter, if she were in another school, she wouldn't be where she is now," says Sophia King, the mother of 1st and 3rd graders. "The teachers are great. They talk to you."
A second-grader at PS 47 is fighting back against the end of a dedicated art period, organizing a petition to protest the termination, the Daily News reports.
PS 47 recently opened its new playground, was developed with the help of the New York Trust for Public Land and the city, as part of the mayor's PlaNYC initiative, NY1 reports.
"awesome school. Wish they had a high school attached to it. Kids learn alot and get the individual attention they need. All the students from all the grades know each other."

"The school is small enough to give each child the individual help they need," writes a parent. "Not to mention the school goes from Pre-K to8th grade. The students all know each other through each grade because there is only one class for each grade."
"I love this school despite the fact that it is very small. I am one of few black students attending this school, but I have never felt discouraged," writes Shantinique Ramsey, a 7th grade student.

A parent said, "We're lucky it's a small school," and noted that one of her nieces transferred to PS 47 from a Catholic school because she needed extra help that the parochial school had failed to give her. "She got the help here," the parent added.

M.S. 53 is on a list of 50 schools that will participate in the DOE's Bronx Plan, which will boost salaries in hard-to-staff positions and "give teachers formal decision-making power in their schools" according to Chalkbeat.
The UFT Website reports that MS 53 will remain open after being slated for closure earlier in the year.
Grow to Learn and the NYC Food Policy Center honor M.S. 53 for its Garden of Cultures and its commitment to student engagement as NYC Food Policy reports.
Principal Shawn Rux was nominated for a 2016 hometown hero in education award by the Daily News for his work in transforming the culture and improving academics at MS 53. Read more here
An afterschool worker at MS 53 has been fired after refereeing a fight between two students, which was filmed and posted on Facebook. Read more here.
A Success Academy elementary school will open in the building with MS 53 and Village Academy Middle School. Read more here.

The MS 53 school environment has provided me tremendous opportunities to grow as an educator and as a humanbeing. The atmosphere allows me to make effective connections with my students and the entire school community in order to create an environment that allows for the well rounded development of all students. I not only see the work being done, but i feel it. I feel the level of confidence in our children rising, the level of care from teachers and staff is consistently increasing and it shows. The only element that we tirelessy try to encourage and enforce is parent involvement. We need that consistent reinforcement at home. We need to bridge that gap by building trust. We can only build sustainable trust by sharing ambitions, goals and expectations for our children.
Since Shawn Rux became principal of MS 53 test scores and attendance have improved while violent incidents and suspensions have dropped. Read more and hear the story here.

Ninety-four low-performing schools are now called “Renewal Schools,”. They will receive increased funds designated for an hour of additional learning time, after-school and summer programs, and teacher training. The principals will also be under review. Read more here.

In 2010 MS 53, was also considered one of the city's most dangerous, with 280 suspensions and 188 reported violent incidents. But three years down the line, Rux has managed to quell violent behavior, reduce the amount of suspensions at a faster rate than any other middle school in the city and innovate an incentive system called “Rux Bucks” to help boost student attendance above 90 percent. Read more here.

Principal Claude Monereau said that special education students "create a lot the [discipline] problems in the school. The problem is that even though we offer them the best services we can, some cannot sit still for a very long time. We try to keep them in the classrooms, but some of them decide not to report to class." To address this problem, Monereau said that he came up with a practice called "sweeping" in the last week of May 2005. From 4th to 8th period, he and other administrators "sweep" through the hallways 10 minutes after each period begins. Wandering students get a letter home to parents after being caught the first time. The 2nd time, they get a letter and phone call home. After being caught the 3rd time, they get a detention. If they don't show up for the detention, they get suspended."

"You see more kids with hall passes," says an 8th grade girl. "You don't see as many kids cutting [class] and in the hallways."

"It's a very nice school," says an 8th grade mother. "But you have some troubled kids: They're very disrespectful. The security is very good. The teachers are very good. Not all of them are nice, but there are a few nice teachers."

"I live in this neighborhood," a teacher says. "It's gotten a lot safer here [at school], and it's a lot cleaner. A lot of people in the neighborhood are very pleased with improvements that have been made."

"Piccolo was a very good school, each student was treated with great respect and the teachers were well trained and experienced," writes a former student. "Like all school there were the few "problem kids" but due to the excellent security staff and professional teachers [they] were kept in control and students like myself who were there to gain a proper education were able to meet graduation requirements and graduated on time."

"Many of the teachers and students are wonderful at MS 53," writes a teacher. "In response to a parent who feels that there should be more black teachers, I believe that there are many white teachers who absolutely love their students. I am one of them. I don't believe that placing black teachers in the school will change anything; however, I believe that more parent involvement will. Of the 32 children I taught last year, 8 parents came to school for parent-teacher conferences. I am always so anxious to meet my students' parents, and each year I experience the same disappointing turnout. Parent-teacher conferences are a wonderful way for me to communicate, share, and learn important aspects of the children I spend 6 hours a day, 5 days a week with. These conferences take place twice a year. So parents, please make the time. It is one of the best ways for you to share in your child's academic life, and learn how your child socializes and behaves outside of your presence."

"I love this school," says a 4th grade teacher. "It's small, with a close-knit staff and good kids. Our strength is definitely academics, and kids learn to be kind to each other and to develop good moral character. But there's lots of micromanaging by the city right now. The city isn't giving teachers a chance to use what they know -- I'd like to see less of that."

"Mrs. Leiter is wonderful," says the math coach, referring to Principal Ann Leiter. "She's an educator and a leader. Students are her primary interest. The school is headed in the right direction: It has high standards and a great staff. But we could use more money [from the city]. And Mrs. Leiter's parent component [Saturday field trips] is fabulous."

"One of our greatest assets is the involvement of the administration," says the literacy coach. "They know every child by name and how each one is doing. It's a safe, nurturing atmosphere. Kids look forward to coming here. We're dealing not just with their academic growth, but with their emotional growth as well. We don't have a library. It would be wonderful if teachers and students could go to the library, but we don't have the space or the funds. So we have tried to fill up classes with books." She adds that the school has lost funding in recent years because of diminished enrollment.

Abdul, a former student, writes: "This is a good school, [but] what I didn't like about it is that ... we didn't have any field days from 3rd grade to 5th grade." He adds: "The teachers are great and you can't go wrong with this school. You barely get into any fights in this school and the children here are still innocent."  

The principal responds [to the above comment] that field day is only for 5th graders. "We don't have the facilities to have it for the whole school, so we have to walk our children over to Forest Park [a nearby public park]," said Principal Ann Leiter. "Because of the logistics, we can only take one grade, so we take the exiting [graduating] class."

PS 60 had the highest scores on improving education for black and Latino boys on the progress report. Read more: Number of NYC public schools hit with failing grades on city's annual school report cards doubles.
PS 60 first opened its doors to students on April 1, 1966.

My daughter has attended this school since kindergarden.  It has been nothing but upsetting to me.  They constantly tell you the wrong information and are many times nasty about it.  I have called the school to ask questions and again snippy attitudes.  They promise the kids certain things and do not follow through.  One year I had to change my daughters class because the teacher was a Drill seargent.

Principal Frank Desario received a 2011 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor an aspiring principal while continuing to serve as principal at their school.
It is upsetting that Teachers College would choose this principal to mentor others.  The principal has a dictatorial approach to running a school which hurts the school spirit and staff moral.

"All facets of the school including secretarial, custodial, kitchen staff and teaching staff have been wonderful to my children and myself," writes a parent. "The parent coordinator works very hard and knows almost all the students by name, which is a big task in such a large school. The assistant principal, Ms. Marino, has been extremely kind, professional and informative about my child's education."

"In the past three years the school staff has become greatly divided due to the high level of unprofessional behavior from the administration," writes a teacher. "The teachers have become untrustworthy of one another and unhappy, leading to many highly qualified teachers leaving to work in other schools."
A teacher writes that "morale of many of the PS 60 school teachers is dropping significantly" as a result of micromanagement by the administration.
"My son loves it here," said a 2nd grade mother. "Things have changed a lot since the new principal came in September. I'm happy."
"This school's strength is its structure and community," said a 2nd grade mother. "Parents have a say this year. That's important in a school this size."
"We want to change the classrooms," said Mia Velez, 5th grader and president of student government. "We want new desks; a lot of kids write on the desks. And we want new textbooks."

"I would take teaching in city schools over teaching in suburban schools," said a 3rd grade teacher. "The students are more appreciative. He [Principal Desario] is a lot more interested in the staff and in the students. He's more interested in people than in the system."
"He [Desario] makes you want to work hard for him," said a 3rd grade teacher. "I know that I'm putting in more effort than other teachers at other schools."
"I have a great staff," Desario said. "When you take good ideas and surround yourself with good people, good things happen."
"Of the teachers who left before this year, some retired," said a 3rd grade teacher. "Others moved to other districts or Long Island for more money."

"The new [city-mandated] program is more rigid," said the school math facilitator. "It's good for new teachers. It's hard to get used to for older teachers. But it works well when you see it from grade to grade."

"The new [city-mandated] program is more rigid," said the school math facilitator. "It's good for new teachers. It's hard to get used to for older teachers. But it works well when you see it from grade to grade."

PS 62 was part of a pilot program to introduce the Common Core standards. See this video (after the section about PS 124) to see how teachers help children who are learning English. https://www.teachingchannel.org/videos/common-core-state-standards-elementary-school

Principal Angela O'Dowd praised "the student population. We have very few discipline problems. They're a joy to work with. And the families are very traditional; they have great respect for school and for teachers."
"I like the challenge of change and building continuity," says Assistant Principal Mary Flanagan, who's been at PS 62 since the early 1990s.
Regina, a student, writes: "[PS 62 is] a good school. The new principal is nice and cool."

PS 63 students have participated in several events this year including creating a sculpture that will be displayed at the 1028 Queens Boro Arts Festival, winning the Queens Borough award in the annual Jack Ezra Keats bookmaking contest, and putting on a performance of the musical "The Lion King" The Queens Chronicle reports.

PS 63 5th graders visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art then used the techniques they observed to create their own works, many of which were then displayed at the Queens South Borough Office. Read more here.
The "amiable principal, Deidra Graulich has retired.  Unfortunately, many now seem "harried and unhappy"!
Kindergarten teacher Karen Senita was a NYC Teaching Fellows Award for Classroom Excellence finalist, Chancellor Klein announced.
For the 2006-07 school year, PS 63 is newly identified by the State Education Department as "in good standing."

A parent of a special needs child complains that the school segregates special education students. "Many schools have long introduced inclusion for all students. PS 63 has not." This parent calls the special education classes "prehistoric" and an "academic wasteland."

Principal Deidra Graulich responds: "Our special education students come from all over the city. We offer a wide range of services ranging from consultant teacher, SETTS, 12:1 classes and 12:1:1 classes. Our students have many related services onsite such as speech, occupational therapy, physical therapy and adaptive physical education. Our students are well integrated into the general population through mainstreaming in academics as well as non-academic settings, such as assemblies, physical education, trips and lunch."

The parent of twins, one in a special education class, says PS 63 is "phenomenal". "When we first came here it took of us to get him up the stairs [he was so reluctant to come] but he's adjusted so well. As far as I'm concerned this school is phenomenal." She added: "all the teachers are great. I haven't had a problem with one teacher here."

"The parent involvement is amazing," said a 2nd grade teacher, who also said the principal "brings so much material for the kids."
Stephanie, a former student, writes that she loved the school and her teachers, especially Ms. Flood.

Karla, a former student who attended the school from 1st to 5th grade, writes: "I loved it there. Great teachers, a great PTA, and good gym teachers. All I can say [is] that I spent the most wonderful years in that school"

"PS 63 is a great school!" writes Daphne P., a recent graduate. "The school is academically stable, there is a section for Special Education, and you get to know all your teachers easily, because the school is small. But, being a small school, that is part of the downside, because the teachers and students don't have that much room." She writes, "It is also a Magnet school for the Arts, and some painting have been displayed at JFK airport. For about two years (or more) they have been hiring traffic enforcers, for students. Again, it is a great school that would get excellent remarks if it were to be reviewed."

"The school is fine, and the teachers are good," said a 1st grade parent. She added, however, that work given to her child is sometimes too difficult or advanced, although she does not blame PS 64 for that. "They ask 1st graders to do 3rd- and 4th-grade-level work. The children don't get a chance to be kids. But that's not the school's fault. It's the [city-mandated] new curriculum."

"My daughter loves it here," said a 5th grade parent. "She likes everything about the school. And it's improving: They've installed new [outer] windows, and there are smaller class sizes. My daughter gets enough homework to keep her busy, as much as a 5th grader should get. In 1994, I had an opportunity to move, but I stayed in this neighborhood, because I wanted her to attend this school."
"These kids really get along with each other, and it's a diverse population," said a teacher. "We're like the United Nations."

PS 65 will be joining the DOE’s PROSE program, which gives participating schools more freedom to make changes to their school day, class structure, among others, aimed at boosting achievement and providing more opportunities for students. Read more here.

do not go to this school. You HAVE TO GET SENIOR POINTS TO GRADUATE AND GO TO RAY DAY which is unfair and you have to pay the fee too. whats wrong with this school. the gym is the auditiorium the kids have to sit on the floor

PS 65 The Raymond York Elementary School has been selected to showcase family and community engagement in the inaugural year of Chancellor Carmen Fariña’s Showcase Schools Program. The initiative is designed to promote collaboration and sharing of strong practices. Schools that excel in a specific learning focus area will host educators from other schools to share their successful structures and strategies. Read more here.
"Each year this school gets better," a parent said. "It never goes back."

Principal Beth Longo said, "Success for All is not a remediation program. It's an acceleration program that does everything to move along children quickly on a continuum. It allows us to give the higher performing students what they need."
A parent writes: "The corridors and classrooms are immaculate, and you sense the true commitment to learning that exists here. A cut above your average public school."
A parent complains of "inexperienced staff."

PS 66 was one of six NYC schools to receive the 2013 Blue Ribbon Award from the United States Department of Education. The Blue Ribbon schools are recognized for their academic excellence and their success in preparing students for college and careers. Read more here.

"PS 66 is a great school for children who are 'gifted and talented' but it is not a good school for children who have learning disabilities," writes a parent. "The staff is trained to deal with children who are at their best at all times. I feel there are different ways to deal with children who have special needs rather than calling the parents every other day. PS 66 is considered a 'good' school because all the children do is prepare for the ELA exam. They walk, talk, and breathe ELA. Everyone is focused on staying on top rather than on addressing the needs of the many different children."  
Principal Phyllis Leinwand responds to the comment above: "PS 66 is dedicated to the commitment that all children can meet and/or exceed the standards. We differentiate instruction to adapt to the needs of all learners. We are proud to have 'parents as partners' in their children's education and consider this to be an integral part of each child's success."

"As an instructional leader, I'm only as good as the people working with me," says principal Phyllis Leinwand. To build the strongest possible team, "I try to pull their strengths out and spark them."
"There's an intimacy in this small building that you can't buy for a million bucks," says literacy coach Stacy Mizrahi.

One 1st grader said he liked this school better than his old school. "When I'm sick I can't go to school," he said, "and I really want to go." He and his tablemates all agreed that they wanted to be teachers when they grew up.

A teacher who has worked at PS 66 since 1992 writes, "I am very proud of being an integral part of such a wonderful school." She says the school received landmark status after the building was restored, and was renamed the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School. At that time, "Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg visited our school and visited many of the classrooms. My class created a book called Young Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and it will be placed in the archives of the JFK Library. We are all very proud."

Some good teachers with good intentions. But there is another handful of teachers who are not culturally aware, do not relate to the community, the principal does not accommodate parents. Teachers go around giving 1’s on report card because it’s the first marking period not based on rubrics or student performance. Really disappointed because its the only option because of the whole zoned non-sense.
This year the theme of PS 90's annual literacy night was "Feeling Groovy about Reading!". The school was featured in Queens Chronicle's "School Spolight".
that tecaher miss logan a all teachers was good

The public should know that this school may or may not still have a bedbug problem since September 2010. They barely did anything about it and it caused a child to lose services due to the bedbugs coming to the child's home. The child's parents lost furniture, clothing and family members stop coming to the house. P.S.90 has not apologize or compensated the child's family for so much lost that originated from their school. BEWARE of sending your child to this school because they will barely admit they have a problem.

I disagree with your opinion.  The Principal and Staff of PS90 take every precaution when it comes to any situation, by sending out notices and raising it at PTA meetings.  When the issue of bedbugs was raised, a notice went out to the parents immediately where they were informed what precautions to take in the event a bedbug is found and materials to educate everyone on bedbugs.  Note, bedbugs do not survive in a school environment.  They are carried in from the outside, where they thrive in a day-to-day environment such as a bed, furniture with material or warm residences.  PS90 does not have to apologize or compensate any losses faced, since they are not the responsible party.  Everyone should look at how they take care of their homes or where they put their bags down. If parents do not attend the meetings, read the materials sent home or ask questions, they won't know what's going on and are going on misinformed assumptions.

The New York Times reported the successful win of some city public schools in Chess Tournament in Florida. Horace Mann School, won the fourth and fifth grade championships but unfortunately lost the tie-breaker with I.S. 318
Horace Mann School is a private independent school.

Emilin, a former student who attended the school from kindergarten to 5th grade, writes: "It was a wonderful learning experience. The school had a welcoming feeling. There were murals in the main entrance and first floor. It truly was a home away from home!!!"

Parent Carlette Merill, whose son is one of the visually impaired students in the school, writes: "I love PS 90. His self confidence has gone up 110%. The teachers (classroom, vision, PTA, and principal) all are very helpful, sincere and positive role models." She writes that her son "enjoys homework, wearing his uniforms, and reading and that she considers the school a "blessing." She adds: "I hope they get the funds to repair all that needs to be completed. Keep up the good work!!!"
"My daughter does homework every day when she comes home," said a kindergarten parent. "She works on the alphabet and on numbers. She knows what to do, because the teacher explains it all."

"I'm very satisfied, because my daughter likes it here," said a kindergarten parent. "She likes her teacher and the principal. She gets homework every night: She makes calendars, and I read to her. Her teacher tells her to find a story and write what she likes about it."

"It's a safe school," said a 4th grade parent. "Everybody wears uniforms. I like that. I think it's important. In other schools, you see girls wear things that are too short [revealing]. This is more like a private school."
"It has good teachers and a good principal, "said a 1st grade parent.
"There need to be crosswalks at the corners by the school," said a parent. "Other schools have crosswalks that say 'School Crossing.' We don't."
"I love teaching kindergarten most," said a teacher. "Some know the alphabet. Many can read and write by the end of the year. It's a challenge, getting them to read and write."

"In the beginning, they come with very little knowledge of letters," said another kindergarten teacher. "At the end of the year, they are reading and writing. Two or three kids don't speak English at home. Most get help with homework at home."
PS 96 is rallying to have funding for its after-school program extended. Read more here.
Last week at PS 96, students celebrated their second annual "poetry jam." Read more here.
were do i find the school supplies

"My son likes it here, because his classmates are from the neighborhood," said the mother of a kindergarten son and pre-K daughter. "They [my son and his classmates] do a lot together in and out of class. My daughter couldn't wait to be here, because of what she'd heard from her brother. She loves her teachers. As a parent, I like the smaller classes (number of students). I'd like to see more parents helping teachers. It helps kids be more proud when their parents are helping."
"A lot of our parents work," said the parent coordinator. "They volunteer when they can. I have seen an increase in attendance at PTA meetings."

"With smaller classes, there's more hands-on," said the physical education and health teacher. "There's more one-on-one with the instructor. We can do more in the classroom. A lot of phys ed teachers work with 40 or 50 students at a time. I have 15 in my classes. With the limited funds we have, each child gets a baseball glove, a basketball. I have all of the supplies I need; it's a matter of saving it for as long as possible."

"Some children are not getting as much support at home as they should be getting," said a teacher. "Some have disabilities. I would like to see more parent involvement. I would like to see parents and teachers working on a project. We were getting a lot of Carleton House [a home for displaced families] kids two years ago, but it's more spread around now."
"Kindergarten isn't what it used to be," said a kindergarten teacher. "There used to be dramatic play. Now it's all reading, writing. They have to know more."
The Queens Chronicle highlights PS 97 and its efforts to bring cultural awareness to the school community.

Principal Grady, whose house was destroyed by Hurricane Sandy, tells DNAinfo how she has worked to help her school recover after the storm. Read more here.

"Our school is well-stocked," said one teacher. "Every year we give a list of what we need in supplies and we get it from the school. We don't have lessons disrupted because a child's only pencil is broken."
The Reebok foundation is bringing its physical activity program, BOKS to P.S. 105 as part of an expansion of physical activity options for elementary school children. Read more here.

The former principal of PS 106 Marcella Sills is suing the city for her job back, claiming her contract did not state what time she needed to get to work each day, and therefore lateness could not justify her removal. The New York Post reports.
The New York Post reports that this appeal was filed months after the legal deadline.
The new principal at PS 106 has been criticized for firing the whistleblower who prompted the firing of the last principal and for letting students run wild. Read more here.

Chancellor Fariña visited PS 106 in her 70 school tour. PS 106 was One of the few troubled schools she visited, dubbed the “School of No” by the New York Post because of reports that its principal had neglected it for years. Read more here.

Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña met with 30 teachers and paraprofessionals from PS 106 to discuss the transition since Marcella Sills has been removed as principal. Read more here.
Some parents were surprised to learn that Principal Sills had been fired when students returned to PS 106 after mid-winter break. Read more here.

After a two-month investigation of Principal Sills' attendance record, investigators are recommending that Chancellor Carmen Fariña terminate Sills’ employment at PS 106 and bar her from working again in the city school system. "The teachers make you feel at home and everyone cares about you," writes student Clereshae.

"It's a small, intimate school," said a teacher. "I just wish that we had a real gym, auditorium, and cafeteria. They keep sending us little units, instead of using the vacant lots [around the school] to build something permanent."

"It's a small school, so everyone knows everyone else real well, the staff and the children," said a guidance counselor. "But we're getting tight on space. The art and science teachers will lose their rooms. I don't think the art teacher should have to travel around with paper and crayons on a cart."

"Both of my children have been here since they were in kindergarten," said the mother of a 1st grader and 4th grader. "The school is very pleasant, very worthwhile, and they learn a lot. My 4th grader gets a lot of homework."

"I like the school," said a parent whose three children attend PS 106. "I have two kids in the gifted program, and they are doing well. It's a small school, and the teachers are concerned. They teach well."
"I've been here since 1981," said a kindergarten teacher's assistant. "They get a great education here. I've been in others, but this is the best."
"I drive one and a half hours to get here," said a paraprofessional. "My husband wants me to transfer to a school closer to our home, but I stay here because I like it."
"It's a small school, but we're very lucky with materials," said a literacy teacher. "We have a lot of textbooks. And there are very few disciplinary incidents."

I went to this school 11 years ago. I have really great memories of it because most of my teachers were nice and they inspired me to become a teacher! I went back to this school about a year ago for fieldwork and I was impressed at how well behaved most of the students were. I have observed in classrooms in over ten schools and this one is probably the best. Most of the teachers here are very enthusiastic about teaching and they try to help every child. The staff is very organized, the school is clean, and the resources are up to date. I really like that this school provides a safe environment for students. I hope that I can teach here one day!

Please update your information.. As a parent in the school, I can tell you that the school has had a gifted and talented program since 2007, producing excellent results. They really do try to cater to each individual student's need - whether it be a need for gifted and talented enrichment or a need for special education. As a parent with a child in each of these categories, I have been satisfied with the attention they have been given. The school is very parent friendly. There are plenty of Learning Leader parent volunteers who work with a truly caring parent coordinator and aide with everything from sorting papers, painting murals on the walls, a school carnival to coordinating a food-drive for Sandy Relief and volunteering sorting clothes with NYPD community affairs and assisting Volunteer Cooking Teams for Sandy at the Aqueduct parking lot. Parent workshops abound, including a successful GED program which has helped parents get their H.S. diploma and enter into the work force. The principal is very hands on has high standards for the teachers and staff and is consistently trying to improve technology at the school, including installation of smart boards in various classrooms.
Thanks for your thoughtful comment! As you see, we have updated the information. Please continue to send us information.

"Many teachers feel that the school prevents creative freedom in the classroom, because many of the grades are required to stick with uniform units with little room for individuality," writes a teacher. "Children begin test prep in the first grade and are expected to write more than they can handle. Social development is at stake. Most kids cannot go outside for recess or free play each day. "I'm amazed at the things they learn here," says a parent.
"There's a safe environment here," says a parent.
"I think they should have more physical education and more music," a parent says. "Because of the size of the school, it's difficult to get it for all the kids."

A student writes that the school is "great" and that the only problem is that it's too hot inside.

Good news reached PS 114 when they were informed none of their teachers would be excessed this year: Good News from the PS/MS 114 The Belle Harbor School PTA! .

PS/IS 114 reopened on Nov. 26, three days earlier than planned after having been shuttered for several weeks due to storm damage from Hurricane Sandy. Parents continue to be concerned about air quality at the school. While the school was closed, students were reassigned to three different schools. "Parents are very interested in education" in the community, an administrator said. "The community is into helping others," she said, doing such things as sending supplies to the troops in Iraq.

"They have good programs here," said a parent whose 5th grade student transferred in under the federal No Child Left Behind law, which allows children to leave certain failing schools. "The PTA is active." Her daughter is one of a small number of black children in the school, but she said she felt welcome there.

Caroline, a former student, writes: "I love PS 114, one of the hardest things I have ever had to do was leave. You make such great friends that last a lifetime. I am now in the 7th grade at Bay Academy, and I pass by PS 114 everyday, and I miss it."

"I love PS 114," writes Caroline R., who graduated last year and now attends Bay Academy in Brooklyn. "I came to this school in second grade and everyone was so nice to me, the teachers the students, everyone! One thing I remembered I didn't like about the fifth grade was that we had a lot of principals and assistant principals, but I still love PS 114!"

"PS 114 is truly a unique school," writes the parent of two recent graduates. "The staff, being mostly from the neighborhood, treats their classroom students as they would their own. It should be a model for all elementary schools."

Fifty-two registered sex offenders living in a homeless shelter less than 1,000 feet from PS/IS 124 should have been removed in July, says City Councilman Ruben Wills. Read more here.
Children should be safe at school. The administration has to deal with bullying properly. Don't hide the truth. Bullying could affect children's future seriously.

There are certain parameters that must be met when using the term bullying, so I will refrain from using it lightly.  However, what is most disturbing with this school's administration is the lack of direct and immediate action to appropriately handle incidents that are brought to their attention.  In fact, it is clear that the manner in which numerous parental concerns have been handled involving unsafe conditions, physical confrontation and injury is unacceptable.  Many schools take these matters VERY seriously and have little to no tolerance for acts of malice, horse playing and especially bullying.  Actually, there are times when the punitive consequences are delivered to heavily, as I have personally experienced with my own children and former students who I taught in private schools.  I do not favor one extreme over the other.  However, I do expect strict rules with contingency plans in place.  I expect swift response time/notifications and thorough investigations that will satisfactorily address the concerns of parents who entrust this institution with the care of their child.  I also expect proactive measures to ENFORCE a no tolerance policy for any unsafe condition.  These are basic, imperative necessities a school should and must provide.  Hopefully, the voices here are heard and action will be taken to address and reverse the negative reputation gained due to the inability to embody simple communication and protocol.  This alone would help to alleviate emotionally compromising situations for all parties involved; especially when it comes to the safety of children.        .

I've heard of multiple bulling issues taking place at this school and incidents like these would not be taken lightly at the school I attend, The Scholars' Academy, in which the assistant principal at PS 124 has referred to. As a sophomore at this school, this sort of behavior would never be tolerated. The administration would have acted upon it as soon as the issue had came about. All procedures would have been followed and all actions necessary would have been taken place. Bullying should not be taken lightly, especially when it is happening with little kids. They need to know that these actions are serious which can lead to very bad damage and that there are consequences. 

As a school, your number one priority should be the children. If the children are not safe, is your school a safe school?

Outraged! At the fact that Bullying is still going on! The lack of supervision is evident! It doesn't take a professor to figure out what needs to be done to cease, intervene, and prevent this type of abuse. So now that the elephant is out the bag, I want to know what PS 124, along with The Board of Education is going to do to end physical and verbal abuse to our children, who we as parents have entrusted you with the most valuable gift anyone can receive, our children? I want to know how long is it going to take to realize your lack of action is only awakening a giant. Who is going to accept the responsibilities that come with "proper" supervision? Who is going to take accountability for these matters that continue to exist. Ms. Jones? Ms. Lapsley? How can we even fathom the fact that they are in a building designed to house half of the amount of students, and the number continues to grow? Are we serious here? I can go on in regards to the poor excuse of the administrations direction and decision making. But in staying focus on a matter that should've ceased decades ago, in moving forward, how can we get more eyes on our children? Whatever it may take, allocate a budget to hire more assistance, request volunteer work from parents to simply watch children, not only in the school, but at least a 5 block perimeter around the school. Every child matters, every child should make it home unarmed! #childrenovereverything
this is horrible!!! how can a child's head be slammed into a table, his teeth broken, and this be labeled as "kids being kids and playing games"????this is totally not acceptable!!!!
call 311 and make complaints against administration so that they can be accountable for their actions.
Peace. I have. It's deeply disturbing that our children's safety is not a #1 priority.

It sickens me when the bullying reaches the point, where the bully hits away my child lunch tray , when she tried reporting it to the principal, she just made the bully say sorry to my child, however lo and behold in front of me while dropping off my child the bully called her deragotory words ..

Peace Anju. I'm sorry to hear about your child's bullying incident. Please send me your contact information. The more parents are aligned in a unified front to demand safety for our children,  the more the administration must listen. There is strength in numbers. Be sure to file a formal complaint and demand a copy of the report EACH time your daughter is bullied. If nothing is done, file a compliant with the superintendent's office. If they dismiss you, go to the Chancellor. If nothing happens there, reach out to the Mayor and Governor. I'll help you if you need assistance.

There seems to be a pervasive issue in regards to bullying at this school. There have been several incidents over the course of the year, and the administration's response seems muted and indifferent. If this is to be the approach to dealing with the issue, we should expect to see more such incidents in the future. The safety of our children should not be a subject taken lightly; we should take this opportunity to be proactive, and not sit passively on our hands until the issue shows up on our doorsteps.
Everyone says that they don't tolerate bullies-but if it makes the school look bad, they will hide the issue.

As a concerned  community member and Parent Bullying should be taken seriously and should be addressed. A child should feel safe being at school ,And a parent shouldn`t have to worry about their child while at work. Administrators and teachers must ensure horseplaying ,bullying or whatever you want to call it is not accepted and is dealt with accordingly. This school has had several cases of bullying and its Principal has constantly swept these incidences under the rug. The school superintendent and Chancellor have to take this school administrators to task and see why every situation is a case of just horseplaying. Let`s get to the real problem and stop looking at parents and children of these occurences as complainers and not victims.

Peace to Everyone......Indeed......As a parent......We should never feel like....we are not being taken seriously......That are feelings about our children are not...... validated and shown respect.....The parent should feel like they are part of the community.....a valued member....... along with that child.....and when something goes wrong....that this institution is carefully making sure that something is done about the event......Support those parents and teach Peace .....

I have to echo recent comments by concerned parents and community members regarding recent bullying issues at the school. While surely not all incidents can be prevented, providing proper supervision is key to minimizing such instances, and if they do happen and a child is seriously injured the administration must provide proper recourse and support for the parents and child as well as take disciplinary measures to send a clear signal that such behavior won't be tolerated and carry consequences, otherwise it is bound to happen over and over.

Bullying is a serious problem plaguing our schools today. As parents we are asked to put our faith and trust in the fact our children will be kept safe while there. Once that trust is broken the whole educational process also is broken. I think the school administrators need to take a greater level of accountability in properly handling this serious issue of bullying. If they do not, then they should be replaced with people who will, because our kids lives depend on it. No child can reach their full potential while living in constant fear for their safety at the same time.

I have some concerns about the way this school has handled multiple cases of children being injured and children being bullied. I have friends and family with kids and siblings that go to this school and it really worries me and upsets me that better action and precautions are not being taken.

It has to be terrifying for a parent to have their children in a school where they have to be concerned about their safety.  We know that bad things happen and that there are bullies, but the least a parent should be able to expect from their child's school is that when such incidents happen, that they are dealt with appropriately so as to properly care for any children injured and prevent further incidents.  And, in such incidents, if a parent is upset and showing concern for their child, rightfully so!  This should not be ignored or pushed aside. 

It’s evident that the school is overcrowded and understaffed.  But when we are responsible for the children in our community, then we need to step up and ensure that their safety is primary.  There needs to be some type of resolution, and the school could stand to use some input from the community.  I would feel much better if the school at least welcomed input and collaboration from the community, as opposed to shutting the community out, in particular the parents.

It's unfortunate that children from my community including my niece have to attend a school that is understaffed and simply ignores acts of bullying. No proper reports are made but rather simply referred as "accidents". It's terrifying knowing I have to send my niece to a school where anything that happens can be called an accident when in reality it may be bullying. The physical trauma as well as the mental trauma that children who experience bullying, is unacceptable. The staff needs proper training or education to prevent such events, the staff also needs to learn to handle these situations the right way.

The administration of P.S. 124Q is disgraceful, disrespectful, and concerning. As a community member with nieces and nephews who attend this institution, I am highly concerned for the type of care, education, and accommodations our children receive when they walk into P.S. 124 five days a week. Specifically, the Assistant Principal is rude, disrespectful and unprofessional with concerned parents. The Interim-Principal at the institution demonstrates a lack of empathy when dealing with conflicts that involve bullied children, as well as children who have suffered permanent physical injuries as a result of such bullying. However, as constituents of the community we need to raise a concern of the administration of P.S.124 to those who employ such unqualified individuals such as the Assistant Principal and Interim Principal at the institution. After a further investigation, I have learned that P.S.124 also have never executed a by-laws. Rather, P.S.124 employs a "grab out of the hat" voting policy that ensures anonymity and protects it from any claims of bias or interest. It is also highly concerning that the administration at P.S.124 become so involved and interested in the conflicts of students and parents that they take sides of other parents thereby demeaning the concern and requests of a complaining parent. This comment responds from the most common bullying incident where a 7 year old boy was bullied by another. The school not only refused to write an incident report but failed to find an appropriate disposition; refused to empathize with the complaining parent, refused to accommodate the child who is suffering physical injuries; intentionally placed the victim child back into a dangerous position where he is susceptible to injuries from his bully; negligently managed lunch aides during the lunch hour [which is when the incident occurred; the lunch aide did not even know a child was being bullied]; negligently managed the nurse aides who place victims of bullying back into public areas of the school; unprofessionally involved themselves in parental conflict by yelling at a concerned parent at a meeting that was intended to be restorative in nature, but not in practice; and the school administration, specifically the Assistant Principal was negligent when she failed to fill out the necessary paperwork correctly, which she had a duty to do so, and she failed to carry out such duty. Such incompetent administration should not be tolerated. The Department of Education should investigate this matter, and all students at P.S.124 should be interviewed with respect to their experience at the school.

This whole story is outrageous and very disappointing. I am so sorry that these children and families had to endure this. There must be something that can be done-even if involves getting media attention.

I am a concerned community member and the way bullying is being addressed is unacceptable.  When a child is beaten by another child at school, it is up to the school to deal with this efficiently.  Parents leave their kids with the school believing that it is a safe and secure environment.  From what I've heard about this school, students have been assaulted and nothing's been done.  Being lax about discipline could send a message to the assaulters that it is okay and that their assaults will go unpunished.  A school is supposed to be a safe place to learn and if my child was assaulted and nothing was done I'd be exasperated.

While I'm not clear on how the law works in NYC, here in NJ something called a Harassment and Bullying (HAB) Report is filed for every claim made by a child or parent, followed by a thorough investigation with both parties. My understanding is that not only was the decision to label this "incident", as an "accident", almost instantaneous, but the handling of the matter thereafter was treated with seemingly zero compassion for both the victim and his mother. Literal insult to literal injury. I also understand the story on record indicates there was a game in place, involving hand movements. How a hand game led to a smashed face in a table resulting in permanent dental damage, becomes lessened to a mere (hands in the air) mishap, is beyond me.  How a Principal's office and Superintendent's office alike, can rehash the words "accident, accident, accident" to a mother who has to (a) come up with the funds to repair what she can of her son's teeth, (b) come up with the words to repair what she can of her son's spirit and (c) come up with patience to keep her composure while be shooed away and snickered at, is also - beyond me. 

More attention and care needs to be given to the handling of these "incidents". I hope those in the position to make changes for the better, will do so.

The bullying and the aftermath is pretty terrible. These types of incidents should NOT be tolerated or even part of the educational experience and yet this school is a prime example of what's wrong with our society. The schools lack of willingness to assist the bullying problem is terrible.

On Tuesday, June 16, 2015 during the last School Leadership Team meeting of the 2014-2015 school year, I asked the parent coordinator about the process of having a CBO (community based organization) join the SLT team at P.S. 124. She informed me that for as long as she has been at the school, no CBO’s are allowed on the team. 

	As per the Chancellor’s Regulation A-655 (Article II - Team Composition, Attachment No. 4, Section 4, pgs. 1-2), it states: “Community based organizations may also serve on SLTs. The SLT will create a process for the organizations to apply for membership. A member of the team may also recommend an organization for membership. This will be done on an annual basis. Community based organization members will be included in the total number of team members, but will not be counted when determining the balance of parent and staff members.” I asked her to please advise as to the process the SLT of P.S. 124 should have in place for CBO’s. 

	In addition, when I asked the SLT team what the process was for choosing parents to serve on the SLT this past school year, the response was that names were chosen out of a brown paper bag for those positions. When I asked if that was the customary process for choosing parents, the response was “yes.” When I asked how long the term was for parents, the current PTA president looked at the rest of the team and asked, “What are our Bylaws?” as the entire team looked perplexed. The interim principal finally interjected and said it was 1 year. When I asked what the Bylaws of P.S. 124 are in accordance with this matter, there was no response. I am unclear as to why the Bylaws of the School Leadership Team of P.S. 124 are not completed in written form.

	As per the Chancellor Regulation A-655 (Article II- Team Composition, Attachment No. 4, Section 4, pg. 1), it states: “Election of Team Members Parent and staff SLT members must be elected by their own constituent group in a fair and unbiased manner determined by each constituent group. All elections must be advertised widely, with reasonable advance notice given. Elections must be open to all members of the constituent group and must be held in accordance with the term limits set forth in these bylaws. Parent member elections must be scheduled after PA/PTA elections are held each Spring. Parents must be provided a minimum of ten calendar days notice prior to the election. The PA/PTA is encouraged to stagger the terms of the non-mandatory parent members of the SLT.”

I informed the parent coordinator that I would like to apply to be on the School Leadership Team for the coming school year of 2015-2016 and to let me know what form(s) I need to follow through with in order to begin that process.

Hi, I am in support of my good friend Mala Sookdeo on the bullying of her 1st grade son and daughter a few weeks ago. It's kind of surprising that this school or any school for that matter would let such an act take place with no disciplinary action taken to the culprit. What are we teaching are kids? ...how to hit other kids and be successful or to be productive members of society one day? ...is this even a school? ... something has to be done soon to address and correct this matter or this will be taken up on a higher level until the correct steps are taken to protect everyones kid when they are in school ...

I've heard of multiple bullying incidents taking place in this school one where a child's two front teeth were knocked out by another student at the school and no disciplinary action was taken place and the bully got away scott-free.

On 5/29/15 my 1st grade son was a victim of bullying when his head was smashed into a lunch table by one of his classmates. The child broke my son’s front, permanent teeth. The school aides should have been watching my son’s class and was not. I have been going through the proper protocol of speaking with the AP (who deals with the younger grades), the guidance counselor, and the principal to address my concerns. I requested a meeting with the child’s parents to which the principal declined to be present. The AP yelled at me during the meeting, creating a very hostile environment. The child that did this to my son was not suspended as per the Chancellor’s Regulations that addresses infractions linked to disciplinary actions. 

There was another bullying incident with my daughter 3 weeks prior when two classmates kicked and punched her in the schoolyard during recess. The school aide took a written statement from my daughter and made a copy for her to give to me. She was supposed to give her copy to the guidance counselor. She put the statement in her bag and went home. I was not notified by the school.  When I went to the school the next day to address the bullying issue, the AP was completely unaware that anything happened. She took statements from my daughter and the bullies as well as other children involved. On 6/3/15, I asked for the copy of the online report she should have filed. She told me she never filed a report because my daughter had no injuries. I responded saying that it is a bullying incident report that should have been filed. She claimed she gave the bullies 3 days of lunch detention. When I reminded her that she previously called me and told me she gave the bullies 5 days lunch detention, she then yelled at me in front of everyone in the main office and said, “‘I’m done with you! Have a nice day!”

During that same week my son was injured, another child broke his arm during recess. 

On 6/11/15 there was another incident with a 5th grader on the school bus who pulled a knife on his classmates. He threatened to kill them if they told on him. From what I understand, the child was on medication. This child should have been supervised at all times. The mother said the school did not call her about the situation. She found out from her son when he got dismissed from school. 

A parent came up to me who said a child was being bullied and had water bottles thrown at him. The administration told the mother it was her son’s fault because he made a racial comment. 

The school is excessively overcrowded and there is not enough lunch aides to handle over 1,300 children.  I am disturbed by the pattern of particularly violent children who are not being reprimanded for their physical attacks. Instead, the victims are made to feel as it is their fault that they have been targeted and attacked. 

I went to the DFA and superintendent for my district. They both said the child involved in my son’s assault will not be suspended because they did a full investigation and concluded it was an accident. They have yet to take a statement from my son. Therefore, a complete investigation was not performed. The lack of adhering to the chancellor’s protocol and the unprofessionalism the administration shows to the parents is an outrage. 

Today I went to Councilman Eric Ulrich's office to explain my son's situation and request for them to help facilitate a fair resolution. The Community Relations Advocate told me I had to go through the Department of Education and that she could only give me the chancellor's phone number and address. 

I am going to contact the Chancellor's office but it seems that going through the proper protocol gets me less results and more red tape. It's very frustrating and in the meantime my son is still in a school where bullies are not disciplined according to the Chancellor's Regulations for serious physical injuries. 

Our children are entitled to a free AND safe public education. They should not have to choose between the two.
are you reporting this to the superintendent and doe? are you filing a formal complaint?

If they don't want to acknowledge or address the issue, then you need a lawyer and a lawsuit-or a public forum where they will be exposed. You will never get justice if you go through your current process-as schools and administration are notorious for trying to hide their imperfections.

I have two children that attends this school and is very proud of every single teacher that assisted me in molding them,the principal,assistant principals,parent coordinators and everyone in charge does a fanatic job...special thank you to all the teachers of the gifted and talented classes for a job well done on my two children.

The after school program needs to be more flexible with their requirements.  For example they insist the children attend every day while other public schools allow students to attend when they need to be in after school. This school is filled with ignorant kids because they feel they are bad. I graduated from J.H.S. 226, and my perspective is this school is a clean and a high ranking school. "Teachers may be new but there are all great and the school is well organized."

"M.S. 137 is a good school," writes student Brooklyn. "The teachers are young but are some of the best teachers." This student adds that students "get to learn about other countries" and are prepared for tests. She says the only bad thing about the school is its lunch, but even there, "the pizza tastes good."

"The building is cleaner than most schools and has central AC," writes Janelle, a 2005 graduate. " What really made this place special is that you are befriended by teachers and staff. Even the teachers I didn't have and just had for a substitute, knew me and I felt like they cared about me. The layout of the school was made simple so it's really hard to get lost."
"Security isn't very good," writes student Enrique. He also says there is gang activity in the school.

Rachel, a student who attended the school for her 6th- and 7th-grade years before moving away, writes: "When I was there I enjoyed that school. I did things that I could never picture doing ... [but] when I stepped in to Ms. Brucino's room it was a piece of cake. She made it so simple to learn." She praises many of her other teaches as well, and says gym was her favorite subject since her teacher made her feel like she could "come to her for anything."

Hritik, a student, writes that although the MS 137 is "overcrowded" this year, it is located in a "multicultural community" that is "the main reason for the school's diversity." He adds that he "loves the school" and feels like part of the school community. Also, in response to a previous comment, he notes that students can now "borrow books from the library with permission of a teacher."

Rohan, a recent graduate, writes: "I thought the school was great. The teachers care for you like their own child, and they teach really good. Sometimes [there are] fights but every school has problems." He adds: "My teachers that I had were really nice and they tutor you at lunch if you don't understand the work. I am in high school right now and I was prepared in September."

A student writes: "This school is wonderful. Teachers ask you questions after class, so that they know if you understand the work. The teachers are very motivating. The staff in this school are your friends. Students are friendly." She adds: "The staff is very protective of the students but they are just doing their job. If you ever have a situation the teachers would help you and won't put your business all overt the front page of every newspaper."
A student writes: "This school is really cool, the teachers are really nice. Yeah the teachers are new, but that way not only students are learning from their mistakes teachers are too, right?"

A student claims that although the school has a library, the students "aren't allowed to take out any books. It's only for 'show.'" This student writes: "I loved the school up until 8th grade because now since the school is so overcrowded that they spilt up the senior class of 2004 during lunch! ITS TO STRICT!"
Ritika, a senior, complains: "The school is horrible ... the school lunch tastes nasty and the school is cheap. The only thing I like is Tech with Ms. Santiago."
Reginald, a student, offers reasons as to "why MS 137 is so good: "There are almost no fights nowdays. There are good teachers. They have the best library ever."

A student writes: "This school is alright. But its too overcrowded so a lot of the 8th graders are seperated during lunch. I think seniors should have at least the same lunch period. It's too strict!"

"America's Choice has a very strong writing component," said literacy coach Patricia Clark. "America's Choice scaffolds each component of it [balanced literacy] and shows how to use it. I would recommend America's Choice to the city if it really wants to get balanced literacy underway."
"I feel a lot more positive about America's Choice," said a 3rd grade teacher. "I can modify my lessons for what the kids need. I have more impact.

"Most of our coaches are very good," said a teacher. "The resource center is excellent, and I love the mayor's library. I'm happy with America's Choice, and I like the freedom of the writers' workshop model. It's a safe school -- the security guards, the doors -- and there's a lot of disciplinary follow-through."
"Their writing has gotten a lot better with America's Choice," said a 2nd grade teacher. "There are more opportunities to write in different genres: poetry, nonfiction, fiction."

"Our strength is our staff," said a 3rd grade teacher. "You can go to anyone here for help. I would like to see more parental involvement. They've created wonderful workshops for parents, and there are such small turnouts. I'd like to see more respect from the district and the region."
"We have a lot of new immigrant kids whose parents are working just to make it," said a teacher.
"When the region comes through, they only tell us negatives," said a teacher. "Children here are well behaved. Parents very rarely come into the building without passes."
"They [the city] should model what they're telling us to do: Praise first," said a teacher. "We only get negatives. With no positive feedback, you get burned out."

For the 2006-07 school year, PS 183 is newly identified by the State Education Department as "in good standing."

"PS 183 made a great increase in math," writes Principal Peart. "In 2004, 52.3% of our fourth grade students scored at or above grade level. In 2005, 83% of our 4th grade students scored at or above grade level. The overall math scores increased to 42%. Which means in 2005 the math scores increased by 4%."

"PS 183 has made great improvement in the school year 04 --05," writes Principal Peart. "We have many after-school programs. Students in all grades can receive additional academic assistance after school and on Saturdays. The staff is dedicated to improving instruction. Many staff members come to work early and stay late in the evening to plan lessons. Also, teachers meet regularly to discuss the academic needs of the students. Teachers attend bi-weekly professional development workshops. Additionally, teachers regularly give up their lunch break to attend lunch and learn workshops. There are many instructional materials in the classrooms. The classrooms are not cluttered. Every classroom has an array of books. Each class has a library filled with over 300 books. Every student has science, social studies and math textbooks. Additionally, there are materials to support the balanced literacy program. Instruction and maintaining an orderly environment are our top priority. Teachers provide students with enriched challenging lessons. Also, teachers maintain an orderly environment in the classroom and hallways by reviewing school rules regularly. Teachers do not raise their voice. We will continue to increase parental support by providing parents with monthly parent workshops, parent meetings, conducting learning leaders classes and hosting evening events like shows, award assemblies, career day, etc. The PS 183 staff is committed to providing a standard based education in a nurturing and supportive environment. We are dedicated to our students and parents."
One parent says, "More parents are helping out at the school."

P.S. 197 is on a list of 50 schools that will participate in the DOE's Bronx Plan, which will boost salaries in hard-to-staff positions and "give teachers formal decision-making power in their schools" according to Chalkbeat.

Ninety-four low-performing schools are now called “Renewal Schools,” by DiBlasio. They will receive increased funds designated for an hour of additional learning time, after-school and summer programs, and teacher training. The principals will also be under review. Read more here.

After many of the local churches and community organizations that used to offer pre-K were damaged by Superstorm Sandy, Christina Villavicencio principal of P.S. 197 said running five pre-K classes next year will be challenging but worthwhile. Read more here.
