Hello, i am a fellow student attending MS 210. I am in the 8th grade and am in an accelerated/AP class. I will be taking four regents this year and let me tell you, this is school is much better than the reviews written below. The principal described in the article was fired and replaced by a man named Mr. Singh. Ms. Butcher, the old principal, was not the greatest in keeping the school in top shape. She did not have the best methods and harassed a couple of the staff members (this was the reason she was fired). However, she has left and Mr. Singh is doing a much better job.
   Our school is divided into academies and have certain programs that students in their individual sections can do. For example, the Visual Arts academy has classes such as theatre and can perform during our spring and winter festivals. In addition to that, rumors about teachers being "terrible" are not true. The staff at our school are nice people and can teach well. Many say that the teachers are bad due to their behavior and attitudes towards the teachers
   There are fights that occur in our school but that should not affect you in any way unless you're involved. Many also say they do not feel safe but absolutely nothing has happened that can ruin your life. The students are not threatening or very dangerous but they do have bad behavior; it's just a case of a "bad attitude." 
   Lunch isn't the greatest but that is not the school's fault, every other middle school in New York City is serving the same food. The cafeteria can be dirty due to the students who aren't capable of throwing out their garbage but, there aren't things such as food stuck to the walls.
   Personally, I love this school for the way it is but I wouldn't say it was your best option for middle school. If you're here to get a good, regular education, Ms 210 is the place for you. However, if you'd like an amazing education, you can earn it by getting grades to get you into an accelerated class (90 and above but, try striving for grades in the principal's honor roll range which is 94 and above. It'll guarantee you the chance of getting into an AP class). The curriculum is better and you get preparation for the regents (high school credits!). Being in an AP class gives you a larger work load but, if you aren't good with large loads of homework, a regular class would be best for you (I typically get 2-4 medium sized assignments everyday but that also depends on your teachers). 
   I hope this review helped and can help you choose your child's new middle school. If you are a student who is already ATTENDING the school, look on the bright side if your days here are going rough. You can ask for a transfer for a new class or maintain grades that will get you into an accelerated class (less troublesome students) for the next year. If you do have any questions, I'll do my best to answer them ASAP :)

Before he came these things didn't really happen often but now it does. He even created clubs for us which we did not have until now. JHS 210 students were the only team from the 5 boroughs to participate in the mock Legislature session in Albany, the Queens Chronicle reports.
Miyosha Steele, a first year teacher at JHS 210, tells Chalkbeat why she chose to become a teacher.

Hello teachers, parents and current/past/future students of Middle School 210,

One year ago today, one of the worst things happened in my life at Middle School 210. I will not describe it but today, I have come to speak the truth, the full and complete truth of Middle School 210.

First off, I am, unfortunately, an alumni of this place I am not proud of.
Thank God I graduated in June (of 2015).

Let me tell you, I was in ARP and the teachers were pretty good. I would like to give a shout out to those teachers (who I should keep nameless to conceal my identity if they or anyone who I mention in this reads it) Some administrators and most Deans (specifically Mr. Yulfo) there are completely unreasonable and are obnoxious. Especially Mr. Yulfo. He thinks he's above everyone and is better than everyone. He has a superiority complex.

Although I was in ARP, the kids still did drugs. There are drugs EVERYWHERE in 210, you just gotta look closely.

Contrary to what the people said down below, fights don't happen very often. But they do happen. (Just stay out of people's business and don't cause any issues with fellow students) And when they do, it is usually an isolated situation between two people who most likely had previous beef (issues). In my experience, the teachers were nice and fair but the students are backstabbers and fake.

Watch out for fake friends or people, because trust me, they can and will 
turn on you IN A HEARTBEAT. IN AN INSTANT. Everyday, I dreaded being in that place and I prayed every night it would be over. And when it was, I was the 
happiest person ever.

********************
FOR PEOPLE LOOKING FOR THINGS IN TERMS OF ACADEMICS: 
The school has an Advanced Regents Program that allows students to take the
 Living Environment Science/Common Core Algebra Regents in the 8th 
Grade. As well as Spanish I and II in 7th and 8th grade.
•Homework is usually in medium level, 2 hours if you understand the material and concepts
•STUDY HARD FOR THE REGENTS !!! (ESPECIALLY OUT OF SCHOOL, AT HOME) I received an 87 on the Living Environment Regents and 79 on Math (and trust me, I don't get very good grades) I studied every other day for 1.5 hours. Half math and half science.
****************

TIPS IN GENERAL:
•STAY OUT OF TROUBLE. THE DEANS WILL PUNISH YOU VERY BADLY, EVEN FOR THE SLIGHTEST THINGS. ESPECIALLY MR. YULFO. IF YOU ARE WRONGFULLY PUNISHED OR ACCUSED, DEFEND YOURSELF! DON'T BE INTIMIDATED BY THEM. TRUST ME, IT'S HAPPENED TO ME. (THAT IS ONE THING I REGRET NOT DOING WHEN I LOOK BACK AT MY 210 YEARS)
•Most people (both "good" and bad kids) there might be cool with you or be your "friend", but they are just fake. Unless you have been friends with them since Kindergarten, TRUST NO-ONE!
•Mind your own business when people are doing bad OR POSSIBLY ILLEGAL things or things they SHOULDN'T be doing, just walk away. (THIS IS ANOTHER THING I REGRET NOT DOING. SOMETHING MAY HAPPEN AND IT WILL NOT, I REPEAT, WILL NOT END WELL FOR YOU OR ANYONE)
•Don't act like the sheep or act scared, be yourself and if someone pushes you around, defend yourself!
•Definitely do your homework and classwork but don't try TOO hard. Do it enough to get a good grade. 
•Get to school ON TIME, some Houses will penalize you for be late, possibly detention or parents being called.
•Read the first tip!!!

This school has taught me lessons that I will always take with me in the 
future (in terms of street smarts), it has made me tougher, and stronger in my experience. I will never forget the things that have happened 
there. 

Make TRUE friends, do your homework, stay strong and you will have a decent time!

P.S. If anyone have any questions about the school, feel free to ask them down below and I will reply to them when I check this webpage occasionally.

PS 223 overall is a good school. I am the
parent of student who is now going into first grade. My daughter's Kindergarten
teacher Ms. Robinson was very involved and nurtured my daughter though this
sometimes difficult year of Kindergarten. Their parent coordinator and staff
are very inviting.  The security staff are especially on point, when it
comes to students entering and existing the building.  They have a free after
school program (lottery) which also has a free summer program sponsored by
COMPASS. 
I strongly believe that students can and will do well at any school with parent involvement.
Test scores, attendance and student performance all come down to how involved and engaged as a parent you are with your child and their school.
PS 223 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in English.
You are so wrong. I am a graduated student from that school and it was the best. Especially the COMPASS Program.

"My son likes his class and teacher," said the mother of a 4th grade boy and 3rd grade girl. "I love his teacher. She understands the children and their needs. I would like to see more parental participation and more social [non-academic] programs. It's a quiet school, aside from the lunchroom."

"It's a quiet school, apart from the lunchroom," said a 1st grade mother.

"The teacher dress code needs improvement," said a parent. "They wear mini-skirts, nasty-looking jeans, things we don't want kids wearing. If we don't want kids wearing baggy jeans and skirts, we should hold teachers responsible, too."

"I couldn't believe how few supplies the teachers had [in fall 2000]," recalled Gedacht. "There were no crayons, no pencils. There were broken computers and outdated textbooks."

"This school used to have a horrible reputation," said a special education teacher who joined the faculty in 2001. "Now, students are succeeding. The changes that have been made are remarkable. There is administrative support. When I need help with anything, I get extra help. I would like to see more parental involvement. I understand that a lot of parents work a lot, but they need to give a lot more support at home."

"I came from the chaos of a middle school," said a physical education teacher who joined PS 223 in 2002. "I was very pleased to see the structure here."

 "Before [2000], this school was an 'every man for himself' show," said a special education teacher who has been at PS 223 since 1998. "Six years ago, no parents showed up for conferences. I crocheted a blanket during those conferences. This year, I had all but one parent."

Parent Michelle Scott urges anyone who is curious about the school to visit. She writes: "My son entered this school in March 2002 from a private school that was less effective than PS 223. The school's principal remains the same since his entrance. He had an excellent first grade, excellent 3rd grade and scored Level 4 on the 3rd grade exam. I recently attended the 4th grade open night where I had a look at the curriculum-excellent! They have the Kaplan studies in effect, excellent resource room, well caring staff, an informed parent coordinator, and organized PTA." She adds: "The school may have had a torrid past, but the present is good and the future looks brighter with its small classrooms, added lower-grade vice principals, checkpoint security, crossing guard, library, music, psychologist and councilors ... The only downside is no GYM or extra activities."
Students from J.H.S. 226 won an award in this year's "We're Walking Here" competition with the Department of Transportation for their street-safety PSA poster, as reported by the Queens Chronicle.

I don't recommend going here because the environment is very unwelcoming and there has been many times where there were issues that weren't address. Please I DO NOT recommend sending you're child to this school, because of safety and lack of staff. This is not only a middle school but high school as well, which makes it more concerning.

"I attended this school in sixth grade and despite how much I want to say I dislike it, I have to admit that I did enjoy my one year in 226. However, just as many students say, if you mind your own business, then nothing will really happen. I almost got beaten a couple of times. Another thing is that some teachers make you feel worthless. In my opinion, that doesn't make sense and it ruins the whole gpa"

About 400 students and staff members were evacuated from the third floor of the building when a 15-year-old 8th grade released pepper spray, the New York Post reported on June 13, 2007. About seven people were taken to a hospital but none was seriously injured, according to the Post.

5th grade teacher, Gregg Kwarta, is a recipient of the prestigious Big Apple award, which recognizes "exceptional success in instruction, impact on student learning, and overall contributions to school communities," as reported by Chalkbeat.
Great school.

Angela Manekas, 4th grade teacher at P.S. 232, is one of the 17 recipients of the 2016 Big Apple Award. The Big Apple Award is a citywide recognition program that celebrates the incredible work of New York City public school teachers. Read more here.

There is a crowd of boys that the school knows work in tandem to bully their peers, and that act out in malicious ways (reports of bringing a knife to school, a faux-gun, following a student home and jumping a student after school among a few things) and yet the only action taken is a few days suspension.  Their history should have had them expelled by now so they are no longer a disturbance of a future threat to students who come to school to LEARN. All three of my childen attend PS 232 and I am extremely lucky to have all of my children in the same wonderful school. I strongly encourage and recommend this school for k-8 students, its amazing.

This school has changed from the time my child entered kindergarten 5 years ago. Staff is overwhelmed and need to be trained in dealing with students who do not reside in the neighborhood (bussed children from Brooklyn) The school is extremely focused on having students pass the state exams and have created robots that believe school is about tests and not about learning. Unfortunately I have no choice and must send my son to this school as we live in the neighborhood and cannot afford the insane tuition the neighborhood catholic school charges. Mr. Collins is the worst AP I have ever had the chance to meet and deal with. The man is unprofessional, incompetent and socially awkward, the complete opposite of Mrs. Leibman who would be a wonderful principal unlike colonel Josephson who is a bully and unapproachable.

This is a wonderful school. The early-grade teachers have all been phenomenal and Ms. Josephson and Ms. Leibman are excellent instructional leaders. Our son was lucky enough to have Mrs. DeClemente as his Kindergarten teacher and she is, hands-down, one of the best Kindergarten teachers in the City! Her welcoming presence helped our son transition to elementary school for the first time and he learned so much from Mrs. D! We recommend this school to any parents in Queens.

A parent complains that the school's cafeteria is frequently dirty and "foul smelling." This parent complains that the principal is "approachable, but she is not good with following through with interventions. She always has something to say to the parent that would make the parent hesitant about speaking up again."
PS 232 was identified by Standard and Poor's School Evaluation Services as having reduced the achievement gap between its students who are economically disadvantaged and those who are not.

A parent notes that Principal Josephson has started "a music program with a real music teacher who will start a school band next year" and that the school will include grades K to 8 beginning in September 2006.

"The new principal and asst. principal run a very tight ship and seem to make safety and instruction their priorities," writes parent Joanna Brigliaro. "There are a number of new music programs and soon there will be technology programs for the kids. Parents need to sign in and get passes before they can enter the building and that's a big improvement!"

Rosiel, a student, writes: "PS 232 is the best school I've ever been to; it's where I grew up and I'll never forget all the people in PS 232 who helped me throughout the years from kindergarten through 5th grade."

"I have nothing bad to say about [PS 232]," said the mother of a 3rd grader. "They're wonderful. My daughter went to Catholic school last year. Catholic schools are fine when [your child] is keeping up, but there is no additional help. They give a lot of extra help to students here."
"I think the teachers here could be more attentive and more patient," said the grandparent of a 1st grader. "My daughter wants to take him [the 1st grader] out and try home-schooling."
"They love their teachers," said a man whose nieces are in the 2nd and 3rd grades. "The kids get a good amount of homework. If they need extra help, they get it."
"We have a nice amount of volunteers," said Carolyn Russo, P.T.A. president. "We get a lot of help from them."
"I like art class," said a 1st grader. "I like making witches. I made a blind witch."
"Ms. McManus is very caring and very understanding," said a teacher. "She's not a dictator. It [PS 232] is better than a lot of what's out there in other schools. I've been there. I know."

"The principal has real compassion for the kids," said a teacher. "She's always present, always peeking in rooms. We have a very supportive administration. You can go to them for anything. What could improve here is the camaraderie among teachers. Most of the teachers are older and have been through what they've been through. I think they're getting ready to go."
"This principal has a very open-door policy," said Debra Falcone, parent coordinator. "It's not like other schools where I've worked. You can just walk in and see her."

A parent writes that her son transferred to the school in September 2003. "His reading which was his most difficult subject, has improved greatly," she writes. "His attitude toward school has changed. He now enjoys going to school. I could honestly say this is one of the better schools in Queens. Thank you P.S. 232."
The family of a boy who was hospitalized after a playground incident, charges that his injury was caused by bullying, not by an accident, the Daily News reports

The Channel View School was featured in an article by The Indypendent for its implementation of restorative justice practices. With restorative justice, the school hopes to change this by redefining what it means for a school to be safe without antagonizing its minority students.
The corner near the Channel View football field will be renamed "Midshipman Justin Zemser Way," in honor of the class of 2013 graduate who was killed in a 2015 train crash. Read more here.
LYFE center teacher Margaret Diercks-Henfling received the 2015 Big Apple Award for excellence in teaching. Read more here.

Justin Zemser, valedictorian of the Channel View graduating class of 2013, was killed in the recent Amtrack crash. Read more <a href=" http://ny.chalkbeat.org/2015/05/14/victim-in-train-derailment-leaves-lasting-legacy-at-queens-high-school/#.VVtk5Usuir1">here.
A Channel View student focuses on the path to graduation while working hard on a burgeoning rap career. Read more here.

Comments below are fairly old. My son has attended this school for the past two years, and I can say that it is a safe and caring environment, and the teachers are committed and enthusiastic. Coming from a Catholic school, he was shocked to find that it was equally, if not more, strict than his old school: the uniform code is narrow and there are few "dress down" opportunities, and students are never unattended in the building. However, the discipline is rooted not in punishments but in high expectations for achievement and good behavior. Students do seem to rise to those expectations. What's more, the teachers and other staff really push students to do their best, and to keep raising the bar for what their "best" might be. 


CVSR is housed on a large campus with other schools, but there is little interaction between them. My son has not had any incidents regarding safety, bullying, or general lack of respect since he started, and he feels completely safe in the building, as well as walking to and from school (we live a half mile away). There are metal detectors, and they cannot carry cell phones at all, so there was some apron string cutting to be done on my part, but he's a big boy and that's for the best if you ask me. 

Overall, we are very, very happy with Channel View, and I do recommend it to anyone in South Queens who is looking for a tightly focused and gimmick-free education for their child. Test scores reflect the fact that the school doesn't take just top performers--it accepts students of varying abilities who are hard workers and who have no disciplinary issues. There is an honors class in each grade, so advanced students can take 9th grade regents in 8th grade, an important factor if you are hoping to get into a competitive high school. But most kids do stay on through high school (CVSR goes from 6-12), with good reason. I strongly suggest getting them in for middle school, so they'll be set to continue through the high school if they want to. Few seats open up for 9th grade, as current 8th graders get first crack at the HS; even if they think they'd like to go somewhere else for high school, it's nice to know that they can stay at CVSR if they are happy there.
Gothamschools reports that six month after returning to their hurricane-damaged school, Channel View is still struggling to recover from Sandy.

I have to agree that PS306 has not been the same since Flandro left.  The many wonderful teachers that started that school and made it a family have slowly dissipated.  The bonds they created with our children are priceless and immeasurable.  My oldest son was able to be a part of that complete warmth and love until 4th grade, but sadly my youngest was not.  If not for his friends and the teachers, I would have transferred him.  Up to recently I was asked "When is Mrs. Flandro coming back, I miss her", my oldest prayed that Mrs. Flandro would surprise them for graduation and be there, he said she should have been the one that was there, and he was so disappointed that the yearbook didn't even mention her, he said her picture should have been there in the front. His almost entire existence at 306 was with Flandro.  She knew how to treat her staff as well as the parents and children. 

It would always surprise me at events of how many of the teachers would be there with their family.  It was such a wonderful and rare thing.  I used to boast about how wonderful the school was and how much it felt like family, where all the teachers knew all the children and parents alike.  We were encouraged to be a huge part of our children's education at school as well, not just at home, and we were made to feel welcomed by the school.  The teachers and parents didn't mind putting in the extra time and effort because there was mutual respect and admiration for one another, and boy did the children benefit, so much love and concern at school from teachers...(I mean who ever heard of such a thing)...it seemed like something from the movies, but it was our wonderful reality. When it came down to it, Flandro would get to work with the teachers and help everything, even at the events.  She was a genuine, welcoming smiling face whenever you walked into the school and will be sorely missed.  She knew every child's name, their sibling and parent or relative. She was truly a leader.  She created a wonderful school and it is so sad to see what it has become. 

It feels so cold and uninviting now that I don't even feel comfortable calling in to ask questions anymore.  I used to be able to call the office and say "Hi, my name is so and my kids are", but before I could say who my kids were, Mrs. Basso, another great loss and wonderfully genuine smile at the school, would say, Hi. Ms. so and so, and she already knew who I was.  But even if she didn't know my name you could tell she was smiling and easy to talk to.  I pray that Mr. Kalamaras, another great leader at the school does not go, as well as the other wonderful teachers there.  But it is NOT the teachers that make this school feel cold and uninviting now.

You have taken the words right out of my mouth!  It is so comforting to know that I am not alone in feeling what I do.  Overall, all the teachers are quite amazing.  Isn't it bizarre that since Ms. Leone's arrival, things have gone down hill. I am so disappointed.  It's about time parents such as yourself are voicing your opinions as it does matter!  I pray that the administration changes and we see someone new come in who is actually there for the kids and the staff, and doesn't have to have anything "REQUIRED."

Thank you so  much.  I hope other parents will come out and say how they feel too so we can take our school back for our children.  We are losing excellent teachers and its not fair to our children or to the teachers.  I hope the Board of Ed really takes into consideration what the parents are saying and takes notice and even question why so many teachers who were here from the opening of this school are now suddenly leaving under new management.  Why are our teachers so unhappy after years of nurturing and happiness with our children and with Flandro.  

Many children have also lost the respect that Flandro instilled in the kids when she was there.  You wouldn't see kids running in the hall or shouting out.  She taught the kids to have respect for everyone, teachers, parents and each other.  She also made sure kids kept their hands to themselves, no hitting or touching, playing or otherwise.  Her motto, "We keep our hands and feet to ourselves".

We need to spread the word.  Parents need to write letters to our superintendent or send emails to let them know how we feel about what is going on, even write our feelings on sites like this if we have to.  We need to be heard for the sake of our children.

I have to agree with Clara, we have lost so many great teachers since Mrs Flandro's absence. Definetely the demeanor of teachers and students have taken a turn that most of the parents can't help but wonder why. It is truly sad to see that we are no longer a closed family but only parents and strangers, and no much will be accomplished and our the students and the reputation of the school are going to ultimately be one more stratistic of a mediocre school. I can only hope that the chance to revert the negative comes soon through communication, flexibility, understanding, and above all unconditional love and care for the children, because at the end of the day, money and reputation will never replace the sincere admiration, gratitude, cooperation and love that we used to have. My suggestions, make the children feel welcome, Mr. Kalamaras was always outside in the mornings waiting for them, Mrs Flandro was always talking to the children, she showed them love and respect, Mrs Marino an excellent teacher. Leadership is not just a title, a salary, ego, or a benefit, leadership is a skill, is being able to be flexible, is know how to listen, and care, leadership is about be a fair team player, and most of all an approachable person so that all the people below will have the encouragement to work together and keep us parents supporting their hard work and goals. I miss the old PS 306 and I really wish we could get all those excellent teachers back.

It is quite sad to me that such a wonderful school has taken a turn.  Since Ms. Flandro's leave this past year, the school's culture has truly changed.  The teachers and staff continue to put their all into the students, it is the administration on the other hand that does not.  To them it is all about the appearances, rather than what matters most...the children.  My children have told me that of too many instances where they are unhappy.  If it weren't for the staff, I would have removed my children. On a daily basis, my childrens' learning is constantly interrupted with the constant announcements over the speaker, with birthdays, teacher, meetings, etc., Doesn't learning come first?  Why not have the announcements done Monday mornings, rather than on a daily basis.  How about the day that my child SAT outside in the cold for 45 minutes in less than 60 degree weather while the principal decided that this would be a great moment to have her staff look at bulletin boards?!  This is absolutely absurd to me!  Attendance to most events at the school as declined. It is sad to me to see so many staff members looking so sad and wanting to leave a school that they/we cherished for so long.  More and more teachers are going to want to leave if Ms. Leone stays.  As of right now she is "Acting Principal," I hope that it does not become the permanent principal!

I graduated Scholars' middle school in Spring of 2016. Although I left to attend Bard High School Early College Manhattan, I keep in close contact with those of my friends who stayed for the high school. In complete honesty, leaving Scholars (not staying for the high school) was the best decision I ever made going into adolescence. Yes, the school is rated high for diversity, but it handles that diversity SO poorly. Racism, sexism, anti-semitism, xeno-phobia and queerphobia is rampant, there is no concern for mental health of students, and administrators/teachers, in mine and my friends' experience, have never done anything to deal with this. The amount of rules that restrict students from expressing themselves to the most basic extent are absurd- separate academic and gym uniforms are required, and students are asked to pay a dollar if they want to wear normal clothes on assigned "dress-down days." Even then, there are rules prohibiting self-expression; the Parent Handbook (accessible on www.scholarsnyc.com) states that students can be punished for wearing things considered "disruptive" or "inappropriate," such as scarves, jewelry, any piercings, any dyed hair (even natural colors), and skirts (of no specified length). Students wearing shirts that are considered "political," i.e. graphic tees with slogans of movements such as "Black Lives Matter" or even "Love Wins," may be asked to **take their shirt off or miss class until their parents can come to school with new clothes for their child.** The Arts Department is extremely underfunded, with the theatre department only allowed $500 a semester to produce shows with complete sets, props, costumes, sound, and lighting, while the Athletics department is overfunded, receiving annual grants for new uniforms. Juuling and Vaping are also extremely popular among both high school and middle school students. In my time at Scholars, I have had person experiences with explicit anti-semitism, queerphobia, and a lack of concern for my mental instability. In reality, the social environment of Scholars' Academy is geared towards the prosperity of cisgender-heterosexual, white kids who are good test-takers and come from supportive middle-class families. Nonetheless, if you/your child prioritizes the school's academic and athletic reputation over the social environment and a promotion of critical thought/self-expression/self-exploration a child may need as they edge closer to adolescence, the Scholars' Academy may be a place where you/your child can thrive.

What scores are needed to even be considered for an interview at Scholars? Also does Scholars offer a waiting list?

High 3's and 4's on the 4th grade state exams and 3's and 4's (equivalent to a's and b's) on report cards. Some students with the highest grades in the applicant pool are considered for early admission. This enables students to be accepted without an interview

Scholars' DOES have a waiting list,however I think that you have to have been interviewed to be put on the waiting list. I know someone who was on the waiting list and ended up being offered a seat :) so good luck!

Dear Pepe693, according to the letter the school sent to me, the applying student's test score for 4th grade ELA must be 669 and higher.  The 4th grade math score must be 684 and higher.  If the student has the 5th grade scores (applying the sophomore year at Scholars' Academy I presume), then the score for ELA must be 683+ and math must be 702+.  Here's the link to the letter:
http://schools.nyc.gov/NR/rdonlyres/A63714E4-C1C7-404B-9EAF-C393864F1754/48811/CoverLetterofmsapplication20092010docCompatibility.pdf

However, I've heard that students get accepted to SA without interviews.  I can only guess that those students have very impressive ELA and math scores.  And oh, I don't have any info on waiting list.  I don't think waiting list is going to help much, good luck.

Oh and that link for the eligible scores is from 2008.It changes every year.I'm not sure what this years' scores were.When my daughter applied last year it was 681 for ela and 692 for math.This year it may have been a couple points lower.

A parent at the Chancellor's Parent Advisory Council (CPAC) meeting said that there is no longer a parent coordinator at the school, although all Empowerment Schools are supposed to have a parent coordinator. She also said that parents were concerned about other changes at the school instituted by the principal, especially concerning special education students.

PS 40 is on a list of schools that the DOE may close. The schools were on the state's persistently lowest achieving list last spring and have low tests scores, with fewer than 30% of the students reading at grade level. Additionally all but one received a "D" or an "F" on the city progress reports. After last year's union lawsuit prevented the city from closing 19 schools, a judge ruled that the city needs to communicate better with the schools' communities. This year officials are also considering closing the 19 schools identified last year. Education officials will also consider alternatives to closing the schools, including removing the principals and changing staff. Check this link in the Daily News.
Because of improvements in its test scores, PS 40 was removed from the state's list of schools needing improvement and is now considered "in good standing" under No Child Left Behind.

The teachers at PS 48 are among the best in NYC.  They are dedicated to the students and strive to create a warm, inviting, and engaging environment in which students can learn.  The students who attend PS 48 are for the most part, respectful and well-mannered and  display a desire to succeed in all that they do.  The new PS 48 building is beautiful and highly conducive to learning.  Each classroom is equipped with SmartBoards and each student had access to laptops on a regular basis.  PS 48 boasts an impressive gymnasium, auditorium, and library where students can learn and grow academically, emotionally, and physically.  In addition, the administration of PS 48 sets high expectations from both their teachers and students, and strive to include parents in all aspects of their child's education.

PS 48 is a neighborhood school that strives to serve the best needs of all members of the school community.  We have worked very hard to make sure that all of our students achieve academic success. Our attendance rates have gone up, our after school programs are thriving and teachers spend much of their own time working with small groups of students making sure that they aquire the academic skills that they need to meet the current learning standards.

The inaccuracy of the above article is appalling.  As veteran teachers in the building we are in a position to refute the appalling inaccuracies of the above article.  Our attendance is among the most improved in the city.  Our Parent Coordinator is the hard-working and dedicated and unrelenting in her dedication to our students and their families.  As veteran teachers we can attest to the unstinting dedication of the staff.  Our teachers give of their time and their personal funds to support the education of their students.  They arrive before the sun comes up and often leave the building at night.  Many teachers have lunch with their students and work with them during their free periods.    Many teachers buy books for our students, provide them with notebooks and pencils, and have even bought their own copy machines to support their students' work.  It would be appropriate to visit our school and find out the facts before publishing such scurrilous   and false information.

PS 48Q is a school which works to overcome its deficits by reaching out to community based organizations to render support to the students. When PS 48Q's budget was cut and the students' reading services were cut, the school sort outside agencies to fill the void for our at-risk students. 
PS 48Q is a school which works  to overcome any obstacles for their students.

Take the opportunity to walk in the building and sit in the seats...Teachers spend hours upon hours meeting with students, calling families when there is a need, and researching information to provide multiple access points to engage students in active learning.  The use of data is amazing.  Teachers observe, use baseline data to assess, communicate with parents via internet and through 'snail mail' routinely.  This is indeed a family that has dedicated itself to living out the village community adage of 'taking care of a family' (not just a child), builds a better community, then nation and finally world.  If you want to see a multiplicity of methods used to teach students who are facing challenges diagnosed and undiagnosed, take a seat and learn  from P.S. 48 and the leadership of Ms. Pat Mitchell and Ms. Vanessa Christensen!

I am very happy with this school. I think that the Principal is doing an outstanding job, as are the teachers and other administrators. I see a very strongly coordinated effort to make sure that the children are being taught not only on an intellectual level, but also an interpersonal level. Being able to get along and communicate with one's peers is critical in today's world. The caliber of education that my children are receiving is excellent. I know because I've done my research.  I, also, appreciate that the principal, teachers, and administrators are instilling a strong work ethic via homework and other projects ----- a strong work ethic that will be carried by our children into adulthood. My children are given a chance, on a regular basis, to exercise at the school's playground. It is a small playground, but the staff manages the play period well. I know because I've made it a point to stand outside, and actually watch what is going on in the playground. I also appreciate that sound eating habits that are encouraged. I know a lot about what is going on at the school because I speak with my children every day, and I ask them about what is going on at the school. I also make it a point to reach out to the teachers with any questions, and they are diligent about responding.  The Parent Coordinator has been very helpful in directing me to the appropriate parties if I have any concerns outside of classroom activities. I have also spoken to other staff members, and they have been very helpful. The Principal has instituted a very good chain of command at the school, and has surrounded herself with an excellent staff. As such, any concerns I may have had were addressed quite well.  I appreciate the organized fashion in which the principal runs this school, and the discipline she insists on.  I feel very confident that the well-balanced approach that the principal is utilizing in managing this school, is preparing my children for the rigors of the work world in the future. I also feel confident that my children will succeed in life because of the superb partnership I have in our very dedicated staff, teachers, and excellent Principal.

Paulette Foglio wants to keep parents and their probing questions at arm's length. When I approached her with a problem I was having with my daughter's teacher, she said, You cannot just walk up and talk to me, as though she were royalty. Speak with the teacher, she said. I had already done this. I had to ask, Where is your secretary. How can I make an appointment. She responded arrogantly, Across the street. She was just standing there, holding the door after school. She could have spoken to me. Most of the grant money this school receives is siphoned off for programs to help the bottom 20 percent of students. This isn't fair to the majority of normally developing students. I would hate to work under her. Worse, though, is to have a child go to school with such a callous administration that thinks it is never wrong.

Speaking of callous, don't you think that speaking of "normally developing students" and with such contempt for special needs students is rather...callous?  I was on your side until you did that.  Those are my children you're talking about.

PS 99 has a very competent parent coordinator, who does his best to respond to parents, but like most of the staff and administration, his hands are tied and every decision is left to the principal. As a concerned parent who likes to be involved in my children's education, the school has really pushed me out. Some teachers are truly outstanding while most others really don't understand their students' emotional needs, making learning very difficult. PS 99 is a school with the potential (concerned parents and bright students of the Kew Gardens community) to be the shining star of the district. Unfortunately all that potential is being wasted."

That review is a joke!  Ms. Paniagua has nothing to do with changes in school grade as she was not Principal during period graded and came in only mid-year last year.  Community was happy to see Valerie Capitulo gone and, after a semester with an interim Principal who was not given permanent position, also happy to see Ms. Paniagua in place and 10 years of transition hopefully ending.

This review is out of date:  Valerie Capitulo-Saide quit her job at end of 2011, leaving the NYC school system,  and is no longer principal, after giving several beloved 15 year + teachers negative reviews that put them on probation.  Satisfaction at 101, both parent and teacher, remains mixed, with a school grade of C in 2012-2013 school year and a 2011 and 2012 decline in overall test scores.  

If the teachers reviewed Valerie Capitulo-Siade as a good manager, it was only because they were scared for their jobs.  Monique Lopez - Paniagua is 101's current principal, having started mid-semester in 2013, and making her 101's FIFTH principal in last 10 years (shame on the DOE for allowing that to happen!!!).

Also:
-2012-2013 is last year for 6th grade at 101.
-Class size in most grades is now 30+ kids as almost all grades that had about 100 kids in 4 classes (2nd, 3rd, 4th, 5th) are combined into 3 classes.
-Only "seniors", which were 6th graders and going forward will be only 5th graders, have opportunity to participate in the school play.  No other theater is taught at 101.
-4th, 5th and 6th graders have had no art instruction AT ALL until the 2012-2013 school year, when they went from nothing to art sometimes every other week (and sometimes not at all).
-4th and 5th grades participate in a truly wonderful ballroom dancing program, but there is no other dance at the school.
-Physical Education at 101 is truly "education", in that the kids spend 90% of time writing in their notebooks and really only get to run around when there's a substitute teacher.  The school is very good at picking select programs, like "Mighty Milers", to get good public relations spin for something to hold up as how great their PE program is.
-Hot lunch food is truly inedible (my kids eat anything/everything and they refuse to eat the school food).
-Afterschool program is run by the PA, which is comprised overwhelmingly of stay at home parents.  The program offers a nice break for stay at home parents who need a little extra time in the afternoon as it runs only part of the school year (starting a month or so after September school year start and ending about a month before last day of school) and adds an additional 1 1/2 hours of occupied kid time after school dismissal (afterschool is over at 4:30).  Kids enroll on a semester basis and there is no ability to participate in the program on a "drop in" or one day basis.  Unlike many other elementary schools' afterschool program, PS 101's does nothing to accommodate needs of working parents.
-101's PA does hold meetings sometimes in the early morning and sometimes in the evening, and PA touts this as accommodate to working parents.  Diversity of PA meeting time is mandated by DOE.
2015 - 6th Grade still at 101!
...and aferschool program options expanded so that there's now a later ending option too...
What are the middle school choices for PS 101 grads?

Generally, for zoned for choices, this would be Russell Sage.  However, you should check your specific address on the DOE website, to find out more info.  In addition, there are many kids in the neighborhood who apply for middle school options elsewhere, such as Louis Armstrong (Queens unzoned middle school), and middle schools in Manhattan, such as Manhattan East (MS 224).  There are also some options that are only for 7th graders, such as Hunter and the Baccelaurate School (LIC); these schools also attract many graduates of PS 101.   Most PS 101 kids do very well in middle school, as 101 has traditionally been one of the strongest elementary schools in Queens.  And Russell Sage, which most 101 kids would feed into, is also very strong.
Thank you that was very helpful

You are very welcome!  I forgot to mention that there is also a new 6-12 school choice for Forest Hills kids, and District 28 kids, generally -- Metropolitan Expeditionary School, in Forest Hills Gardens, along its southern border.  While I know parents who like it, especially those parents in the far reaches of Forest Hills, and just beyond, who have been zoned for not so great middle schools, this is not a school for high achieving kids aiming towards a specialized or selective high school.  However, it is an engaging and safe choice for C to B+ students who want to stay close to home for middle school, or who wish to attend a smaller middle school than Russell Sage, with more individualized attention.  Most of the students at this school stay on for high school, which is also understandable, given that it is a very long trek to Forest Hills High School from the back of Forest Hills Gardens, Middle Village, etc., and also, some of the border areas are not zoned for Forest Hills High School, but instead are zoned for under performing high schools well outside of the neighborhood.

The traditional strength of PS 101 has been based on its traditions: the old curriculum, the experienced principal, the real library with weekly book selection and check-out.
It remains to be seen how weak or strong PS 101 students will be after several years of leadership instability and the experimental "serve industry" focus of the Bloomberg curriculum.
Some of us will never accept as a "good school" a place that does not have a full library collection with weekly book check-out, a developmentally appropriate kindergarten and a law-abiding attitude towards PE instruction.

Looks like we hit pay dirt with our new principal.  This person is exceptional.  As a parent who has had children in the school for the past 9 years, I feel rejuvenated by Ms. Paniagua.  Change is a comin' and it's going to be great!

Any specifics? For example, are they going to start obeying state law and provide gym every day for K-6? Are they going to reduce Kindergarten homework to a developmentally appropriate "none"? Are they going to obey common sense and come closer to the city average size of a K class of 22 or fewer? One can only hope.

SaneMomNo9 - I am guessing you volunteer as a recess helper, and help supervise more than just your own kid's class?  That you also donate large amounts of money to help alleviate the financial strain caused by DOE budget cuts, including loss of teacher salary funding - or assist in other fundraising, grant writing, or one of the other of myriad of things that we parents can give of ourselves and our stuff to alleviate that financial strain? Are you involved in the PA or SLT, or joined one of their committees to research curriculum, overcrowding and most other things relating to school academic and social life?  Or maybe you are a class parent, which is something even a working parent can do to help out?


It takes a village - of people putting actions where words are, not playing victim and busting their butts to move the mountain that's the DOE.  I'm guessing you are working to do that?

Your attitude illustrates one of the greatest crimes at 101: the idea that insiders should get more of a hearing when problems arise, and more privileges than outsiders. Is this the Soviet Union?
Insiders are those who volunteer and donate a lot; outsiders are everybody else. You're wrong on this and it's part of what's holding 101 back: 101 is a public school and is is there to serve, not a school co-op and not there to be served.

101 answers to the citizens and parents, not the other way around.
But yes, yes I did do a lot of volunteering, donating, giving up work clients to work as a recess volunteer, etc. And when I did, I heard your attitude expressed many times by people in power. Any time a problem came up in conversation with an "enfranchised" person ... staff member, PA Officer, volunteer ... they would sing the chorus about how parents have to go about complaining the right way and that you don't go about complaining if you haven't volunteered and donated.
Darned if all of the kids called on -- multiple times -- during the Open School visit weren't the kids of PA committee heads! What a coincidence!
I'm not interested in "busting my butt" to buy test-prep computers and copy paper so 11 pages of homework can be given to 4- and 5-year-old kindergarten students on Veteran's Day weekend. I'd rather use my 1st Amendment rights to call them as I see them.
News flash: You Are Not Entitled To Anything Special From An Arm of The Government, Funded By The Taxpayers, Even If You Spend Countless Hours On PA and SLT and CEC Committees. You are entitled to Serve in the role of Unpaid Public Servant if you volunteeer, Period, End of Conversation, All You Get is the Glow of Doing Good, Like it or Leave it.

SaneMom9 - This is not at all what I meant and, trust me, I am not one of "the insiders".  My only point is that in these days of attack on public education, in NYC at least, simply paying taxes and sending your kid to public school will not get you a rational or quality education for your child.  Bureaucracy, politics, administration all seem to take precedence in NYC education.  If you want to push back effects of all these things, you have to get up off your butt and work hard to make it so.  And if you are working or unable to give monetary donations, find other ways to make it so.  Simply complaining won't make it happen, won't wring some perceived entitlement out of a broken system, and is not productive.   It is your child's education.  How wonderful that they see you at school or doing other things to benefit their school where they spend most of their waking hours every week, and you are contributing to their community.  


Know also that the NYC public schools that do well all share two things: Consistent leadership that's willing to take maverick approach to getting their particular school what it needs to thrive - and a unified parent group that voices it's wants  with a unified voice.

Our schools are too important for me to let these intellectual errors slip by. We are not going to "push back" the effects of bureaucracy, politics, and administration, as you put it, by donating time or money...that simply supports the status quo. Speaking up will help: it tells the Emperor he has no clothes and empowers other people to say so. I don't want a "NYC school...that does well," we've been told to expect, and I want, world-class schools. Forest Hills will never had a unified parent group until people see examples of speaking truth to power; the parents in this neighborhood are either too overwhelmed by corporate life or too cowed by the power structure. 101 doesn't even come close to taking a maverick approach or to having a unified voice among parents. How can you have a "unified voice" when you have nothing to say because everyone is afraid to name problems and talk about them, when everyone knows that when you speak up someone like you will stand up and say, "Stop talking and start donating time/money."

You're making another common mistake -- buying the party line that "helping" means keeping one's mouth shut, the assumption that people who speak up about problems are complaining, and the idea that people who speak about problems aren't on committees and aren't donating time or money.

I am up off my butt. What are you doing for the schools? Are you going to stop "shushing" people like me and find the guts to confront the new "paydirt principal" about gym time and K class size? Or are you going to continue to hide behind the bake sale counter, continue to attempt to shame the people like me who speak truth to power?

I feel as though my child went to Kindergarten during 2011/2012 at a different school than SaneMomNo9.  Perhaps I am not so "urbane" as she to have had the capacity to comprehend what really was occurring around me?  Maybe I bumped my head while bowing down to the principal amidst the full capacity audience (not!)?

The children I saw were never shoved, nor ripped away from parents, nor did they get chastised for asking for some more, Sir.  My child loved school, loved his teacher amd loved his principal.  He is very much looking forward to first grade as well. Nearly all the children seemed to feel the same way.  Certainly there were a few exceptions, and a few children continued to cry right until to the very last day, but, invariably, those very same children (at least in my child's class)  were happy and engaged by the time I saw them during school activites like Friday Sweet times, during which parents may come to class and read, do a craft, etc., with the kids.  

I was pleased with the communication level in the school, had many opportunities to join in workshops, in-class activities and extra curricular fun, as well as voice opinions and concerns during PTA meetings (which, unfortunately, are extraordinarilly poorly attended).

P.S. 101 is a public school, and with that comes many grievances that are engendered by poor funding, constantly changing state and city reqirements, Board of Ed/Bloomberg policies, etc.  I truly cannot imagine having to put up with all that our teahers are faced with in NY (including interferance by all those sophisticated parents) and still doing as good a job as they manage to in 101.

PS, there's a difference between a principal who "appears before a full capacity audience" to give a speech and then leave the room and a principal who takes as many questions as parents want to ask and answers them all fully. Some schools have them - principals who are capable of explaining why rest time is prohibited in Kindergarten (even if their parent coordinators confess to colluding with the teachers to sneak in a nap for certain kids), principals who say yes, we agree that we need a rainy-day recess solution, are there any parents willing to come in and organize the kids to play games in the auditorium on rainy days?
Other schools have principals who say no, there are no parents allowed in the auditorium on rainy days because the aides "need time alone with the kids" (why is anyone's guess,) and no, children are not allowed to take books into the auditorium during Sponge Bob time or the book will be confiscated.
There are even principals right within this very district who say Yes Please, we DO want parents helping 4-year-olds to open their milk cartons at lunch, and Yes Please, we'd love to have parents start a volunteering rotation inside the clasroom because we don't have enough school aides and our classes are enormous. They are principals who are modern-minded, open-minded problem solvers.
And then there are principals who don't welcome parents inside the school but instead feel threatened by it.
Our tax dollars would be best spent by hiring the modern, open-minded, problem-solving, open-door-type principal. There's a difference between security that protects children and security that helps to hide problems because you don't want to admit you have them.

Good for you! They must have fixed their first day of school problem. Apparently it was well-ordered, friendly, organized, and made the children feel welcome.
So the kindergarten teacher called each child by name, greeted them with their parents, and had them all together as a group before they walked upstairs together? The Kindergarten teacher knew exactly which kids were there that day and which were not before leaving the gym where the parents were? Glad to hear it.
Also glad that your child liked Developmentally Inappropriate Kindergarten. It IS good for a few kids. Of course, research shows that it's not the best education, but we wouldn't want our schools to be driven by -- um - scholarly research, right?
Instead, most parents either think their kid is too smart for a play-based program (even gifted children should learn through discovery play at age 5) or are afraid they'll give the impression that their kid isn't smart because they advocate for play. I got that; my kid is plenty smart, but everyone told me that maybe my child wasn't "ready" for academic kindergaten.
Hey, what can I tell you. One of the things I learned in public school was how to do research; and the research shows that playful kindergarten leads to -- drumroll please -- higher test scores. But that's ok, 101's test scores are already high enough. Right? They are, aren't they?

The school has now learned the consequences of hiring someone who is connected rather than someone who has a strong intellect. This is a neighborhood full of doctors, lawyers, academics, journalists, entrepreneurs, investment bankers and other highly urbane, sophisticated hardworkers. It needs a principal with the guts to stand up before a crowd of parents and actually answer questions as if this is a modern institution -- this is not the 1950s where the principal spoke and everyone bowed down. Parents expect accountability, not just to the DOE but to the taxpaying public.
It needs a principal who is willing to examine curriculum and make changes and admit mistakes, whether the mistake is made by the principal or a staff member.
Most of all, it needs a principal who treats children as if this is the 21st century, not London under Dickens.
These are children being educated, children who need to be guided over time into correct school behavior with an appropriate school-readiness program in Kindergarten. Many schools have open houses on the first day where parents can visit the classroom with the children; 101 just shoves everyone into the gym and then the 4- and 5-year olds either run to find their teacher or are ripped from their parents at the door.
When a first grader is throwing a tantrum at the door of the school in late November, as I witnessed last year, the solution must go beyond a call to the parents and punishment for the child. A child that age throwing a tantrum at the school's door is terrified of something, maybe simply terrified of failing, and he needs compassionate counseling to be able to achieve.
Most children don't even remember pre-K by the end of Kindergarten, you can't assume they learned everything they need to know about school by the start of Kindergarten.

Principal Valerie Capitulo quit this week, leaving the NYC system to be principal at an elementary school in Nassau County - and giving PS 101 a wonderful opportunity to hire a principal with true classroom teaching experience, a genuine concern for the education of all of our children and the intelligence and interpersonal skills to both keep the lights on and the parents' voices acknowledged - and get the teachers what they need to teach our children (e.g., no more keeping ballroom dancing and not having enough money in budget for classrom books).  I am sad that my entering 4th Grader will have three (!!!) principals during her 101 tenure, but ever hopeful that this change will bring true talented leadership to 101 and restore this once wonderful school to it's former self.

No school is perfect and I was not deeply disturbed as other parents were when PS101 received a C in its last School Report. What disturbs me is the cool and unwelcoming attitude a certain staff member in the main office showed to parents when they came in to the office on school related business. This gives a very poor impression of PS101's school administration to parents, incoming and otherwise.

PS 101 seems far from a way to an "A"...by discontinuing their account with Artsonia where every child is an "artist".  Only a few pieces of artwork and "artists" are named on a weekly basis on USTREAM.  They used to stream the PTA meetings on a monthly basis, which I found to be quite informative and convenient since I work...but that has been discontinued as well, for whatever reason.  A strong music program or perhaps chorus for all grades would be a tremendous benefit because by reading the lyrics, children will learn to read in no time.  The after school program needs revamping.  I would not hesistate to enroll my child, if the program offerings were creative and enriching.  Do we really need 3 martial arts programs? children need to be challenged with fun and educational programs like instrumental lessons, robotics and chess from 1st grade & up [god knows we need it based on our math scores], modern dance or glee or kids, basketball lessons, more language lessons [french, chinese] and science experiments.  Next,  science and social studies, boy do we need to pull up those test scores.  A $4-$5 fee per child from 1st grade - 5th grade should be included on the supply list so that each class may subscribe to Kids Discover magazine, which will enhance PS 101's science and social studies curriculum.  The teacher can make photocopies of the articles and have the children read, summarize in writing and quiz them on a bi-weekly basis.  Lastly, teachers have a difficult time bringing the class up to standards if they have to teach a class of 24 children of various reading and math abilities.  The advanced children are left to work on their own, while the teachers spend most of the day/week bringing the others up to speed.  Starting from 1st grade - 5th grade, divide the children into 2 advanced classes and 2 average classes.  It is a win win situation for the teachers and parents.  If I was a parent with a child in an average class, you bet I will push my child to work a little harder to make it to the advanced class the following year.  This will bring us from a "C" grade to an "A" grade in no time...otherwise the bright kids from 3rd - 5th grade will leave for better schools in other districts.

Jenny, You are correct on all counts and your ideas are great. How about having the after school program start when school starts in September and running on same schedule as school (and not starting mid-Semester in October and ending before the last day of school)?  Or having after school program run until 6:00 every day so that it is truly available to working parents (and not until 4:30, which requires working parents to hire childcare)?  That's how it's done in most public elementary schools and not a crazy idea - just an idea beyond the conception of 101's PA.  My personal thing is to have field trips connect to our children's curriculum so that, for example, a third grade class studying the rain forest goes to the Museum of Natural History to see the Butterfly Exhibit and the Hall of Biodiversity - instead of to Sony Wonder to play video games and have no before or after trip discussion of the technology they saw.  Curriculum at 101 is flat and uninspired and taught wholeheartedly to the middle.  Agreed.

My comments have more to do with InsideSchools than PS 101...This review of 101 is hopelessly out of date and inaccurate. I've been reading these words for 10 years and it in no way reflects our experience at the school. Sadly, it is no longer one of the highest-rated schools in the city; it has a C rating, and had a B for several years. PS 101 does not have its own gifted and talented program; it has one gifted class that will disappear when those students graduate.
We would love to update our review. We have repeatedly requested to visit the school and have had no response from the administration. Any ideas on what we might do?

Insideschools - please keep trying!  RG98765's assessment is accurate on all counts.  We moved to this neighborhood relying in great part on IS review of 101 and appreciate how valuable accurate information on IS is.  My only suggestion is to keep calling to schedule a visit.  In the meantime, would be great for IS to list comments in chronological order, with most recent comments first (including your response to RG98765).
Using our DISQUS comments system you can order the comments so they show up by newest first. See the drop down menu. You can select newest first, popular now, best rating and oldest first.
...also...two grades in the school (this year the 4th and 6th Grades) receive no Art at all for entire year...
A parent complained about a biased account of Israeli history. Read more: Parent Complains of Bias in Sixth-Grade Lesson.

The New York Times reports on parent complaints at PS 101. They say that the school is high-performing but it's too much work and not enough play for kindergartners. Read the full article: At One School, a Push for More Play Time.

In just the few short months of our new principal, community spirit and sense of collaboration between administration, teachers and parents is blossoming. This principal gets it and the school has become much more parent-involvement friendly. Communication is one of her priorities and since she took on her new role she has created her own massive e-mail list so she can communicate directly with families. Also, the website (which is updated by volunteer parent and very, very time-intensive) is so popular it's use has grown exponentially in the past 6 months. This is a wonderful community and quality teaching staff. I feel relieved that the new principal has turned out to be so effective and dedicated.

Communication and dissemination of information still needs to be greatly improved in this school, despite the new Principal's stated intentions for improvement in that area. The monthly curriculum charts and newsletters on the school's website are not updated in a timely and accurate manner. Parents with kids in K-2 cannot rely on their children for accurate and complete information on what they are doing in school, and it is not feasible for parents to email the class teacher every other day with such questions.
Principal Feder resigned. Now 101 awaits (with fingers crossed) new principal.

Overcrowding continues at the School in the Gardens. Parents calling the school last June about availability of seats in the G&T program for Sept. 2009 were told that the class was already filled. Yet more than a week after school re-opened, 3 new students were added in September and in October to this G&T class. There needs to be better communication between the school and DOE about enrollment numbers.

"We LOVE this school. We have 2 children, 3rd grade and Pre-K and overall their education is well above average and the community at the school is wonderful. That's not to say that we haven't been through a rough year with a lot of dissatisfaction with the overcrowding problems caused by poor decisions by the DOE and administration and how it's been handled by the PA. Mistakes were made, but it's because the parents at this school care so much that sometimes conflicts will arise. No school is perfect, but our principal's greatest strength is that she's an excellent educator and managers her teachers wonderfully, directing them into areas that bring out their strengths. Communication is not always good and needs improvement, but these people care, teachers, parents, administrators, they really care. That's the kind of environment I want my children to learn in."
Community organizations pitch in to save graduation festivities at PS 117. Read more here.
this is the best school ever
Eighty-year-old teacher Lillie Leon is suing PS 117 for wrongful termination. Read more: 80-year-old teacher sues to get job back after arguing with school about bathroom breaks.
"I went to this school from kindergarten to sixth grade and i think it was a really good school and I'm happy I got to go there for 7 years."
"This school rocks," writes student Rida. "If you need something someone's always there to help. If your parent dosen't speak English they help them."

"PS 117 has good teachers and a principal who really care about the best interest of students," writes parent L. Chen. "All students receive state test preparation and lunch for free! The school has an after school program for a reasonable fee."
Teacher Debra Cassidy says, "We're lucky here. We have few discipline problems because the administration is behind you, making sure the kids are doing what they need to do."

"Parents of the many Asian children in the gifted program"--from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, China, and Korea--"put very strong value on education," says gifted education teacher Susan Herschenhous. "They come to the U.S. for the educational opportunities. On open school night, they come in droves. They want the absolute best for their children."
Chorus member and 6th grader Adriana says, "I would change the playground rules so we could run."
Elizabeth, a student in the school chorus, says she would change school policy so the playground wasn't restricted, "so everyone can go."

The school food manager is attuned to culture-specific food choices. On days when the city Department of Education menu offers pork, she always prepares an alternative for kids who adhere to Islamic dietary laws. "If the kids don't eat ham, we can't give it to them," she says.
"The teachers are the best and they care about us so much," writes a student, who adds that there are discipline problems in the cafeteria and that many bathroom locks are broken.

"This school is a very nice school," writes student Violetta, who notes that her only complaints are that the lunch period is too short and the library is not always available for everyone who wants to use it.

A student, writes: "PS 117 is a very nice school. My teacher, Mrs. Mucci, is very helpful in everything. I think that all children should go to this school." However, she adds: "The problem that I have is when the 6th grade gets in trouble [with the lunch aides]. Most of the time everyone gets in trouble -- even the good kids get in trouble."

Amanda, a former student, writes that she'll "never forget [PS 117]." She writes: "[I went there from] 1st grade to 6th grade. It has to be one of the greatest public schools in Queens. ... Everything about that school was great. You feel right at home. The teachers are your friends, not your commanders, even though they do a good job at being strict. I met so many friends in that school." She notes that although many of her friends went on to MS 217, she did not.

A former student writes: "I grew up in this school. ... Once you get into the school you will feel the warmth, friendliness, and love of the administration, teachers and students." She praises the school's active drama program and dedicated instructors. However, she complains that the bathrooms were sometimes messy and ill-equipped.

"I went to 117 since Kindergarten," writes a student. "It's a wonderful school. I just graduated so I can say that the teachers are very strict, but they look out for your best interest. Now that I'm going to my new school 217, all I have to say is that I will miss and always remember 117."

A recent graduate writes: "What can I say, I spent most my life in this school and it is a very very good school. Met alot of my good friends here, and I went all the way from K to 6 getting really good grades and all."

"I think that my school, is a very good school," writes a 6th grader. She complains about the school aides who "dont care for us like there sopose to" and writes, "we have no toilet paper and the bathrooms in the 3rd floor have no locks. But other then all that other stuff my school is a wonderful school for math grades and reading grades. This is my school and it is a wonderful school."

If unpleasant Admission staff is a tell-tale sign of how my daughter will be treated,I am hesitant. W/o a smile, she asked for the G & T offer letter w/ required docs and plops paper in front of me.I told her the P.S. near me said they will send the same forms to P.S 121. She says  'that may be what they said but for this school, you have to fill all this out..'   No welcome to the school or friendly w/ the child. Office staff is the face of ur school. How they treat me tells the environment my child will be in. If office staff has an attitude, how are teachers? If office staff can not show my child w/ a warm smile, how do teachers respond? If it is unpleasant for a parent to deal w/ your office staff, how unpleasant will it be to deal teachers? I understand that I can't  generalize what teachers will be based on an unhappy woman.The school atmosphere is reflected by every staff.Again, this is my experience &no one else has to agree.When I experience rude people,I don't get warm fuzzy feeling.P.S. 121 should want the parents feel good their child is in this school not that they have to choose this school(b/c there is no other choice).
The school has declined under Mrs. Vadi's leadership.

According to the city Quality Review Report, "Education throughout the school is driven by high expectations and challenge. Students have no doubt as to what is expected of them, and in discussion often talk about 'learning' being the most important part of school for them."

"A lot of the parents are recent immigrants and don't know that the school is open to them," says the parent coordinator, as a partial explanation for why parent involvement is low. "They call me up and say 'sorry to bother you.' I want them to understand that it is my job to help them."

A student writes that PS 121 is "the best school in the world." He writes: "Teachers encourage us to grow as students and as individuals. PS 121Q is more like a family than a school, and Mr. Somers is like our father."
